Dear Sir:

This is to certify that I inspected the electric wiring installation in the new Duck Lake Indian Industrial School on Monday afternoon, March 2nd.

The wiring is a concealed conduit system and the lighting fixtures and ceiling lights were all attached and in place.

Sir:

Referring to your #109-1-5 dated the 17th instant, I have to advise you that on the 16th Mr. A. Taillon forwarded direct to you from Duck Lake the final certificate in favor of Messrs. Smith Bros. & Wilson, and furnished me with a signed copy. As I note from your letter referred to that you wish me to certify to the correctness of the certificate I enclose signed copy sent to me by Mr. Taillon, duly certified to by myself and trust that payment will be made upon receipt thereof as the contractors are desirous of receiving payment not only of the amount of this final estimate, but of the amount of their deposit cheque when they submitted the original tender.

In regard to the second paragraph of your letter asking for a copy of the agreement made with Mr. Matthew Wylie as to the payment of 10% for work supervised and performed by him. I beg to state that no formal written agreement was entered into the agreement being merely a verbal one. You will recall that it was the intention to accept Mr. Wylie's tender to perform certain electrical work at the school. However, I thought it would be a better arrangement to buy the equipment direct from those who were in a position to furnish it and make separate arrangements with Mr. Wylie to install the equipment and provide the necessary labor etc., on a 10% basis and this arrangement I entered into with him verbally.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham
Indian Commissioner

Dear Sir:

In reference to the conversation held in your office on the 10th inst. re-accessory buildings which are very badly needed close to the new school, I beg leave to ask the Department that:

1. A new hen-house be built to accommodate 250 chickens. The old one is 1300 ft. away, it is a long building in bad shape, too small and not sanitary. The school will furnish most of the material as you can see on the sheet of specifications attached to this.

2. Two Indian houses be moved close to the new school. The two buildings are on the grounds about 1200 ft. from the site of the new school. With little cost for the moving, a new concrete foundation and a few repairs, they would accommodate the Indian visitors for many years.

3. A new modern cow stable be built. The old one is nearly half a mile away and in a very bad shape. It is built on the ground without concrete foundation, practically no roof and very far from the water supply; said barn should be large enough to accommodate at least 30 cows. You know better than I do what the cost will be. There is lots of material in the old barn which could be used but I think there is no contractor who would like to use second hand lumber.

I would ask, dear Mr. Graham, to recommend these estimates and we will start the work as soon as we are allowed by authorities.

Sincerely yours,

(Signed) Rev. H. Delmas,
Principal.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.

REGINA, SASK., March 24th, 1925

Dear Mr. Scott:

On the 11th November last I wrote you on the subject of additional accommodation being required at the Duck Lake School for stabling at least thirty head of cows. I also referred to the necessity of providing a store house and on the 21st Iden you wrote that at that time there were no funds available.

I have just received a communication from the Rev. Principal on the subject of additional buildings, a copy of which I enclose, and I shall be glad to know if funds will be available to undertake the work outlined.

A barn to provide accommodation for thirty cows could be built at a cost of $3,000.00. A chicken house, asked for by the Principal, will cost in the neighborhood of $255.00, and the moving of the two Indian houses referred to would cost about $350.00.

Yours very truly,

W. W. Graham
Indian Commissioner,

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have your 305-11A of the 84th ultimo, with reference to outbuildings at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School. In reply I regret to inform you that the appropriation for this fiscal year will provide for no building activity at this institution, but the principal's requests will be noted for future estimates. I hope that the school can get along nicely without new outbuildings for the time being.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Dear Mr. Scott:

Referring to the engine and generator that was recently installed at the Duck Lake Boarding School. It has been brought to my attention that they are too small for the amount of work they are called upon to do. The engine should be at least 5 H.P. more than the one we have, and the generator should be a 7½ K.W. instead of a 5 K.W.

It seems to me that it would be the proper thing to transfer this engine and generator to the Onion Lake School and buy a 15 H.P. Type 'Z' engine and a 7½ K.W. generator for Duck Lake. Fortunately, the engine and generator that we have at Duck Lake is just what we require for Onion Lake, so that nothing has been lost through installing them.

The cost of a 15 H.P. Type 'Z' engine will be $975.00 f.o.b. Winnipeg, and the 7½ K.W. Generator $325.00 f.o.b. Winnipeg. I would be glad to have your authority to place this order with the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse people at the earliest possible date. They will charge approximately $100.00 for taking down the present engine, crating it and installing the new one, and the freight charges will be approximately $100.00.

If you decide to act on my recommendation I would hold the engine at Duck Lake for some time till the school at Onion Lake is ready to receive it.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit to you the following report on the sewerage of the Duck Lake School.

Before we redugout we tried water pressure and found that from one pipe the water comes out and goes in the other line of pipes. There are two lines; one from toilets and one from kitchen and washing machines.

We redugout from the first to the second manhole, about 510 feet and found that there are leaks practically to all joints.

I will advise you to have an Inspector from the Department of Sanitation to come and let us know what should be done in the present case. Last summer an Inspector came from Regina and obliged the men of the contractor to reopen the pipes and make the joints not leaking.

As far as I know we need two other manholes. It is nearly impossible to make a rod of 500 feet long. We have in town a man who is able to build manholes and to do any kind of work according to the advices of an Inspector.

Sincerely yours,

Dear Sir:

We have made an examination of the Sewage System at Duck Lake on the 9th of September, and although we understood you had ordered a plumber to come down, and cleaning rods to be supplied some two weeks before this date, we find that all that has been done is to uncover the drain pipes for about 500 feet, but none lifted, and an attempt to force water through from manhole #1 to manhole #2, and all this time the system is being used by the School.

We examined manhole #1 and found sludge up to level of the 6" outlet and water flowing over into the 6" sewer line. We examined manhole #2 and found it normal, but understand it had been washed out during the present difficulty by the school representative. We examined manhole #3, next to Septic Tank, and found it filled with sludge up about 24" above the sewer outlet to Tank.

We pumped water into this manhole and disturbed the sludge until we had it down to proper level, but the sludge was heavy and hard to flow.

We broke up one length of pipe taken at random and found the joint packed with oakum and apparently in good condition and well cemented. The school representative showed us some joints that were leaking and there is evidently a slight leak in a few joints, but in our opinion no more than any other tile drain would leak, and in any event the school representative has had 60 lbs. pressure of water on this line and it is possible for this pressure to have forced some of the joints.

In our opinion the stoppage was caused by paper and other heavy matter clogging around the iron grid at manhole #3, next to Tank, and the whole system filling up before any person was aware of the condition at manhole #3.

The iron grid should be cut away and the system should have regular attention to see that it is flowing normally.

The extreme length and the very slight fall per foot make it necessary to use a lot of water, and also to examine the manholes regularly.

Another manhole should be installed between #1 and #2, as over 500 feet is too much without a manhole, for cleaning and examining the line.
We wish to emphasize the fact that the joints are as tight as any drain tile would be and this is proven by the fact that the open ditch had several inches of rainwater due to recent heavy rain, and the pipe failed to take off the water from the ditch in spite of the fact that the six inch pipe is flowing only about 1" of depth.

We believe Mr. Poiret is going to attempt to clear the line with rods, but some time has already been lost and the longer the system is left the more trouble it will be to put it right.

We have not seen anything which would indicate negligence on our part or by our sub-contractors, and the system was installed under the constant supervision of the Inspector Mr. Taillon, who made it his business to see that all the joints were properly cemented before the back-fill was done.

Yours very truly,

SMITH BROS. & WILSON, LTD.,

Per (Sgd.) Geo. Johns
Superintendent.
Sir:

In connection with the sewerage system at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School I am enclosing herewith a copy of a letter that I received from the Principal, Rev. Father Delmas. I am also enclosing a copy of a report received from Mr. Johns, Superintendent of the firm of Smith Bros. & Wilson, whom I asked to go up there and look into the matter.

In speaking to Mr. Johns further on the subject he tells me that the work of cleaning out the pipes has been neglected and the sewage has been allowed to accumulate. When he went there he advised them very strongly to get to work and get the drains cleared.

You will notice from his report that he attaches no blame whatever to the construction of the system. I fear that we are going to have serious trouble at this point if the matter is not attended to. I called up the Sanitation Division, Department of Health and asked that an officer be sent to Duck Lake to see what could be done. I also instructed Father Delmas some time ago to get rods made and see if he could clean it up.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
I fear that we are going to have continual trouble with the sewerage system at this school. A very serious mistake was made in locating the school 1400 feet away from the point of sewage disposal. I would never have recommended that it be placed so far away had I been consulted and the Department must take the responsibility for this. It could easily have been placed about 600 feet away. 1400 feet of pipe with a drop of only one inch in twenty-five is bound to make trouble, especially when there is a limited supply of water.

Mr. Johns tells me that when he visited the school the Principal was away, but he did see him for a few minutes before he left.

I have done all that I think can be done in the meantime.

Yours truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Sir:-

At your request I arranged for Mr. T. A. Reid of this Department to visit Duck Lake on the 18th inst. for the purpose of reporting on the operation of the sewer and sewage disposal plant at the Duck Lake Indian School.

Mr. Reid has had considerable experience in the construction of sewers having been a contractor himself and you may therefore place full confidence in his findings.

It would appear that there are two sewers from the new school to the disposal plant, which run side by side for a distance of approximately 1370 feet. One sewer is a six inch sewer which conveys the water from the laundry and the run off from the roof, and discharges direct on the ground surface, the other sewer is 8 inches and carries the sewage, from the toilets, baths, and basins, discharging into the disposal plant.

I am unable to understand why there should be two sewers and Mr. Reid cannot throw any light on this matter.

The 8 inch sewer is in itself quite large enough to take all waste liquids from the school, including wash water from the laundry. If the wash water from the laundry had been excluded from this 6 inch storm sewer, I could understand its purpose for it would then convey only clear and harmless water which would be discharged without treatment, but the waste liquids from the laundry should certainly be run through the disposal plant.

There are three manholes between the school and the disposal plant, and Mr. Reid found that the outlet pipe for number 3 manhole had been blocked by three vertical strips of metal which were acting as a screen and causing the sewage to back up in the pipe.

The sewer pipe appears to have been choked for the following reasons:

(1) The strips of metal above referred to at manhole No. 3.

(2) The bases of the manholes have not been properly finished off. Sewer manholes should be provided with a proper concrete channel at the base and this channel should be so finished that it will be impossible for solids to lodge at the base of the manhole. This has not been done, the manholes being perfectly flat at the bottom with the result that the solids have spread over the floor of the manhole and have caused stoppage in the pipe line. This is obviously bad workmanship on the part of the contractor.
(3) There is not sufficient water coming down the 8 inch pipe to flush and keep clean the pipe line. The waste water from the laundry should be turned into this 8 inch pipe leaving the 6 inch pipe for storm water only.

Mr. Reid suggestions therefore, which I endorse, are as follows:

The base of the manholes to be reconstructed by providing a proper concrete channel or a split pipe channel. This should be done in all three manholes.

It would be well to cover the pipe line and manholes with straw during the winter as some of the manholes and positions of the sewer are only about six feet deep.

Mr. Reid also points out that the disposal plant is in a very bad state of repair. The distributing trays need adjusting. The filter bed required to be cleaned and rebuilt with broken stone. The roof needs repairs and the outlet channels and ditches require to be cleaned out.

This matter was brought to your attention on September 9th, 1924, and on September 11th of that year you advised me that you were arranging for the plant to be overhauled. This has apparently not been done and I would be glad to know that some definite action will be taken.

Yours truly,

R. H. Murray,

Director
Division of Sanitation.
Sir:-

I beg to refer you to my letter of the 14th instant, enclosing a copy of a letter that I received from the Rev. Father Delmas in connection with the sewage disposal system at the Duck Lake Indian Boarding School; also a report from Mr. Johns, Superintendent of the construction firm of Smith Bros. & Wilson, who had the contract for the work of installing the system.

I now enclose a report from Mr. R.H. Murray, Director Division of Sanitation for the Government of this Province, on a visit of their Mr. T.A. Reid to Duck Lake. This report would indicate that there is not much blame to be attached to Messrs. Smith Bros. & Wilson. They claim that they built according to specifications, and that the manholes should have been provided with a concrete channel at the base, but instead of this, I understand it is just a flat slab. They also object to the metal strips which have been placed over the drainage in the three manholes. I believe that the contract called for these metal strips at each manhole. Mr. Johns told me that these should never have been put in, and you will see that Mr. Reid is of the same opinion. You will also note that there is not sufficient water going down to properly flush the 8" drain, and the suggestion is to turn the water in the 6" storm sewer into this drain. You will note that this suggestion comes from an engineer of the Division of Sanitation of the Government.

October 5, 1925.

Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo, together with a copy of a Report by Mr. R. H. Murray, of Regina, with regard to the defective condition of the sewage disposal system at the Duck Lake Indian Boarding School and the location of the site where the main building has been actually erected.

In reply I beg to say that the choosing of the above mentioned site was made after a complete survey of the property had been obtained. The long distance between the points of discharge of the sewage and the building was necessitated in order to obtain the required difference of elevation between these two points so as to ensure proper drainage of the basement and make use of the underground disposal system which was already installed, thus saving the expense of a new complete installation.

With reference to the recommendations made by Mr. Murray as to the alterations required to remedy the present conditions to this sewage system, it is considered that the following repairs should be made:

(a) Lowering of the base at the man-hole 18" below present level.
(b) Cleaning and reconstruction of the filter beds with crushed stone, also cleaning of the outlet channels and ditches where so absolutely required.

I shall further give instructions to the Principal of this school, that the man-holes be inspected once a month and cleaned out if necessary. It is considered that if this precaution had been taken, the actual condition in the sewer pipe would not have resulted.

Your obedient servant,

Wm. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 5th instant #109-1-5 acknowledging receipt of a copy of a report made by Mr. R.H. Murray, Director of Sanitation for this Province. I note what you say regarding the choosing of a site for the school. I still am of the opinion that the site is in a wrong location, and it could have been four or five hundred feet nearer the existing cesspool, and I am not alone in this opinion. People who know the situation well, agree with me in this. This would have saved having the long sewage drain and would have made it much easier to handle the situation. As a matter of fact the sewage drain has got to pass through a low section, and in order to get the drop it brings those pipes about four feet from the surface, which is going to cause trouble all the time. I think that I am quite right in what I have said regarding this matter.

On receipt of your letter I could not understand what you meant by "lowering of the base at the man-hole 18" below present level." This is the last thing we would do, according to the contractors, Messrs. Smith Bros. & Wilson, and according to Mr. Murray and his Sanitary Inspectors. By carrying this out you are merely putting a cesspool at each manhole. What is needed is a channel leading from the intake at the manhole to the outlet on a level with the drain. No excavation whatever should be made; simply a grooved channel.

I am not acting on these instructions until I hear further from you, as it is hard to understand what is meant by your letter.

With reference

Secretary,

A.F. MacKenzie, Esq.,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
With reference to the cleaning and reconstruction of the filter beds, this will be attended to without delay. I quite agree with you that the manholes should be inspected at least once a month.

Kindly reply by wire, as the season is advanced and I can possibly get the Sanitary Department of the Government to assist me in getting this matter cleaned up.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham
Indian Commissioner.

Sir:

I beg to refer you to my letter dated August 21st last, in which I informed you that I was holding back a voucher in favour of Matthew Wylie of Regina, representing the moving of an Engine and Generator at the Duck Lake Residential School, pending an endeavour to arrive at a settlement, as I considered Mr. Wylie's account for labour and material, amounting to $673.85, was altogether too high in view of the services performed.

I am supported in my belief by the Principal of the School and one of our Inspectors who has examined the work and both these men agree with me that too much time was spent in performing this work. However, I have gone thoroughly into the matter and find that Mr. Wylie's receipts for the payment of material and labour are all in order and in view of this, feel that we are helpless and have no other alternative but to pay the account.

I took the matter up with Mr. Wylie with the hope of having the account reduced but have been unsuccessful as Mr. Wylie asserts that the account is not too large in view of the work performed.

I may inform you that the Engine and Dynamo were first installed in an inner room at the school in which there was no ventilation and it was found that the gas evaporated from it caused a great deal of annoyance and was sufficient to suffocate anyone going into the room. It was therefore necessary and very important that the Engine and Generator should be moved to an outer room where there was adequate ventilation. Mr. Wylie was the electrician employed by the Contractors and it was a most natural thing to employ him, as he was familiar with the situation. My arrangement with Mr. Wylie was that he was to do the work on a cost plus 10% basis.

I trust that the foregoing information will enable the Department to clear the matter up. I am enclosing herewith full details of the account, and would recommend that it be paid.

Your obedient servant,

Some necessary repairs to the septic tank at the Indian Residential School at Duck Lake were undertaken last fall and I recently received a report from the Acting Principal, advising me that the roof of the tank had collapsed. It was necessary, therefore, to purchase material to repair it, and the voucher enclosed herewith for $48.65 in favour of the Monarch Lumber Co., which is the only lumber firm operating at that point, represents the cost of the material in question. I beg to recommend the voucher for payment.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham

Sir:-

I beg to inform you that Inspector Murison recently visited the Duck Lake Indian Residential School, and reports that the drainage system is not satisfactory, and that the work that was done last Fall does not clear up the situation there, although we carried out the instructions furnished us by the Engineer of the Provincial Government here.

The drain from the School to the septic tank is about 1350 feet long. The first manhole is 325 feet from the building; the second one is 574 ft. from the first, and the third is 444 ft. from the second, this latter one being right at the septic tank. The general opinion of the Inspector and those at the school is that the pipes are not properly connected and cemented, and that a lot of the fluid escapes, causing clogging. I am told that the drop from the School to the septic tank is only 2½ ft. over this 1350 feet of piping, and if the pipes are not properly cemented the chances are that we will always have trouble. It is thought also that there are not sufficient manholes along the line to permit of cleaning the pipe out with rods. It is suggested that there should be a manhole every 100 ft. Your Engineer will be able to decide as to the number there should be in a drain of this length.

I do not believe anything further can be done this year. I should not be surprised if it were found necessary to dig all the piping up and cement the connections, and perhaps deepen the drain at the far end. The contractors, Messrs. Smith Bros. & Wilson state that the work was properly done and there is no way of finding this out without digging out the whole line. However, nothing can be done during the present winter.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a report on the various schools in the Duck Lake Agency, which were inspected by Mrs. Murison. You will notice that he speaks well of Mr. Goodman, the teacher of the North Day School on James Smith's Reserve, and the good work that is being done by Mrs. Goodman the Field Matron. The residence of the teacher at this point requires exterior painting. It would take very little money to do this work, and if it were available in the Spring I think possibly we could have the work done by Indians. The request of the Field Matron to have a pasture for her ponies and the cow is one that I think we should grant. It would cost about $50.00 to have a suitable pasture provided, and if funds are available for this purpose I will have the matter attended to first thing in the Spring.

The attendance at the South Day School does not seem to be all that it should. Out of an enrollment of 28 there were 16 present. I am not very much impressed with the practice of supplying children with second hand clothing; they never look well and a boy of fourteen going around with an adult's coat on, and girls wearing discarded dresses of all colours and styles does not give a very good impression to a person visiting the school.

The John Smith's Day School seems to be doing satisfactory work, although the attendance does not seem to be as good as it might be. I am not taking any notice of the difficulty they are having with the hot air furnace. It seems to me that the Agent or the teacher could look after this.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt., General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
With regard to the Inspector's remarks dealing with the sewage disposal system at the St. Michael's Boarding School, I have your authority to have this system thoroughly overhauled in the Spring, and this will be done as soon as the weather permits. The necessity for outbuildings at this school is pointed out. An item of $5200.00 has been placed in the Estimates to provide a cow barn and root house, but I doubt very much whether this will be sufficient to supply a henhouse, piggery and killing house. The necessity for these buildings was not brought to my attention at the time the Estimates were being prepared. We may, however, save some of the $5200.00 and apply it on these extra buildings which are apparently necessary.

You will note that the Principal has 105 head of cattle. Surely we are not going to be expected to put up a barn to accommodate this number. At our largest schools we provide for about thirty head of live stock. We must have an understanding regarding this before any expense is incurred. They should have shelters for the young stock and we should only provide for the milking cows. I think you will agree with me in this.

The school is suffering considerably through lack of vegetables this year. You will note in the report that the crop was an entire failure and that it has been necessary to bring in potatoes. All our reserves in the northern part of the province, including the northern part of Alberta, suffered severely from the August frost.

On the whole the reports on the Duck Lake Agency and Schools appear to be very satisfactory, and if we get through the present winter with our stock I feel that there will be a substantial increase in the cattle and also in farming operations next year.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
ST. MICHAEL'S R.C. RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

I visited this school on November 24th.

Inspector Murison's Report on Schools, Duck Lake Agency.

ST. MICHAEL'S R.C. RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (Cont'd)

I examined the sewage disposal plant and the outbuildings. I also went through the school building and noted conditions. I did not examine the children in the class room.

The Principal, who is the Rev. Father Delmas, was absent but was expected back by Christmas. His place has been taken during his absence by the Rev. Father Chevallier. There are 140 pupils on the roll, 76 boys and 64 girls. The health of the children was particularly good at the time of my visit. I was present at the evening meal and noted that an abundance of wholesome food was provided. This includes all the milk the children care to have. There were 20 cows being milked at the time of my visit which provides sufficient milk and butter for their requirements.

SCHOOL BUILDINGS.

It is unnecessary for me to describe the main building; it is quite new and in excellent condition. The Principal, however, complains that the windows fit badly and the North and East rooms are hard to keep warm on this account. He complains particularly of the difficulty in heating the sewing room. I have already reported to you verbally regarding the condition of the septic tank and you have brought this matter to the attention of the Department.

The out-buildings, with the exception of the horse stable, are very old and inconvenient. An up-to-date cow barn, root house, hen house, piggery and killing house is required. They have very poor accommodation for butchering animals, in fact they have none. They were killing hogs on the day of my visit, a cold day; the hogs were killed outside and taken into the blacksmith shop to be scalded and dressed and I could see the necessity for a proper
Inspector Murison's Report on Schools, Duck Lake Agency.

ST. MICHAEL'S R.C. RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (Cont'd)

proper building to do this work in. The old laundry building is being used temporarily as a Farmer's residence. This building is very old and the arrangement can only be considered as a temporary one.

There is a good farm in operation at this school. They have 700 acres of land in the immediate vicinity of the school and 400 acres of hay land a few miles away. They threshed in 1926, 3500 bushels of wheat from 210 acres, 3400 bushels of oats from 70 acres and 800 bushels of barley from 20 acres. The yield off their wheat crop was affected by the frost; a year ago they had over 7,000 bushels. Their live stock comprises 105 cattle, 26 horses and 41 hogs. They have a large garden at the school but this year they have no vegetables as their garden stuff was destroyed by frost in August. Their potato supply is being shipped in from outside points.

Dear Mr. Scott:

The matter of outbuildings that it is proposed to build at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School is one that I think should be attended to without delay. The difficulty we have experienced in the past has been in getting our authority rather late in the season, at a time when most of the carpenters and tradesmen have arranged for their summer's work, and you will appreciate the difficulty in getting men under such circumstances. Then again, the season is so short here that if we do not get the work started in May we are usually working late into the Fall, and never get a satisfactorily completed job - usually carrying over some of the work until the following year. I should be glad, therefore, if steps could be taken to have our building programme arranged as soon as possible.

A cattle barn, to hold 28 to 30 head is badly needed at this school. A poultry house is also required, as one was not built at the time the school was erected. There is urgent need for outside quarters for the help. In a conversation with the Principal, Father Delmas, he tells me that he would like to have two small cottages to accommodate two married men and their families. You will appreciate that at a school of this kind where farming is done on such an extensive scale it is necessary to have a staff of men. It is estimated that the two cottages could be built for approximately $4500.00, as the Father would undertake to do a certain amount of the freighting and excavating, as well as any other work which could be done by the staff and bigger boys

at the

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,

at the school. The other buildings which are required are a niggery and a root cellar. A root cellar at an institution of this kind is rather an important thing to have, as a great many roots are grown and used. As you know, it is necessary to have a separate root house, as roots cannot be stored in the main building, and besides, there is not room for them.

There is another matter which I was told to bring to your attention in the Spring, i.e., that of the drain leading from the main building to the septic tank. Something will have to be done to put this in shape, as it has never worked properly since the time it was first put in.

Form No. 1
Sir:

I had some correspondence with you in regard to the sewage disposal plant at the Duck Lake Residential School, and under cover of Department letter No.109-1-5 dated the 6th May last I was advised that an appropriation of $400.00 had been set aside to effect needed improvements.

Inspector W. Hurison recently went to Duck Lake to make an inspection there and I requested him to look carefully into this matter. In the meanwhile I received a letter from the Director, Division of Sanitation, of the Saskatchewan Department of Public Health, pointing out that an official of the Department had visited the School and recommended certain work being done to put this plant in proper working order. He also pointed out that its unsatisfactory condition since installation was to be attributed to the fact that a qualified drainage engineer had not been employed on the work when it was originally done. Inspector Hurison went over the ground again with the official of the Department of Public Health and has found that the drain pipes, which he uncovered in five places, had not been properly laid and that the pipes in three instances were leaking, owing to defective joints. He found also that no fluid was passing into the filter in the septic tank and the distributing pans were dry. This was owing to the drain pipe.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
drain pipe being frozen between the disposal plant and one of the manholes, which no doubt was due to the fact that part of the pipe line was no more than two feet below the surface of the ground. The roof of the disposal plant is not of sufficient strength to carry the covering which has to be placed on it in the winter months.

The recommendation of the Department's Engineer involves the taking up of the old pipe and relaying under the supervision of a competent engineer who will see that levels are taken. It is not considered that more than 25% or 30% of the old pipe can be salvaged as vitrified tile is of such a brittle nature. Four manholes should also be constructed and the present roof replaced by one of reinforced concrete. The cost of the manholes, the vitrified tile, labour and cement and taking up and laying pipes, the building of the reinforced concrete roof, the services of a qualified engineer, and finally the purchase of proper sewer cleaning tools will involve an expenditure of approximately $1600. Some other work such as covering a portion of the pipe line with a sufficient quantity of earth to protect it from freezing in the winter will be done by the School children. The Principal will also take care of the cartage and the cost of excavating and back filling, provided the work is done before the 15th July when his big boys will go home for their holidays.

I shall be glad, therefore, if the Department will sanction the additional expenditure necessary to place this plant in proper operating condition.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Duck Lake Sask. June 13th. 1927

To The Secretary of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Dear Sir,

I beg to call the attention of the Department, to the fact that since we have moved into our new School, we are in need of all the outside buildings to carry on the work properly.

Last year an amount of money was voted for some of these buildings, but nothing was done. This spring under the supervision of J. Mayoh, the cow barn, the poultry house and the pigery are nearly finished. We cannot wait another year for the root cellar. But we are very badly in need of two houses for our two families with their families.

When we moved to the new building 1925, our Farmer Instructor took up a few rooms for himself, his wife and his six children in the old School. When Brother John died we were obliged to hire another man to look after the mechanic work who in turn took a few rooms also in the old building. Both stayed there until the 3rd of May 1926, when the building burned down.

Then a part of the old wash house was roughly appropriated for the farmer and his family, but it is very far from being a decent dwelling for them all.

As for our Mechanic man, being obliged to rent a house in town, one mile away from his work, he is moving from one place to another every three months, being unable with his salary to rent a decent house.

Our Indian Agent, Ch. Pant. Schmidt, Inspector W. Murison and the Indian Commissioner W.M. Graham see by themselves the necessity of having these two houses erected this season. I will object to see the erection of small cottages with only four rooms on the basement. Our farmer has six children and consequently needs a house with cellar, kitchen, dining room and living room on the basement and four bedrooms upstairs. The Mechanic man has only a child but he is a new married man and young.

According to Mr. J. Mayoh, the cost of these two houses would be $2600.00 each.

Another thing also of no less importance is the question of our sewerage which never gave satisfaction and on which the Department of Health of Saskatchewan made a full report with suggestions to Mr. W. Murison.

All that correspondence is held at the Indian Office of Regina.

We would appreciate very much in seeing the Department taking necessary steps to have the two houses erected this season and the sewerage rebuilt.

Sincerely yours,

Rev. M. De Lisle
Principal.

Principal.
Right Honorable Sir,

I am taking the liberty of sending you a copy of my letter dated June 13th, addressed to the Indian Department, re-erection of two dwelling houses for our two employees and re-reconstruction of our sewerage.

By my letter's content you will see that having new barn, new poultry house and a new piggery built up, it looks like the Department shows more interest for the stock than for our hired men.

You can easily understand also how great would be the responsibility of the Department in refusing or neglecting the reconstruction of our sewerage. Supposing an obstruction happens in it during the cold season, the only issue would be the closing up of the School and the sending of our 150 pupils to their homes in the winter time. What also would be the damage done to our new building?

I am asking you Right Honorable Sir, to use your influence in bringing the Department of Indian Affairs to have the two houses erected and the sewerage reconstructed during this summer season.

Yours very obedient

Dear Sir:-

Re Duck Lake School.

In answer to your letter of July 8th., we beg to state that our letter of Sept. 11th, 1925 covered most of the ground on this matter.

As far as the laying of the pipes is concerned this was done by the same man who laid the sewers at Lebret Punnichy, Cardston, and a good many of the sewers in Regina and was laid under the constant supervision of Mr. Taillon the inspector who established all the levels.

With reference to leaky joints, we do not think it usual to expect tile drains to be laid subject to temperature changes, and with cement joints and still expect them to be absolutely water tight under pressure. In any case this sewer was subjected to approximately 60 lbs. water pressure by the school representative Mr. Foirlet, at the time he was attempting to clear the line, and he could very well have started some of the joints at that time.

We are of the opinion that this 1370 feet of sewer will always be troublesome at the grade it had to be laid. The plans are somewhat misleading to the ordinary man as the fall appears to be good but the plans are drawn to vertical scale of 4 ft. to the inch so that the actual grade is one tenth of the grade on the drawings and actual conditions were that even less grade could be got than that shown on the plan. All this was pointed out to the Inspector and he placed the levels and lived on the job all the time.

This installation is not and never will be entirely satisfactory under its present conditions. It requires a lot of water and constant supervision but we do not consider any responsibility rests on us on this account.

As stated above the system was laid under Mr. Taillon's supervision and to his instruction. He accepted the system after seeing every foot of pipe laid and we must repudiate any responsibility for the present conditions.

Yours very truly,

SMITH BROS. & WILSON, LTD.
Per (Sgd.) George Johns
Superintendent.
With reference to your letter of the 24th ultimo No. 109-1-5 regarding the sewage disposal system at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School, I have taken the matter up with Messrs. Smith Bros. and Wilson, of Regina, and they take no responsibility whatever in connection with the condition of the system. I am enclosing copy of a letter from this firm, from which you will note that the installation is not and never will be satisfactory under present conditions, and that it requires a lot of water and constant supervision. They point out that the system was installed under the supervision of the Department's Inspector, Mr. Taillon, who established all the levels and accepted the installation after seeing all the pipes laid. I am not sure that 60 lbs. of pressure was ever used on these pipes; I have never heard that it was. I quite agree with Messrs. Smith Bros. and Wilson when they say that this 1370 feet of sewer will always be troublesome at the grade it had to be laid. I believe there is only a fall of 2½ feet to the entire length of 1370 feet.

I would recommend that the work as suggested in the penultimate paragraph of my letter of June 9th, be carried out by the Department at the earliest possible date, so that we will be sure to have it completed before there is any possibility of frost. The figure which I have had quoted for the work is $1600.00.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
July 26, 1927.

Memorandum:

I wish to draw to your attention Mr. Commissioner Graham's letter of June 9th, with reference to the unsatisfactory sewage disposal line at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School. The Department's reply of the 24th ultimo asked Mr. Graham to inform Smith Brothers and Wilson, of Regina, that they should effect the necessary improvements without cost to the Department. Their reply, which is now to hand under cover of Mr. Graham's letter of the 14th instant, repudiates any responsibility for the present conditions.

Sixteen hundred dollars is required to put the sewage disposal system in proper working order. Four hundred dollars is specifically provided for this purpose. The work should be done, of course, and the General Appropriation would have to stand the difference. Do you wish further steps taken with Smith Brothers and Wilson?

Edward Hanna
Supt. of Indian Education.

ST. MICHAEL'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

This is a large school, with 150 boys and girls in attendance. The class room work is carried on in four class rooms. Mr. E. Seissens is in charge of the older boys, and I consider him a splendid teacher. He holds a Second Interim Saskatchewan Certificate. His manner is good and he certainly has the class room well under control.

The other three class rooms are taught by Sr. St. Melaine, Sr. St. Boniface and Sr. St. Ulric. I must say the children all read well, as though they understood, and in the other subjects examined, they answered quite freely. Their books were all well kept and the work neatly done. The pupils were neatly dressed, clean, and apparently healthy. The class rooms were spotless well lighted and well aired.

The sewing room was in charge of another Sister and the work exhibited is certainly a credit to the school. I have seen no better work in any school inspected.

The laundry was not in operation, but everything was in splendid order.

The kitchen department, as usual, was busy, but everything was in such splendid order that one could hardly credit that the work required to feed 175 people was being carried on.

The building, as the Department knows, is new so I need not discuss it further than to say it is the finest building of its kind I have seen. As far as being clean, it was practically spotless, and every room seen showed that care and labour is not spared.

The school
ST. MICHAEL'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (Cont'd.)

The school, I understand, is built fireproof. Just before I visited it, a shipment of fire extinguishers had arrived which the Rev. Father will have placed at various points within the building. The fire escapes are well built and in good condition, as is the hose, which is practically new. The only weak point, as considered by the Rev. Father, and I believe he is right, is the pressure tank. This tank will only hold between 700 and 800 gals., which, in the case of a big fire, would certainly not be sufficient. The Rev. Father suggested that a tower tank be erected outside so that the barns and other outbuildings might also be protected. The supply of water appears plentiful, so that it is simply a matter of storage from which it can best be obtained when needed.

There are two large barns, one for cattle and one for horses. The one is new, while the other, although older, is in splendid repair. It is, however, badly in need of paint. A new building was erected this year, part to be used as a slaughter house and part as an ice house. The Rev. Father was allowed $900.00, and I consider the Department has certainly received value. The building is well built, with a well equipped slaughter house and, adjoining it, an ice house. This building, which is under one roof, is not painted and should receive paint this coming year. There is also a well built pig pen and chicken house, both of which are painted. The same remark applies to the outbuildings as I made in regards to the school. They are the best I have inspected. The other outbuildings are old and of little use. The old laundry is used as a residence for the Farming Instructor, but certainly is not satisfactory. A residence is badly needed. Two other old houses are nearby, which are used to accommodate
ST. MICHAEL'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (Cont'd.)

to accommodate Indian parents who visit the school. The mechanic is a married man and resides in Duck Lake.

Rev. Father Delmas considers this man should be within call at any time and desires a residence for him.

The Rev. Father complained about the lack of a storehouse for vegetables. It is useless to grow large quantities and have no place in which to keep them, and yet I think we must admit that they are essential and some suitable place should be provided.

A large herd of cattle is kept, from which milk and meat are provided for the school.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sirs,

In reply to your telephone message regarding water tank at the Penitentiary, the particulars are as follows:

- Capacity: 80,000 Gals.
- Tank is 22 feet in diameter.
- Height from bottom to eave: 30 feet.
- Eave is 110 Feet from the ground.

You will note from the above dimensions that even if it was possible to take it down whole, it could not be transported and we think that it would be an enormous task to cut all the rivets which will run into thousands, 100 feet up in the air. We believe also that it would be quite a job to make the tank tight again. The sections would bound to be distorted with all that pounding and a torch would not be any good if the tank was to be used again.

The governor of the Penitentiary wants the tank out of the way and does not know how to get it away, so he thought that if he offered it to some other department, they would move it for him. We should think that the best way to get it down would be to pull it over onto a large pile of straw, or something like that & then start to take it apart. Anyway, it is a job for a bridge gang. It was erected by the Chicago Bridge Co, and in the course of its erection, six men were very severely hurt.

We enclose a sketch of tank and tower.

Yours very truly,

Lachine, May 20th. 1928.

The Honorable Duncan Scott,
Deputy Minister of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Scott,

On my arrival here from Ottawa, I received a letter from the Principal of St. Michael Residential School at Duck lake, Father Delmas, asking me to see you about the following items.

Father Guy in a previous letter to Father Delmas had written to him that your Department was to give him $5000 dollars for the buildings of two residences, one for his engineer and the other for his farmer, and $900 dollars for implements shed.

Father Delmas asks you as a favor:

1.- To be notified by yourself of the amount voted for his school.
2.- For what purpose the money has been voted, what amount for the construction of his buildings and what amount for the reparations.
3.- The authorization to himself or the Agent whenever it is possible, to control and superintend the construction of these buildings and reparations, in order to make it impossible for Regina to cut down the estimated voted by the Department or to change the purpose for which these estimates had been voted. This power thus conferred either on the Agent or the Principal would make possible the employment of local labor men and the money spent in the localities in which the constructions or reparations are made.

If his demand is granted, Father Delmas would like to be notified as soon as possible, so that the works might be done immediately after the seeding, as it is the proper time to get workingmen at low wages, whereas later in July, August and September the wages are higher owing to the great demand from the farmers paying big wages.

I heartily recommend to your favor these wishes of father Delmas who is doing such a splendid work for the honor of the Department and the benefit of the Indians.

Your's faithfully,

(Signed) J.A. Sherien

May 22, 1928.

Dear Father Therien:

I have your letter of the 20th instant, with reference to improvements that are to be undertaken this year at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School. I regret that I cannot authorize either Father Delmas or the Indian Agent to proceed with the work, as it is our practice to have Mr. Commissioner Graham responsible for building activity that is to be undertaken on a day labour basis.

In a few days, Mr. Graham will be authorized to erect a double residence for the engineer and the farmer and an implement shed. I am pleased to inform you that $6,100 will be available for these purposes.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to submit the following report on the schools of the Duck Lake Agency which were visited between February 19th and March 16th, during which time I inspected the Agency.

ST. MICHAEL'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

I inspected this school on February 19th, and found everything in its usual good condition and spotlessly clean.

The school work is carried on in four classrooms, and I believe progress is being made. The children were not afraid to speak out and apparently understood their work. The books were all well kept and their work neatly set down. The pupils were neatly dressed and clean. The classrooms were well aired and all the rooms presented a cheerful appearance.

The sewing room is large and well lighted. It is well equipped with tables, sewing machines and cupboards for the storing of new garments and material. The work in this department is almost beyond criticism, and the girls certainly receive a splendid training which should be of great service to them.

The laundry is well equipped with a power washer, drier and roller for pressing or ironing clothes. The work in this department is heavy, but with such splendid equipment neither the Sisters in charge or the girls appear to find the work hard.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

ST. MICHAEL'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

The kitchen is well equipped, and I found it very clean and tidy. The work in this Department was carried on without any fuss or excitement and one could hardly credit that meals were being provided for 160 to 175 people.

The dormitories were well aired and the beds neatly made and covered with white spreads.

The building is well equipped with fire extinguishers which are placed in convenient places. The water pressure is low and on the top floor the pressure is practically nil. There is only one tank in the school, the capacity of which is about 600 gals. of water. This is certainly not a large supply in case of fire. The approach to the fire escapes is through windows from each flat. The windows are the ordinary windows with outside sash which are hooked on. This is a very awkward arrangement. These windows should be made in one sash and put on hinges so that they could be opened as a door. The exit windows are above the radiators, which have recently been changed, so that now they are even with the window sills, and if the window sash were placed on hinges, the exit to the fire escape would be greatly improved. The cost for this change would not be great. The day I inspected the school the children were just recovering from the Flu, and as the weather was extremely cold, no fire drill was carried out.

The barns were all tidy, and well cleaned. 20 head of milk cows were stabled, and of this number about 10 were fresh, so that the school had abundance of milk.

REPORT ON WATER SUPPLY AT INDIAN SCHOOL AT DUCK LAKE.

There are about 150 pupils resident in the school, both boys and girls and 20 of a staff, making a total of 170.

In the basement there are 2 pressure tanks, one for soft water from the roof and one for the well water. Each tank is about 4 feet in diameter and 14 feet long giving an approximate capacity of 1,000 gallons for each tank or say 700 gallons of water. Light and power are generated in the institution by a 15 horse power gasoline engine which charges batteries. There is one, 5 horse power motor operating the washing machine in the laundry and one, quarter horse power motor operating the soft water pump.

Soft water is collected in a concrete tank immediately behind the building, the tank being about 20 feet in diameter and 9 feet deep. There are two wells, one of which is connected up to the main building and the other supplies two houses and the two barns.

The well first referred to is about 100 feet deep and has an 8" casing. The pump is operated by a two horse power motor, the pump house being connected up by overhead wires to the power plant in the main building. There is also in this pumphouse a six horse power gasoline engine which is not used at the present time but can be connected with the pump should the power break down.

The pump is made by Goulds Manufacturing Company and on a test made on April 22nd 1929 it was found that water was being pumped at the rate of 8 gallons per minute.

The cost of operating the power plant is represented by the consumption of about four barrels of gas per month. Gas costs the institution 27 cents per gallon and at 45 gallons to the barrel, this would mean a monthly maintenance cost of about $48, one quarter of which it is estimated is chargeable to pumping.

The water is pumped to the institution through a 2" pipe for a distance of 955 feet as shown on the plan. The other well has also a depth of 100 feet with a 6" casing. It is fitted with a pump operated by a 1½ horse power engine, the capacity of the pump is stated to be 3 gallons per minute. Pipe lines supply two houses and the two barns as shown on the plan. The number of stock watered at the barns is about 40 in winter and 20 in summer.

There is in addition one six horse power gasoline engine which is at the present used for sawing wood.

The proposal is to provide an elevated tank of say 25,000 gallons capacity and connect up both wells to this tank in order to provide suitable pressure and storage for fire fighting purposes both at the main building and at the two barns. The school is equipped with hose pipes on each floor but in the event of fire there is only a matter of 700 gallons of water available at the present time.
With an elevated tank to provide storage and fire pressure for the building, it is necessary that better pumping equipment be provided so that in the event of the tank being emptied for fire or other purposes it may be filled again within a reasonable period and also may be kept filled in the event of fire. It is therefore suggested that two new pumps be provided as follows:

At well No. 1 a pump with necessary piping, fittings and valves having a capacity of 1200 to 1500 gallons per hour and operated by a ten horse power gas engine; cost $1,265.

At well No. 2, 16 foot wind-mill with 40 feet tower, pump with necessary piping, fittings and valves having a capacity of 650 gallons per hour; cost $895.

One, 25,000 gallon wood storage tank on 60 foot steel tower with equipment for preventing water from freezing; cost erected $3,935.

Seven hundred feet of supply and connecting pipe including labor; cost $1,055.

$7,150.

With the equipment above suggested the wind-mill would probably keep the building supplied with water at no maintenance cost. The pump at well No. 1 with the ten horse power motor would be required for filling the tank and maintaining the water level in the event of fire and could be regarded as emergency equipment.

The water in well No. 2 is of practically the same quality as in well No. 1 and the use of a wind-mill to operate the pump at this well is considered more economical. This well would also be connected up with the overhead tank, and pipe lines would be taken to the two barns and if necessary the two residences adjoining, which would permit of all buildings having the required pressure at all times.

The wooden storage tank is suggested in preference to a steel tank inasmuch as the former can be obtained for about $2,000 less.

Regarding the additional maintenance cost of operating the new equipment, the consumption of gasoline for the proposed engine at well No. 1 would be about one gallon per horse power per day of 24 hours, so that if the engine were running six hours, two and one-half gallons would be consumed. Normally, however, the wind-mill will keep the elevated tank filled and well No. 1 will not be in use, which will result in a saving of about $12.00 per month instead of an additional maintenance cost.

The protection against fire at the Indian School at Duck Lake is at the present time nil, and it is most desirable that the lives of the pupils and the property of the Department be protected by some scheme similar to that above proposed.
Sir:-

The question of supplying an elevated tank at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School for the storing of water for use in connection with fire protection, laundry work and general consumption, is one that has been brought to the attention of the Department before, and at one time it was thought we might be able to move to the school site a water tank that belonged to the Penitentiary at Prince Albert. I sent an Inspector up there to look at this tank but it was found that to remove it to the school would be impracticable. I have had a competent man go over the situation at the school and I am enclosing herewith his report, which contains an estimate of the cost of a proposed system. The Department might consider putting in a wooden tank instead of a galvanized iron tank. I should be glad to see this work undertaken, as I think it is absolutely necessary; we should have an adequate water supply at this institution.

Your obedient servant,

The tin roof of the granary referred to is now useless, being perforated by rust and loosened from the rafters by wind and rain.

Dear Father Delmas:

I am sending you today two containers in order that you may obtain samples of water from your two wells when I shall be glad to furnish you with an opinion as to their comparative suitability for use.

You will find inside the containers a yellow form which you might fill out for each well so far as your information goes. You might designate the well: number 1 and number 2, number 1 being the well which is at present connected up with the school and number 2 the well which supplies the house and the two barns.

I have been discussing the question of pumps and wind mills with the maker's representatives in Regina and they have confirmed the opinion that I expressed, that it should be unwise to recommend any larger size of pump until the two wells had been tested out. Would you therefore arrange for the following test to be made on each well:

(1) The distance from the ground surface to the water level in the well to be noted.
(2) The pump to be started up and kept operating continuously for a period of say four hours.
(3) At the end of this period the distance from the ground surface to the water level in the well to be again measured. By making the above observations it will be possible to estimate what size of a pump can safely be installed without danger of closing up the well by admitting too much sand.
(4) The capacity of each of the two pumps is also required. This may be arrived at by disconnecting the pipe line and pumping direct into some large vessel and recording the number of seconds or minutes required to fill a tank of known capacity.

If you will be good enough to arrange for this information to be forwarded to me in the course of a few days it will be of considerable assistance in enabling me to give you reliable advice.

Regarding the best location for the proposed water tower, I would recommend the location which we discussed on the ground, namely just south of the two houses used by the Indians and south of the existing two inch water line from number one well to the building.

I think you will see the spot marked in pencil on the blue print.

With reference to the guarantee that the water will not freeze, the firm who supply the water tower will provide for this. There is special heating apparatus arranged for under the water tower at a cost of about $300.00 which is included in the price which I gave you and the firm who install the tower should be asked to give a guarantee on this matter.

I am quite satisfied that the water from number two well can be made perfectly safe for drinking purposes. It is true that the examination showed the presence of B. Goli, but this is simply due to some surface contamination entering at the top of the well and this can easily be prevented in making all connections perfectly watertight when the wind-mill is erected.

With kind regards,

Yours very truly.
REPORT ON WATER SUPPLY AT INDIAN SCHOOL AT DUCK LAKE.

There are about 150 pupils resident in the school, both boys and girls and 20 of a Staff, making a total of 170.

In the basement there are two pressure tanks, one for soft water from the roof and one for the well water. Each tank is about 4 feet in diameter and 14 feet long giving an approximate capacity of 1000 gallons for each tank or say 700 gallons of water. Light and power are generated in the institution by a 15 horse power gasoline engine which charges batteries. There is one, 5 horse power motor operating the washing machines in the laundry and one, quarter horse power motor operating the soft water pump.

Soft water is collected in a concrete tank immediately behind the building, the tank being about 20 feet in diameter and 9 feet deep. There are two wells, one of which is connected up to the main building and the other supplies two houses and the two barns.

The well first referred to is 100 feet deep and has an 8" casing. The pump is operated by a two horse power motor, the pump house being connected up by overhead wires to the power plant in the main building. There is also in this pumphouse a six horse power gasoline engine which is not used at the present time but can be connected with the pump should the power down.

The pump is made by Goulds Manufacturing Company and on a test made on April 22nd, 1929 it was found that water was being pumped at the rate of 8 gallons per minute.

The cost of operating the power plant is represented by the consumption of about four barrels of gas per month. Gas costs the institution 27 cents per gallon and at 40 gallons to the barrel, this would mean a monthly maintenance cost of about $48, one quarter of which it is estimated is chargeable to pumping.

The water is pumped to the institution through a 2" pipe for a distance of 956 feet as shown on the plan. The other well has also a depth of 100 feet with a 6" casing. It is fitted with a pump operated by a 11/2 horse power engine, the capacity of the pump is stated to be 3 gallons per minute. Pipe lines supply two houses and the two barns as shown on the plan. The number of stock watered at the barns is about 40 in winter and 30 in summer.

There is in addition one six horse power gasoline engine which is at the present used for sawing wood.

The proposal is to provide an elevated tank of say 25,000 gallons capacity and connect up both wells to this tank in order to provide suitable pressure and storage for fire fighting purposes both at the main building and at the two barns. The school is equipped with hose pipes on each floor but in the event of fire there is only a matter of 700 gallons of water available at the present time.
With an elevated tank to provide storage and fire pressure in the building, it is necessary that better pumping equipment be provided so that in the event of the tank being emptied for fire or other purposes it may be filled again within a reasonable period and also may be kept filled in the event of fire. It is therefore suggested that two new pumps be provided as follows:

At well No. 1 a pump with necessary piping, fittings and valves having a capacity of 1200 to 1500 gallons per hour and operated by a ten horse power gas engine; cost $1265

At well No. 2, 16-foot wind-mill with 40 feet tower, pump with necessary piping, fittings and valves having a capacity of 650 gallons per hour; cost $895

One, 25,000 gallon wood storage tank on 60 foot steel tower with equipment for preventing water from freezing; cost $3035

Seven hundred feet of supply and connecting pipe including labor; cost $7180

With the equipment above suggested the wind-mill would probably keep the building supplied with water at no maintenance cost. The pump at well No. 1 with the ten horse power motor would be required for filling the tank and maintaining the water level in the event of fire and could be regarded as emergency equipment.

The water in well No. 2 is practically the same quality as in well No. 1 and the use of a wind-mill to operate the pump at this well is considered more economical. This well would also be connected up with the overhead tank, and pipe lines would be taken to the two barns and if necessary the two residences adjoining, which would permit all buildings having the required pressure at all times.

The wooden storage tank is suggested in preference to a steel tank inasmuch as the former can be obtained for about $2,000 less.

Regarding the additional maintenance cost of operating the new equipment, the consumption of gasoline for the proposed engine at well No. 1 would be about one gallon per horse power per day of 24 hours, so that if the engine were running six hours, two and one-half gallons would be consumed. Normally, however, the wind-mill will keep the elevated tank filled and well No. 1 will not be in use, which will result in a saving of about $12.00 per month instead of an additional maintenance cost.

The protection against fire at the Indian School at Duck Lake is at the present time nil, and it is more desirable that the lives of the pupils and the property of the Department be protected by some scheme similar to that above proposed.
Regina, May 31st, 1929.

Sir:

With reference to the matter of a water supply at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School, I beg to say that after going into the question further I have decided to recommend that the Department abandon the idea of having an elevated tank outside.

I have discussed the matter with several people who depend upon water other than from a city supply and the majority are in favour of the pressure tank system in a country like this where there is so much frost, and the expense of keeping a tank warm is great. The fact that these tanks are being abandoned at certain places should be sufficient reason for the Department not to go on with the installation of one at Duck Lake. I admit that this was at first recommended by me after having had the advice of certain people, but I am satisfied now that it would be a mistake.

I would ask for your authority to put in a pressure tank system, and I might say that I had Mr. Millar of the Fairbanks-Morse Company go up to Duck Lake, and he recommends that a hole be dug in the ground close to the boiler room, covered with concrete, to receive two tanks 45" in diam. by 24 ft. long, with approximate capacity each of 2260 gals. He also recommends that on Well No. 1 a deep well turbine pump be placed with an approximate capacity of 170 gals. per minute, directly connected to

Dear Sir,

It is with a great uneasiness that I have to bring to your knowledge that we had a very bad luck without windmill. As soon as we noticed that we were going to have a great storm, on Saturday night, we stopped the windmill to keep it on the safe way.

Unfortunately we found it yesterday morning so badly broken that it is beyond repairs.

It worked with very good satisfaction for nearly a month; supplying three quarters of the water required without any cost. We never noticed anything wrong in its structure. But Mr. Miller of the Fairbanks-Morse Co. never inspected it. As the contract is not completed it up to him to supply a new one.

We might be in a very bad position, regarding our water supply supposing that now the old pump of well No. 1 gives away, before the electric power, provided by the Saskatchewan Power Commission reaches us.

Sincerely yours,

Sgd. Rev. H. Delmas.

DUCK LAKE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (R.C.)

The classroom work is arranged as follows.

The senior girls are in charge of Sister St. Melanie.

The grades are arranged from 3 to 5 with 35 pupils enrolled.
Duck Lake R.C. Indian Residential School (Cont'd.)

enrolled. This Sister does excellent work, and the children are well along in their grades. The junior teacher for the girls is Sister St. Ulric. There are 28 children in grade 1, and 11 in grade 2. The children were bright, and I believe are making fair progress. I understand this Sister only took over the work about a year ago, and I have no doubt experience will increase confidence in herself. I understand this Sister does not hold a Saskatchewan certificate, but has a two year Quebec training. The boys' junior teacher is Sister Therese of St. Joseph, and there are 33 pupils on the roll, 24 in Grade 1, and 9 in Grade 2. These children are very alert, and I would judge good progress is made. The senior boys have Mr. Burzie, who, I understand, holds his Second Interim Certificate for Saskatchewan, and is doing excellent work. There are 32 enrolled, and the grades range from 3 to 6. The children were all well dressed, neat in appearance, and clean. The rooms were well aired, and are bright and cheerful. I found the registers neatly kept, and the attendance is excellent.

The laundry, kitchen, and sewing room are in charge of the Sisters, and excellent work is carried on. There is no confusion in any department, and the work does not appear difficult or hard. The laundry is well equipped, except for a small stove, which is needed in order that the clothes may be boiled. At present the irons are heated on the kitchen range, which is inconvenient, especially when a meal is being prepared. The kitchen is down the main hall from the laundry, and children are often passing back and forth and might easily be burned when carrying the irons, as the hall is not well lighted.
lighted. A small stove with a flat top, fitted with a copper boiler, could be used for the boiling of the clothes, and also for the heating of irons. At present no clothes are boiled, and it is impossible to keep the white clothes in good condition unless they are. The Sisters made the request for a family size electric washer, which could be used for the staff washing, and would often save, especially in holiday season, the operating of the large power washer, and it would also be a saving on water and soap.

The girls do all plain sewing, which includes the making of their own dresses, nightgowns, and overalls and shirts for the boys. In addition, they do the mending and darning, all of which is well done, and the training will be of great benefit in later life.

The dormitories are large, well aired, bright, and spotlessly clean. The beds were neatly made, and the bedding was clean.

The new pressure tanks are now in use, and good pressure is obtained throughout the building. The new pump apparently is giving good service, and the Rev. Father Delmas assured me he was well satisfied with the system.

The fire hose are in good repair, and extinguishers are placed in prominent places throughout the building. The Reverend Principal assured me that fire drill is observed regularly, and the children are familiar with what is expected of them.

The milk cows were in good condition, and are well cared for. The milk cows number about 26 head, and several have
several have already freshened, so that the school is receiving a fair supply of milk. In addition to the milk cows, a herd of about 70 head is fed outside. This herd supplies the beef, and includes many young heifers which later will form part of the milking herd.

A number of brood sows are kept, and I understand that all pork needed for the institution is produced there.

I found the horses in excellent condition, and the stables were clean and in good repair.

The children were well, except for two or three with bad colds, and these were in bed receiving care and attention from the nursing Sister.

The meals consist of wheat porridge, milk, bread, grease, and tea for breakfast; for dinner and supper - meat, vegetables, bread, butter or lard, syrup or dried fruit, and tea with sugar is provided. Fish is often substituted for meat. Milk often replaces tea. The children apparently receive plenty, and the food is well prepared and wholesome.

The school, throughout, is well managed, and the staff members appear capable for the duties assigned to them.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to forward herewith a very satisfactory report on the schools in the Duck Lake Agency, comprising three Day Schools and one Residential School.

You will note that at the Moose Woods Day School there is an enrolment of 13 pupils, with an average attendance of 12.15, and that the children are neatly dressed and clean in appearance. This speaks very well for the parents on this reserve, who are not under the guidance of a White Instructor, but merely the influence of the teacher, Miss Hare, who is quite capable. The Inspector points out that the school and residence are in good repair, but that both buildings are badly in need of painting, and that a fence is also required. I would point out that $150.00 was placed in the Estimates for painting, and $55.00 for a fence. I should be glad to see these items approved.

At the John Smith's Day School the work seems to be carried on under a capable teacher. The attendance here is highly satisfactory. It is pleasing to note that here too, where we have no resident Farming Instructor, the children were found to be well clothed and neat in appearance.

-At the-

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
At the Fort a la Corne South Day School the teacher is apparently getting splendid results, and the training the children receive will certainly be of great benefit to them in later life. The Inspector points out that there is no well at this school, which is a great handicap. There is an amount of $100.00 in the Estimates for a well, and I hope it has not been struck out.

The Inspector points out that a new furnace is badly needed at the Fort a la Corne North Day School, as the one now in use is beyond repair. This is a matter that calls for immediate action. I may point out that we asked the Department to place an item of $275.00 in the Supplementary Estimates to provide a furnace, and I should be glad to be advised at as early a date as possible if it is being allowed, as I would like to have the furnace installed as soon as spring comes.

The report on the Duck Lake Residential School is most satisfactory. I think the children in this school are getting a good training in all branches of the work. There is one matter which I think should be drawn to the attention of the Department, and that is that the Sister in charge of the Junior grades does not hold a Saskatchewan Certificate.

The children receive a splendid training in all branches of domestic work, but the Inspector does not state whether the girls are being taught to milk cows or not. I am rather inclined to think they are, notwithstanding the fact that there is no mention of it in the report.

You will note a request is made for a family size electric washer, so that the staff washing can be done separately. I do not know that the Department should be called upon to supply this.

I would particularly draw your attention to the wholesome meals that the children at this school receive. I know they get all the vegetables that are good for them, as well as a good quantity of fresh milk.

The report on the whole, as I say, is very satisfactory.

Yours very truly,
