Sir:

On the 14th February last I advised you of the dismantling of the engine and motors at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School and that I proposed to have shipped and stored at Regina the batteries in use with the 15 H.P. engine. I wrote the Principal, asking him to have them carefully packed, but received a letter from him which indicates that the proposed method of shipment could not be carried out. I therefore asked the Manager of the Delco-Light-Frigidaire Company here to advise me what would be the best arrangement to adopt in having these batteries taken care of and brought to Regina for storage. His report in reply indicates that great care must be taken and that, unless certain shipping instructions are followed out, the railway company will not accept them for transportation. The expenditure involved, including the time and expense of an expert who will have to proceed to Duck Lake to superintend the packing, will cost $239.60, according to the estimate furnished me by Mr. J. M. Sharpe, the Manager of the Company referred to.

I do not feel justified in incurring this expenditure without submitting the matter for the consideration of the Department. I should like to be advised what action the Department desires to be taken to properly take care of these valuable batteries, which Mr. Sharpe estimates are worth about $1,000.00.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to report that I received a long distance call from the Duck Lake Residential School on April 24th informing me that the well from which they obtained their main water supply had failed. I left the same evening for Duck Lake and the following morning investigated the situation.

The well in question was sunk twenty-three years ago. It is approximately 110 feet in depth, a drilled hole with 8" iron casing. A concrete building was erected over this well. It is connected with the school by a pipe line 800 feet in length. The well has an iron casing 8" in diameter with a long Johnston screen at the bottom. During the long period that this well has been in use I am informed that several foreign articles have been dropped down the casing, such as tools, piping etc., inadvertently dropped while workmen were engaged from time to time in making repairs.

Owing to the small size of the hole and its depth, it is impossible to ascertain just what has happened; but I suspect that the screen has become perforated allowing the sand to fill in and shut off the water supply. It may be also that the casing has become eaten into and perforated. I examined several pieces of heavy piping which had been used in the well and found these were perforated in many places. The inference I took from this was that possibly the same action had occurred in connection with the iron casing. In order to repair the well it would be necessary to tear down the concrete building and have a drilling machine remove the foreign matter at the bottom and also to clear out the sand; but, when that had been accomplished, it is doubtful if a satisfactory job of repairing could be made and in any event I believe the operation would cost in the neighborhood of $300.00.

I find upon enquiry that water in the district surrounding the school building can be obtained at from 90 to 115 feet. There appears to be no question but that an ample supply of water can be obtained anywhere in that particular area by drilling to a depth of approximately 100 feet. I am informed on good authority that we can expect the present pipe line to last not longer than three or four years, possibly five. It will then have to be renewed at a cost, including the laying of the pipe line at approximately $1.00 per foot, of $800.00.

Sir:

I beg to report that I received a long distance call from the Duck Lake Residential School on April 24th informing me that the well from which they obtained their main water supply had failed. I left the same evening for Duck Lake and the following morning investigated the situation.

The well in question was sunk twenty-three years ago. It is approximately 110 feet in depth, a drilled hole with 8" iron casing. A concrete building was erected over this well. It is connected with the school by a pipe line 800 feet in length. The well has an iron casing 8" in diameter with a long Johnston screen at the bottom. During the long period that this well has been in use I am informed that several foreign articles have been dropped down the casing, such as tools, piping etc., inadvertently dropped while workmen were engaged from time to time in making repairs.

Owing to the small size of the hole and its depth, it is impossible to ascertain just what has happened; but I suspect that the screen has become perforated allowing the sand to fill in and shut off the water supply. It may be also that the casing has become eaten into and perforated. I examined several pieces of heavy piping which had been used in the well and found these were perforated in many places. The inference I took from this was that possibly the same action had occurred in connection with the pipe casing. In order to repair the well it would be necessary to tear down the concrete building and have a drilling machine remove the foreign matter at the bottom and also to clear out the sand; but, when that had been accomplished, it is doubtful if a satisfactory job of repairing could be made and in any event I believe the operation would cost in the neighborhood of $300.00.

I find upon enquiry that water in the district surrounding the school building can be obtained at from 90 to 115 feet. There appears to be no question but that an ample supply of water can be obtained anywhere in that particular area by drilling to a depth of approximately 100 feet. I am informed on good authority that we can expect the present pipe line to last not longer than three or four years, possibly five. Sir:

I beg to report that I interviewed Mr. Creelman this afternoon and found that he can start immediately. This, however, is dependent on casing being on the ground, as he cannot drill more than a few feet without it. Consequently I took the responsibility of ordering 120 feet of 3" genuine wrought iron casing (similar to that in the old well), drive shoe and driving head from the only available source, viz., Cranes & Limited of Saskatoon. A copy of the order is enclosed. This immediate action was obligatory, as it supplies an opportunity for Mr. Creelman to begin work.

The next important matter is to provide for the extension to the tank basement. The extension will be 25' long (jutting out from the building) and 6' wide and about 7' deep. It will lie parallel and contiguous to the tank basement, with floor sides and ceiling of re-inforced concrete.

My first thought was to return to Duck Lake tomorrow morning and procure workmen and building materials and provide definitely for construction of the basement as soon as Creelman has finished the well, i.e., definitely plan for whole work. However, on second thought on reading the telegram "to initiate work", I wondered whether this gave me the authority to hire the men and definitely start the work towards completion. Personally, I think it does definitely instruct you (and me) to go ahead.

However, a short delay in this part of the work will not hurt matters, especially as Mr. Creelman will be some time drilling the well. Incidentally his charges are $2.50 per foot. The depth will probably be about 120 feet. This is the standard price and was mentioned to Mr. Agent Schmidt at the beginning. It is a reasonable price, especially considering the small depth. He would not definitely set an exact time but it will be at least 10 days.

However, I propose to proceed to North Battleford tomorrow morning, thence to Meadow Lake in the afternoon, and do the hydrometric work (5 streams) at the beginning of the week, then proceed again to Battleford to settle the matter of drilling the well at Sandfield School between Nicholson and Rahrick. I was unable to do this during the present week because of the state of the roads. These are now dry and I wish to go to Meadow Lake before rain comes again, today being the first dry one for a week.

1. Purpose of Report

A telegram was received from the Director, dated April 26, 1934, to the effect that the water supply at Duck Lake Indian School had failed and requested that an inspection be made immediately.

The writer proceeded to carry out these instructions, arriving at Duck Lake on May 2. The preliminary inspection was made in company with Mr. C.P. Schmidt, Indian Agent; Rev. Father Delmas, the Principal; and Mr. Forsythe, the School Engineer.

2. Necessary Water Supply

The total staff and pupils amount to 180. The stock includes 100 head of cattle together with horses, sheep, pigs, etc., in proportion, necessitating an available supply of 7000 or 8000 gallons per day or more, at certain times such as winter, Washing, etc.

3. Available Supply.

(a) Well No.1 was drilled by the Government of the North West Territories many years ago for the use of
travellers. It is situated 6' inside (or outside) the boundaries of the school lands, being about 300 feet southwest of the school building. It is probably about 100 feet deep. It actually may or may not be considered as belonging to the school. An eight-foot windmill mounted on a thirty-foot tower, together with an auxiliary 5 h.p. gasoline engine, supply the motive power. This well is at present producing all of the water used by the school. Consequently, if it should cease production for any reason, e.g., during the winter, the school would be entirely deprived of water.

Incidentally, it will be noted that, up to the present, the Government has been subjected to no expense for wells at this School.

(b) Well No.2 was drilled about 1910 by the Mission Authorities to a depth of 105 feet, near the site of the original school which afterwards burned down. This well is 900 feet west of the present school buildings, and is connected with the tanks at the new school by a 2" galvanized pipe, buried 9 feet below the surface and 900 feet long.

This well is situated in a pump house 18' square made of concrete walls 10" thick and ceiling 5" thick. In addition, a false sloping roof made of lumber and from 5' to 6' high has been superimposed on the old ceiling which itself is 10 feet high. The concrete portion of the ceiling has two heavy steel railway rails located about 6 feet apart and resting on the walls, for additional support.
This well is equipped with 8" casing, 3" pipe and a 5 h.p. Fairbanks-Morse motor capable of pumping 1500 gallons per hour. The motor is located in the bottom of a small pit 6' x 3' which has been excavated to a depth of 2' in the bottom of a larger pit 6' square and 12 feet deep. The normal distance from surface of ground to water surface is 28 feet.

This is the well which has failed to produce water. An examination was made by the writer of its capacity.

**Present Condition of Well No.2.**

The pump was started and the casing was emptied to the bottom of the 45 feet of 3" pipe in 2½ minutes. It then "sucked". The water resumes its original height (28' below surface of the ground) in about 5 minutes. This means that the water is running into the casing at an impossibly slow rate. This produces a serious situation which cannot remain for long without improvement.

Originally the water lowered one foot when pumping continuously for 4 hours. At present the pump has been actuated for half a day with only a few gallons resulting.

Father Delmas thinks the casing has "burst". Mr. Greelman thinks that the screen was not placed originally below the casing. The proper method is to drive the casing below its permanent position, insert the screen,
and then pull the casing upwards the length of the screen, leaving the latter at the bottom of the hole. Again, the bottom of the casing may be plugged with sand or foreign matter. At any rate it is known that an old cylinder, a wrench and other foreign materials are now at the bottom of the hole, in the casing.

Labour and Cost of Renovation of Well No.2.

This method of improving the water supply was fully examined by the writer during his visit.

Firstly, it would be necessary to breach the concrete walls and ceiling, also remove the lumber roof, of the pump-house to a width of at least 8' in order to allow the drilling rig to be placed over the hole which is six feet inside the building. The steel rails which are embedded in the concrete ceiling would have to be cut. Then the driller and helper would "fish" with tools for the old cylinder, screen, wrench, etc., at the bottom, perhaps unsuccessfully. The casing may be "frozen" and immovable without breaking, as the drilling rigs and 50 ton jacks are unbelievably powerful. The drillers might work 5 or 6 days at $20 per day and then not accomplish anything.

In addition, the 900 feet of pipe, placed in 1924, will almost surely soon need replacement because of deterioration by the water. This latter point is of great importance and cannot be over-stressed.

4. Recommended Procedure, a New Well No.3.

The cost of renovation of Well No.2 was then compared with the cost of a new well, together with necessary housing.

The most convenient and economical site for a new well was found to be near the present tank basement, as shown on the accompanying plan.

This basement is 28 feet long and 14 feet wide jutting out from the boiler room. A small addition
5' square was also constructed at one side to provide ingress from the boiler room. The basement is 7 feet deep and is constructed with reinforced concrete walls and an earthen floor.

The proposal is to construct an additional basement 23' long by 6' wide as a side extension. This extension will be constructed of reinforced concrete as to walls, ceiling and floor. As the small entrance from the boiler room is barely 6' high and 4' square, inside measurement, it is proposed to widen the extension to 6' and place a step at the entrance to the extension. As the water will probably be about 28 to 30 feet below the surface of the ground it will probably be necessary to place the motor in an extra pit 6' x 8' at the west end of the extension. Water should not be pumped more than 15 or 16 feet. Consequently the pit will be about 5 or 6 feet below the boiler room flood.

The present south wall of the tank basement will require to be extended downwards to the depth of the pit.

An opening 18" square, covered, will be left in the roof immediately over the well to facilitate future cleaning.

In addition it may be found necessary to install a water softener. Space will be available to the east of the pump pit.

5. Subsequent Procedure.

It was recommended that the construction of a
new well be proceeded with immediately. Instructions being received by wire, R.E. Creelman of Saskatoon was engaged to drill the well. He stated that he needed 120 feet of 8" casing, drive shoe, drive head and screen before beginning work. This material was ordered with the exception of the screen which was delayed until the size of sand grains and depth of water-bearing sand stratum was known.

The well at present writing (May 17) is down to 96 feet, and sufficient water is obtained at this depth.

It is always impossible to know the depth to which a well should be drilled.

The number of men required for this work will be as follows:

8. Conclusion

The whole intended design, together with
details, was discussed between the School Engineer and Mr. Fetterly, in order that the work might be proceeded with without the necessary presence of the latter at the school during inception of construction. The school engineer, Mr. Forsythe, is a competent man to oversee the work under Father Delmas and Mr. C.P. Schmidt, the Indian Agent.

The plan has been prepared but lacks one detail, viz: the depth of water surface below surface of ground. The depth of the pit depends on this distance as no attempt should be made to pump water with a shallow well pump more than 15 or 16 feet.

Before Mr. Fetterly's departure from the school, on May 12, he requested Father Delmas to send information to the Calgary office on four questions:

1. Depth from ground surface to water surface in the well.
2. Check depth of drilled hole by means of a coil of stove-pipe wire and send this to Calgary for measurement.
3. Secure a sample of water after the well has been well bailed for possible chemical analysis as all water in this vicinity is said to be rather hard. A water softener may be needed at a later date to prevent possible damage to plumbing.

A copy of a former analysis of water from Well No.1 is enclosed.

4. Ascertain capacity by causing the driller to bail out
the well, i.e. the number of gallons per minute for say, one hour. The Driller stated that he could raise a 10 gallon baler three times per minute.

Answers to these requests are expected at any time as advice has been received from the driller to the effect that water was struck at 96 feet. Meanwhile, this report has been prepared and sent to you for consideration.

It is hoped that further construction will not be delayed as a well is said to deteriorate if removal of water from it ceases for a time.

With reference to your letter of April 26 re the water supply system at Duck Lake Indian Residential School, I enclose herewith a preliminary report on the condition of the existing wells, the action taken in view of the serious water shortage and the additional construction required to complete the new supply with estimates of cost.

Dear Sir,

Herewith enclosed please find my account for drilling well at Indian Residential school at Duck Lake.

Rev. M. Delmas is sending you a log of well so I will not enclose one. You will note that I have drilled to the depth of one hundred and eighteen feet, twenty-two feet after striking water at 96 feet. I always go through the water bearing strata and then set the screen in the most suitable place. So I have set the screen at 105 to 112 feet level where the coarse sand and gravel is. I bailed the well at the rate of 5 bailers every two minutes each bailer full holding ten gallons, without lowering static head over five feet. We then put the school pump on and pumped for six hours at 7 gallons per minute without lowering static head.

I would recommend this well for seventy-five gallons per minute without doing well any damage. I also would recommend a deep well turbine pump capacity 75 gallons per minute for this well as this well will give a good fire protection at any time.

It is hardly necessary to repeat the conversation the writer had with you when you were in Onion Lake a few weeks ago, and this equipment in an institution such as the Indian School at Duck Lake, would effect many many savings, and we feel sure that it would be a very wise investment on your part.

FINAL REPORT

on

Improved Water Supply

at

Duck Lake Indian School

Duck Lake, Saskatchewan.

by P.A. Fetterly, B.Sc., R.P.E., Assistant Hydraulic Engineer.

1. Purpose of Report.

A Preliminary Report on the above named subject was prepared and dated May 17, 1934. The work is now completed and this constitutes the final report pursuant to an inspection made on August 30, 1934, by the writer.

2. Materials.

The materials were of excellent character. They were supplied promptly when needed.

3. Workmanship.

The workmanship is of excellent character. The heavy pressure tanks in the adjacent basement were not disturbed to any extent whatever although the pump pit is 8 feet lower than the floor of the latter. The footing is very solid, being on a hard sand; the extra wall under the original tank basement wall is solid. The concrete appears solid, there being no cracks. The connection with the old tank roof is well made, the new reinforcing steel being hooked on the old steel which was uncovered. A slight discoloration a few inches square appeared in the
west wall at the junction but this can be eliminated by banking this portion.

The cutting of the opening from the small entry into the new basement occupied the labour of the four men for six days and cost $48.00. The electrical fixtures were installed by the school engineer at no cost to the Government except for some of the material.

The pump and motor from the old well was installed in the new one and works efficiently.

4. Water Supply

The water in the casing stands at 14 feet below the floor of the pit. When pumping is begun the water lowers about a foot in the casing, probably the "draw-down" only. Pumping can then be continued for a day or more and the water stops at this level.

The water is of even better quality than that produced by the old well.

The windmill over Well No.1 will still be used on windy days.

5. Credentials.

Mr. Schmidt, Indian Agent; Father Delmas, the Principal; and the writer, were very pleased with the completed work. Mr. Murison, Inspector of Agencies, together with the Superintendent-General, visited the school immediately after completion and, after examining the installation, expressed themselves favourable after an inspection.

Duck Lake, Sask., Nov. 25th, 1934.

Dear Sir,

I beg to call your attention on our small cold storage, which proves inadequate. When the school was built, ten years ago, the Department was not supplying any school with a Genuine Frigidaire. Although the schools built since then have been supplied with such.

I realize that ten years ago it would not have been wise to have one, when our electric power was so limited. Instead of this, a small brick building was put up by the Department in 1926, on the North side of our pantry.

Twice a week, we have to put some ice in it and even with the best care, we lose some meat every season. Moreover, during the hottest days the meat stinks. The melting ice also leaks on the meat, and the concrete floor gets covered with that filthy water.

Now that we have the electric power from Saskatoon, and that the prices of Genuine Frigidaires are cut down, I would like to have that question, brought up to the Department, making them understand the necessity of having a real true refrigerator.

It is a question of hygiene, cleanliness and economy, first of all. Then regarding the financial question, a Genuine Frigidaire would save lots of good food, the cost of 40 tons of ice, saw dust, packing and hauling ice twice a week, about $225.00 a year. It would be a wise investment.

You may present to the Department, the suggestions which were offered to me last fall by the J. H. Ashdown Edwe. Co. Limited of Saskatoon.

"After making a careful investigation of the requirements at this institution, where approximately 500 meals every day are provided, we estimated the cost of supplying this institution with proper Genuine Frigidaire equipment.

........2
Nov. 25th, 1934.

The present method for use, as no doubt you are well aware, is a walk-in refrigerator. It would be our suggestion that this refrigerator be re-insulated with 2" of cork-board. The door in the present ice bunker would be closed, and the ice bunkers in the present box would all be removed before the insulation was added. The present walk-in door would be re-built and equipped with special refrigerator door hardware with the proper offset equipped with the necessary wire gaskets.

We would install one only WXL478 Cooling Coil controlled by one only TS Expansion Valve. This would be operated by one only 3D Genuine Frigidaire Air-Flow Compressor.

All the above equipment would be supplied and installed complete for the sum of $682.00. This price includes the necessary electrical work to install this equipment and represents a complete job in every respect."

I am asking you, Dear Sir, to do your best in recommending to the Department that a Genuine Frigidaire be granted this spring to our school.

Sincerely yours,

Sir:

I have the honour to enclose herewith a communication received from Rev. H. Delmas, Principal of the Duck Lake Indian Residential School which is self explanatory.

I strongly recommend that the request be granted as the small brick building now in use is not a success. One of the reasons I have found, which the Principal does not mention, is that the ice used which is taken from alkaline bottom lakes, smells when melting; the water from this ice is not fit for drinking.

I note the J.H. Ashdown Hardware Co., a representative has recommended insulating with 2 inch cork board. In my opinion this is not thick enough.

I would ask that the request be given early attention and if granted that the work be done early in the season before the month of May, which some years is a very hot month.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

It is proposed to supply a frigidaire system for use at the Indian Residential School at Duck Lake, (Federal Constituency of Prince Albert) Sask., to replace the present small cold storage system, which is inadequate.

This school is now connected with electric power from Saskatoon and the present method used is known as a "walk-in" refrigerator. It is intended to have this refrigerator re-insulated with corkboard, the ice bunkers removed, the present walk-in door rebuilt, cooling coils and air flow compressor installed, and the whole plant connected to the power line.

The J. H. Ashdown Hardware Company, Limited, Saskatoon, Sask., have quoted a price of $682.00 for supplying the equipment required and installing same, complete.

The sum of $700 is provided in our Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, to cover the cost of installing refrigeration at the Duck Lake School. I would request your approval for incurring the expenditure required in installing the refrigeration system and also to be advised if it will be satisfactory to place the order with the above named firm, or what other firms you would desire be given an opportunity to quote.

Deputy Superintendent General.

SIZE AND DETAILS OF PRESENT REFRIGERATOR:-
Your present Walk-In Refrigerator size inside is approximately 6' wide 7' long, 9'8" high including ice bunkers, and has one Walk-In door 27" wide x 72" high with ordinary Tee Hinges and no Hasp.

PRESENT CONSTRUCTION:-
Brick Veneer - Aire Space; 1" Lumber; 4" Studding two board finish inside.

All present ice bunkers will be removed. The present door where the ice is put in the bunkers will be replaced by Brick Veneer, closing same up the same as the balance of the south wall. The east end of your present wall will be taken out and the south wall continued to join the main wall of your present building. No. 2. will be approximately 4' wide, by 6' deep by 3'6" high.

No.1. Compartment will be used for storing and refrigerating of meats, etc.

No.2. will be used for storage of milk, butter, etc.

RE INSULATION:-

We plan to add the following viz;-
One ply of wax paper, then 2" of corkboard in sheets 12x36x2" thick set in hot hydrolene and another ply of wax paper. Then finish with a good grade of V joint siding. This applies to top, ends and sides.

RE FLOOR:-

PARTITION:-

The partition dividing these two compartments will be insulated with 2" corkboard set in hot hydrolene and wax paper on both sides and finished with V joint.
FINISH OF INTERIOR:

After all interior woodwork is completed the entire surface will be thoroughly shellaced.

Compartment No.2. will have cooling coil #1056 - 10" wide by 56" long.

Dear Sir:

We beg to enclose tender for Refrigerator Equipment for
the Indian School at Duck Lake. In doing so we are tak-
ing the liberty of making a few suggestions with the
object of obtaining the maximum amount of refrigerator
space from the building at present used as a refrigera-
tor, also with as much convenience as possible for the
kitchen staff.

On the day the writer examined the present refrigerator,
water was standing on the floor of the refrigerator and
the kitchen superintendent advised me that this occurred
each spring. Suggestions are embodied in contract to
take care of this.

Further, the superintendent complained that when the
building was erected tar paper was used in the construc-
tion and the smell of this tar paper got into all
foods stored in the refrigerator during the summer, when
the weather was hot. We suggest that this matter will
have to be taken care of when re-building the refrigera-
tor and we have accordingly included this in our estima-
te and the contract.

On examining the building in which the present refrig-
erator is housed we find that the roof of the building
was connected with the main building. The building
housing the refrigerator did not connect with the main
building except at the door of the meat cutting room.
We have enclosed a plan of the building as it is at the
present time and as we would suggest that it be made, to
obtain the maximum storage space which is badly needed
by the school. The proposed change would not involve
any structural difficulties nor any material cost, as the
brick taken from the wall removed could be used again on
the new wall and for bricking up the old ice entrance on
the outside of the building.
We are making one other suggestion and that is, that when the concrete floor of the new refrigerator is put in that a new floor on the same level be installed in the meat cutting room adjoining refrigerator as this floor is in bad condition, and the elimination of the step up to the refrigerator would be of great convenience.

Owing to the fact that our recommendations take on a different form to your letter calling for tenders, we are submitting two tenders marked Plan 1 and Plan 2 and have given full details in each case with the tender.

We regret that this letter is so lengthy but we believe you will excuse it under the circumstances. We would also like, at this time, to take the opportunity to thank the staff of the school and yourself for the courtesy shown to us during our visits to the school, in connection with this matter.

Yours truly,

MARSHALL WELLS COMPANY LIMITED,

Refrigeration Department.

Sir:

Reference Departmental letter #109-1-5 of the 20th ultimo re Electric Refrigerator system for the Duck Lake Indian Residential School, I have the honour to enclose herewith specifications and prices received from:

The Manville Hardware Co., Prince Albert, Frigidaire System
Marshall-Wells Ltd., Saskatoon,

Kelvinator

The other firms mentioned in the Department's letter have not quoted, namely: Electric Shop Ltd., Saskatoon, who wrote me saying that for the last two or three years they have not been selling commercial electrical refrigeration jobs. Northern Hardware, Prince Albert, I called on the manager, on May 9th and asked him if he had received my letter of April 24th, asking for a quotation, he said he had and was referring the matter to someone else (Marshall Wells I believe). Grosser & Glass Ltd., Prince Albert, have written me saying they have no facilities at the present time for doing this work.

After receiving the Departmental letter mentioned above I visited the school and took the matter up with the Principal who told me that last autumn when he asked the J.N. Ashdown Co. to give him a price all he had in mind was renovating the meat cooling room, which is not satisfactory (see paragraph three and five of his letter of November 20th, 1934) No provision was made for the refrigeration of milk, cream, butter, etc., which are now being kept in a pantry across the corridor from the kitchen. The pantry not being sufficiently cool in summer milk sours in less than 24 hours and there is waste in these kinds of food as well as in the meats. (NOTE:- See Manville Hardware Co., SUMMARY page #7) I therefore worked on a new plan to provide separate compartments for dairy foods and trays for making ice cubes which are indispensable in an institution like ours, more so in case of sickness, also, a fish box, as there are times in summer when fresh fish is procured from the Saskatchewan rivers or from lakes in the district.

Under the new plan which I will refer to as General Plan, one wall, brick veneer of the present refrigerator building will have to be taken down and this building extended to the main (School) building.

See Manville Co specifications, Page #1, Changes to be made See Marshall Wells, Ltd., Plan #1 (General Plan) last line, also 2nd sheet of sketch lower part in black ink and paragraph four of letter dated May 14th, 1935.

I note Manville Hardware Co.'s specifications call for 2 inch cork board insulation, while Marshall Wells Co specify 3 inches viz; one 2 inch ply and another 1 inch over same breaking joints. I did not discuss this with the representatives who came to look over the layout as I considered they knew what is required, however when the outside walls of the building are taken into consideration, i.e.; brick veneer, one row only, not a solid brick wall, I am doubtful whether 2 inches of cork board is sufficient.
It is obvious that the extra inch of cork board specified by the Marshall Wells Co is a big factor in their quotation being higher than the other.

I strongly recommend that the "General Plan" I suggested be accepted and installed for the following reasons:

(a) The meat cooling room is too small to accommodate all foods requiring refrigeration.

(b) It is not practicable to keep in covered containers the large amounts of dairy produce and other perishable foods required for this institution some of which would have to be placed on the floor under the meat racks.

(c) It is absolutely necessary that ice be available in case of emergencies.

(d) The extra cost of installing a complete refrigerator now, would be less than the cost of an addition which I am certain will be demanded in the near future.

Yours truly,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

FEES FOR THE INSPECTION OF STEAM BOILERS &C.

Under the provisions of Section 2 of an Act to amend the Steam Boilers Act being Chapter 50 of 1925-26 and of Section 57 of the Steam Boilers Act, His Honour the Lieutenant Governor by and with the advice of the Executive Council has been pleased to prescribe the fees which shall be payable for the inspection of steam boilers and other pressure vessels, as follows:

For each portable or traction boiler used for agricultural purposes.................. $ 5.00

For each High Pressure Boiler carrying a working pressure exceeding 15 pounds per square inch (except portable or traction boilers used for agricultural purposes) as follows:

Not exceeding 25 Horse Power.......................... $ 5.00
Exceeding 25 Horse Power but not exceeding 50 Horse Power......................... 7.50
Exceeding 50 Horse Power but not exceeding 75 Horse Power......................... 10.00
Exceeding 75 Horse Power but not exceeding 100 Horse Power....................... 12.50
Exceeding 100 Horse Power but not exceeding 250 Horse Power...................... 15.00
Exceeding 250 Horse Power......................... 20.00

For each Low Pressure Boiler carrying a working pressure not exceeding 15 pounds per square inch as follows:

Heating Boilers not exceeding 20 Horse Power - Froo Cast Iron sectional boilers exceeding 20 Horse Power......................... 3.00

For all other low pressure boilers the inspection fees shall be the same as for high pressure boilers, provided that when an external inspection only is made the inspection fee shall be $3.00.

For each Air and Gas tank, steam cooker, digester, steam kettle or other pressure vessel.

Not exceeding 24 inches in diameter or 6 feet in length............................ 3.00
Exceeding 24 inches in diameter or 6 feet in length but not exceeding 48 inches in diameter or 10 feet in length............. 5.00
Exceeding 48 inches in diameter or 10 feet in length but not exceeding 60 inches in diameter or 12 feet in length........... 7.50
Exceeding 60 inches in diameter or 12 feet in length............................ 10.00

The fees payable for the inspection of Stills shall be the same as for High Pressure Boilers.

Steam Boilers and Stills shall be rated at one Horse Power for each ten square feet of heating surface.

The above schedules of fees shall come into force on the 1st day of May 1926.

Dear Sir:

Further to our conversation of yesterday re painting to be done in our school, I beg to say that, as you noticed, we need some painting on metallic ceiling and on stairs as follows:

**Metallic Ceiling**
Pharmacy--250 sq.ft.--some rotten sheets may need to be replaced.
Corridor (main floor)--860 sq.ft.
Parlor--224 sq.ft.
Kitchen and Scullery--648 sq.ft.
Sky Window--180 sq.ft.

Total 2282 sq.ft.

**Stairs**
Concrete has been replaced on steel steps. These were built during the winter months of 1925 and some parts of the concrete work was frozen on both sides (boys' and girls'). Since then, these steps have become worn out and are dangerous. I have made many inquiries how to repair them and it is only lately that I have been assured of entire success by using a kind of putty manufactured by the Tremco Manufacturing Co., Ltd., Canada. As I want this work very well done I will have my mechanic do it. I wish the Department to pay for the material required which has already been ordered and which amounts to about $95.25.

Also, as both, Indians and children, use these stairs the walls are very dirty and need painting. We have tried water paint without any success. The walls might need scrubbing before oil paint can be applied. The dimensions of these walls including both sides, total 4400 sq.ft., which includes the wall on the south side which goes to the infirmaries. The last mentioned wall has been very dirty since 1925 having been stained before it was dry by smoke escaping from the boilers.
Besides these, I might state that the floor, walls, and ceiling of the dining room are also in great need of repairs and repainting.

Hoping these explanations prove satisfactory, I remain, Dear Sir,

Sincerely Yours,

H. Delmas
Principal.
Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter No. 109-1-5 dated the 7th instant, regarding the expenditure of $400.00 for repairs at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School.

I visited the School yesterday and inspected the interior of the building with the Rev. Father Delmas, the Principal of the School, whom I requested to submit a report on the work he considered necessary.

The work mentioned in his report is, in my opinion, necessary, and I recommend as follows:

That an expenditure of approximately $100 be made first for material to repair the steel steps on the stairways. According to the Principal's report enclosed herein it will not be necessary to pay for the labor in this connection. In places the cement filling in the steps is so badly worn that the outside steel flange of the step is now above the cement and accidents are liable to occur to those descending the stairway by getting the toe of their shoe caught in the steel flange and falling down the stairway.

In regard to the placing of metallic sheets on the ceiling of the Pharmacy room, painting the walls and ceilings where required I would recommend that a competent workman be asked to submit an estimate as to the cost of the material and labor required to do this work. In so doing it is possible that it will be found unnecessary to expend the amount provided.

Your Obedient Servant,

S.H. Simpson,
Indian Agent.

Duck Lake, Sask., October 21st, 1938

Dear Sir;

I beg to advise that the following repairs are badly needed at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School:

Four classrooms and the Sewing Room in the School require to have the ceilings and walls painted, and the floors varnished.

The steps leading to the front entrance of the School require replacing as the boards therein are badly worn and rotted.

The roof of the Community Hall at this School requires re-shingling. As this building is placed between two chimneys sparks often fall on the roof. It therefore should be shingled with a fireproof material.

The School also requires a shoe sewing machine for repairing the pupils' shoes, as the old machine is now worn out.

I beg to advise that owing to the crop failures during the past four years this School has had very little revenue from their grain crops. They also have had to reduce their herd of cattle. This has resulted in their not producing sufficient funds to keep their buildings in repair.

The Principal has requested that the foregoing projects receive the consideration of the Department.

I recommend that his request be favorably considered.

Form No. 37, listing the materials required is attached hereto in duplicate.

Your Obedient Servant,

S.H. Simpson,
Indian Agent.

Duck Lake, Sask., December 5th, 1938

Dear Sir;

With reference to the fourth paragraph of my letter No. 974-4, dated October 21st, and to Purchase Order No. 8625 pertaining to roofing material for the Community Hall at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School, I beg to report as follows:

I am in receipt of a letter from the Prince Albert Manufacturing Company, Prince Albert, which reads:

"Further to our telephone conversation, we are in receipt of an order from Ottawa which reads as follows:

'31 Squares Johns-Manville, Standard Green Slatekote Shingles, in four-tab strips, size 10" x 36", 2" head lap, 4" exposure, 100 shingles per square packed in two bundles Weight approximately 200 Lbs. per square as illustrated on page II Johns-Manville (building material) Catalogue.'

"We are advised by the Canadian Johns-Manville Co. that this is an old specification and this particular type of shingle is not used in Western Canada any more, as they will not stand up under the climatic conditions. They also advise us that they have been supplying Thick Butt Shingles on the different Indian Schools, and they have been acceptable to the Department. When we quoted on this particular job it was our intention to supply the Thick Butt Twins. There is no difference in price between these and the ones which are specified above.

"We are sending under separate cover the Canadian Johns-Manville building materials Catalogue and you will find the two types of shingles on pages 10 and 11. If it is in order for us to ship these Thick Butt Shingles, we would be very pleased to have an early reply and we will be able to make immediate shipment."

I have taken this matter up with the Principal of the School, and he requested that the Thick Butt fireproof shingles be supplied in lieu of Slatekote Shingles in four-tab strips.

In view of this, together with the report made by the Prince Albert Manufacturing Company on this matter, I would recommend that authority be granted to have this Company supply the Thick Butt Shingles at the price quoted by them on Slatekote Shingles.

Your Obedient Servant,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Can.

S.H. Simpson,
Indian Agent.

POSITION VACANT.

Applications are invited from Residents of the Province of Saskatchewan qualified for the position of

INSPECTOR OF CONSTRUCTION. - PREVAILING RATES $6. PER DAY

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS, DUCK LAKE AGENCY, DUCK LAKE, SASK.

at prevailing rates $6. per day.

DUTIES: - Under direction, to oversee and inspect assigned portions of construction and repair work to ensure conformity with plans and specifications; to keep records of and make reports on the progress of the work, materials and supplies, and labour costs; if required, to act as construction foreman; to take inventories of supplies; and to perform other related work as required.

QUALIFICATIONS REQUIRED:- Primary school education; at least two years of supervisory experience in construction work; ability to read and interpret plans and specifications; familiarity with materials and methods of construction; tact and good judgment; integrity. Dear Mr. Scott:

I enclose herewith a number of applications which have been received for the position of Inspector of Construction. They are as follows:

Of these I beg to recommend the appointment of Mr. J. D. Ruttan as Travelling Inspector and of Mr. W. G. Wright as Inspector of Construction at the Duck Lake Agency.

I have reviewed the applications very carefully and have arrived at my decision by a process of elimination. The names of W. A. Hamilton, T. H. Hull, J. S. Manson, R. Paterson, E. S. Sanders and A. Taillon were struck off as none of them had been overseas.

Mr. H. E. Ford is too young to have gained much experience in building construction, and Mr. W. H. Lawson appears to be rather a cabinet maker than experienced in building.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Messrs. G. F. Neale and G. Sime do not appear to have had any experience in a supervisory capacity.

Mr. R. Thompson has occupied the position of Foreman Carpenter, but other than that does not appear to have had any supervisory duties in connection with general building programme. Moreover, although he served in Canada he was not overseas.

Of the remainder who were all overseas, Mr. W. P. Bayne worked for the Alberta Government and is well recommended, but is a resident of Medicine Hat Alberta, and his qualifications are not equal to those of Mr. Ruttan. His residence in Medicine Hat would therefore disqualify him for the position of Inspector in Duck Lake.

Neither Mr. T. S. Wilson nor Mr. W. F. Wilson have the experience or apparent qualifications held by Mr. W. G. Wright and Mr. J. D. Ruttan.

Dear Sir:

I beg to advise you that you have been appointed Inspector of Construction of the new Indian Residential School at Duck Lake, Sask., and you will be paid for your services at the rate of $6.00 per day. You will be expected to devote all of your time to this work, and to see that the building is built in accordance with the plans and specifications. You will note that no alterations are to be made in the plans and specifications or extra work authorized without furnishing full information to the Department and obtaining written consent for the changes. I would particularly draw your attention to this clause in the specifications and ask you to see that it is strictly complied with.

The contract for the building has been awarded to Smith Bros. & Wilson, Limited of Regina, at their tendered price of $126,840.00, and you will note by the specifications that they are to be paid on their contract at the rate of 90% of the value of the labour and material in the building. Certificate forms for this purpose are being sent you, under separate cover. These forms should be filled out in duplicate, and when giving the contractors the certificate you should at the same time forward to the Department a summary of the labour and material comprised in the certificate as issued.

You will be expected to make fortnightly reports to the Department through the Indian Commissioner's office at Regina, giving full details as to the progress of the work. I am sending you, under separate cover diary sheets which should be properly filled out and presented to Reverend Father Delmas, Principal of the Duck Lake School, at the end of each month, when he will forward them to the Department with a voucher for the payment of your salary.

I am also sending you, under separate cover, a blue print copy of the plans and specifications.

Yours very truly,

Adrien Taillon, Esq.,
Marcelin, Sask.

Duck Lake, Saskatchewan,
May 30, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report that the following buildings at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School are badly in need of painting. None of them have been painted since 1928, and two coats of paint will be required to properly cover them.

Viz: One Cow Barn, One Horse Barn, Two Attached Granaries, Two Implement Sheds, Two Employees' Residences, Two Indian Halls, Two Storage Sheds, One Hen House, One Well House, One Blacksmith Shop, One Slaughter House, and Two Granaries.

The Principal of the School has requested that the Department give consideration to supplying the materials required for the painting. The labor will be supplied by the school.

I recommend that this request be given favorable consideration.

Form No. 37 in duplicate, listing the materials required, is attached hereto.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo and also requisition for a supply of paint necessary for the painting of a number of buildings at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School, attached thereto.

Dear Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith Form No. 37 requisition for materials to re-roof the Duck Lake Indian Residential School.

This building was constructed in 1925 and I understand that the present roof was guaranteed for 10 years. The Principal informs me that a large sum of money has been spent during the past six years in repairing the roof without any permanent success.

On one of my recent visits to the school the Principal drew my attention to this matter. I found that the roof was leaking badly in the sleeping quarters of the boys and girls. Utenails were spread over the floors to catch the snow water coming through the roof. The walls of the building and some of the main beams encased in metal ceiling roofing are being damaged by the water seeping into them.

The roof has been examined by an expert from the Tremco Manufacturing Co., who advises that a satisfactory repair job cannot be done as the roof is weathered to the extent that continuous trouble will be experienced from other parts of the roof becoming no longer waterproof.

The Principal of the school has advised that the school has not sufficient funds to do this work. He requests that the Department assist by supplying the material and the school will provide the labour.

I recommend that his request be granted and if possible the work done before the spring rains.

Yours very truly,

S. H. Simpson
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 5th instant regarding the roof of the Duck Lake Indian Residential School.

The Department was surprised to receive your report regarding the condition of this roof as we do not appear to have any previous communication regarding the matter. No mention was made of repairs to this roof in your estimates for the fiscal year 1940-41. At that time you requested $800.00 for construction of an addition to provide outside wash rooms and toilets. Due to present conditions it is impossible to consider expenditures for which provision has not been made.

We are hopeful that the $800.00 will be provided in our appropriation for the year 1940-41 but owing to the dissolution of Parliament I am not in a position to state definitely if this amount will be available. However, it should be distinctly understood by the Principal that the Department cannot consider the repairs to the roof and also the erection of the new outside wash rooms and toilets. Dear Sir,

I beg to advise that the Reverend G.M. Latour, Principal of the Duck Lake Indian Residential School, has requested me to ascertain whether or not any funds have been provided from appropriation in the 1942-1943 estimates on behalf of this school for the purpose of repairs to the interior of the school building.

The roof of the part of the school building used as the chapel has only one ply of lumber, building paper and shingles and is not closed within. Departmental advice in this matter would be appreciated.

M. Christianson, Esq., General Superintendent of Indian Agencies, Federal Building, Regina, Sask.

On September 3rd Mr. Hayes, Provincial Inspector of Steam Boilers made his annual inspection of the two steam boilers at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School. He has reported that the tubes in both boilers are badly pitted and that it was absolutely necessary to have them replaced.

On contacting him by telephone on the night of the 7th he further stated that it would not be safe to use the boilers as the tubes were liable to go at any time and he doubted that they would stand one week's use.

While in Prince Albert yesterday I interviewed Mr. J.C. McDonald, Manager of the Prince Albert Foundry Company regarding the cost of new tubes, and installing thereof, also as to whether or not he had sufficient on hand to meet our requirements. He advised that he did not and stated that he would be able to procure them from Winnipeg but that there might be a slight delay due to the present control over materials of this kind.

Skilled labour will be required to remove the old tubes from the boilers and install the new ones. Such labour is not available in Duck Lake. Mr. Hayes, Boiler Inspector, recommended Mr. G. Pritz of Rosthern as being well experienced and capable in this work. I contacted Mr. Pritz by telephone today in order to get an estimate as to the cost of the labour. At present he is overcrowded with work and is unable to examine the work to be done at the school. His charges are one dollar per hour plus the services of a helper and he estimates that the cost of his services alone will be $300.00 which is $100.00 less than the rough estimate given to me by Mr. McDonald of the Prince Albert Foundry. The helper in this work will be provided by the school at no extra cost.

As the school building cannot be properly heated even in mild weather it would be appreciated if immediate authority could be granted to have the necessary repairs made to the boilers.

Form 37a listing the materials required and the cost of labour is attached hereto.

(Sgd.) S.H. Simpson,
Indian Agent.

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, enclosing requisition for materials required for repairs to the main building of the Duck Lake Residential School, in order to provide sanitary wash-rooms and toilets for female pupils.

Reference your letter No. 109-1-5, regarding requisition forwarded by this office for materials required for repairs to the main building of the Duck Lake Indian Residential School.

I have today finally succeeded in securing definite quotations from the Reliance Lumber Co., Rosthern, Sask. and beg to advise as follows:

Item 1. Unit price shown on our requisition for 1200 interlocking tile at $1.00. This should read 1200 interlocking tile at .10¢ each, a total of $120.00.

It is estimated that the amount of $30.00 will be required to cover costs of freighting the materials from Rosthern, Sask. to Duck Lake Indian Residential School.

I regret this error and the inconvenience it has caused your office.

Reference is made to your letter dated June 1st, your file No. 910-305-11 A.R.C., addressed to Rev. Father G.M. Latour (copy forwarded to this office) regarding storage water tanks required at St. Michaels Indian Residential School, Duck Lake, Sask.

I regret the delay in this matter, however we have finally secured a definite estimate from M. & K. Plumbing and Heating Company, Prince Albert, Sask., and enclose herewith a copy of their letter dated July 26th, also Form No. 37 outlining the amount required to purchase new tanks and labour in connection with installation.

I recommend that the new tanks be purchased immediately as the old tanks are no longer safe for use under pressure required.

I have carefully checked over the installation of the new tanks with Mr. Masche of M. & K. Plumbing and Heating Co., who accompanied me to St. Michaels Indian Residential School and the following is the proposed method which is submitted for Departmental approval.

1. Leave old tanks in present position, to be used for storage purposes only. In the event of a serious fire outbreak, the additional storage capacity of tanks now in use would be of considerable value.

2. Install new tanks immediately above and (at ground level) over old tank housings.

3. Erect a new additional structure over new tanks. Building to be of brick and tile with tarred roof, 2 walls only required 28' x 11' high and 23' x 11' high.

4. Heating arrangements for preventing freezing in cold weather is available at no extra cost by removing windows between new addition and main boiler room. Estimate of costs of material and labour for addition to house new pressure water tanks will be forwarded immediately available.

My reasons for recommending the addition to house the new tanks is as follows:

When the present water pressure tanks were installed, I find that liberal quantities of cement was used and the tanks installed with very little thought as to replacement in future years. The walls and ceiling are constructed of solid concrete and to now remove the ceiling, replace the present tanks and erect a structure over again will cost considerable, also while the installation is under way, the water supply at the school will be cut off for approximately two to three weeks. This to my mind will cause a serious fire hazard and also inconvenience to the school personnel who are now employed in and around the school premises.
Duck Lake, Sask.
July 29, 1946.

Kindly consider this matter as urgent and I would point out that the new tanks must be installed and ready for use on or before the opening of the fall academic term in September 1946. The addition to house the new tanks must also be constructed previous to October 1st, 1946.

With further reference to my letter No. 427-4 dated July 29th, regarding replacement of water pressure tanks at St. Michael's Indian Residential School, Duck Lake, Sask.

On August 23rd, accompanied by Mr. J.S. Mitchell, Department of Mines & Resources Land Surveyor, I again checked over the matter of replacing the present worn out tanks and the following proposal is recommended by Mr. Mitchell.

1. Excavate a trench at rear of tank storage basement approximately 6' in depth by 6' width and 15' to 20' in length. Cut a hole in concrete basement wall approximately 5' square, remove old tanks through this opening and replace new tanks. Shore up the opening in concrete wall with planking and refill trench with earth removed immediately new tanks have been installed. Estimated cost of removing earth, materials for shoring and refilling not to exceed $100.00.

2. Tanks now in use were purchased from The Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Company Limited 300-310 Princess Street, Winnipeg, Man. in the year 1929 and exact duplicates should be purchased in order to have tank openings and fittings correspond to the fittings etc. now in use.

3. M & K. Plumbing and Heating Co., Prince Albert should be employed to install new tanks or purchase the new tanks through this firm as outlined on Form 37 dated July 29, 1946, which shows the cost thereof i.e., materials and labour.

Labour costs of replacing these tanks may appear high; however please bear in mind a temporary set up must be arranged in order to assure that the supply of water to the school is not cut off during installation of the new tanks.

By following the plan outlined herein regarding excavating for removal of the tanks, a considerable saving can be expected and only a small opening made in concrete basement wall.

Kindly bear in mind that the tanks must be ordered immediately and installed previous to October 1st, next in order to have this work completed before freezing weather sets in.

N.J. McLeod
Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM

- The Deputy Minister -

I am returning herewith a requisition for six (6) sewing machines requested by the Principal of the Duck Lake Indian Residential School and submitted to the Purchasing Agent by the Superintendent of Training. I am returning also a memorandum dated February 5, 1947, and a statement outlining in detail the policy that might be followed with respect to the purchase of supplies for use at residential schools throughout the Dominion. This is no doubt the information to which you refer in your memorandum. I can attribute our failure to discuss this matter with you or with Mr. Jackson personally to the fact that the time at the disposal of the Superintendent of Training has been decidedly limited. He has been, as you know, giving until now a great deal of attention to the readjustment of Indian day school teachers' salaries and to the preparation of memoranda relating to their eligibility for superannuation allowances.

The proposal that purchases at residential schools should be measurably uniform is simply one that will not work in practice. My experience has convinced me that each request for supplies must be considered and decided on its merits, always keeping the actual needs of the Indian pupils in mind, particularly their educational needs and their educational advancement.

There are few requests for sewing machines, for example, from schools operated in cooperation with the Church of England in Canada, for the

.... simple
simple reason that the Women's Auxiliary of the Missionary Society of this Church have accepted the responsibility for years of supplying ready-made clothing to Anglican Residential Schools. Until two years ago, this branch paid the freight amounting to approximately $800.00 a year on this clothing. Late in the war period, however, the women responsible for supplying the clothing accepted this charge also. Dr. Alderwood, with whom I discussed this matter six months ago or so, was not at all sure that the policy was a wise one, judged from the standpoint of the pupil. In other words, he felt that it might be more advisable to buy cloth - dress material and cloth for boys' suits - in bulk, and have the pupils, particularly the senior girls, undertake the actual making of the garments and suits. He considered, and I was disposed to agree with him, that it was of the utmost importance that girls should be given a certain amount of this training prior to their return to the reserves.

There seems to be a feeling that certain School Principals, because of their persistency, request and receive more supplies than those to which they are entitled. This contention, however, is not borne out by the information on file. A number of examples of expenditures the significance of which is apt to be overlooked are made at certain schools annually. The Mohawk School at Brantford, for example, is operated nominally at least under the auspices of the Church of England. There are this year fifty-three pupils, many of them graduates of this school, and others of the Indian day schools on the Six Nations Reserve, proceeding with high school studies at a cost to this department of $12,000.00. The same policy, but not to the same extent, is followed at the Shingwauk Home at Sault Ste. Marie, also operated under the auspices of the Church of England, and at the Brandon School operated under the auspices of the United Church. We have not, however, I regret to state at this date an arrangement such as this with any of the schools operated under the auspices of the Catholic Church, for the simple reason that Catholic schools, with rare exceptions, are built on Indian reserves, and we have not found it possible or practical to adopt the Brantford policy at...
schools in remote and comparatively inaccessible districts.

The request for six (6) sewing machines at the Duck Lake Residential School represents an attempt on the part of the Principal to remodel discarded military clothing purchased by him from the War Assets Corporation and to make as well dresses and suits for the girls and boys in attendance at the school. The Oblate Order have for a number of years purchased dress material and suiting in bulk at wholesale rates for distribution to their schools. This provides the pupils, particularly the senior girls, with a certain amount of valuable training. There are at this date 202 pupils enrolled at the Duck Lake School, but per capita grants are allowed for only 187. The last audit statement covering the period February, 1945, to March, 1947, indicates that this school was indebted to the Oblate Order to the extent of $10,709.73, but the debt was reduced during the period covered by the audit by the sum of $2,084.82. It is significant to note that no interest has been charged on this loan. The auditor in his report states:

"While most of the expenditure groups show increases, the percentages of increases are not large, other than in Clothing and Food, namely, 76.8% and 37.17%."

Indian Agent McLeod in a letter dated January 24, 1948, directs our attention to a report submitted by Mr. A. M. Warren, District Manager, Singer Sewing Machine Company, Prince Albert, which report shows that of the sewing machines now in use, one (1) is 43 years old, one (1) 39 years old, one (1) 23 years old, one (1) 26 years old, and one the age of which cannot be ascertained, and another 24 years old. Mr. Warren points out that these machines are in poor condition and few will question this opinion, in view of the fact that they have been operated by Indian pupils over a long period of years, and Indian pupils have never been noted for their interest in or care of Government property. If we are going to be at all realistic about these matters, we might as well face the fact that all the churches engaged in the operation of residential schools,
schools, with perhaps the single exception of the Church of England, have found it impossible during the war period, and even at this date, to secure boys' and girls' clothing to the extent necessary to meet their actual needs. This matter has been brought to my attention almost weekly during the last seven or eight-year period.

I must state that I have been and still am greatly disturbed with the condition of a number of our residential school buildings and lack of equipment at these schools. To enrol Indian pupils at residential schools and to refuse to supply them with the equipment necessary to engage in a worthwhile course of academic and vocational instruction is, in my judgment, a sheer waste of public funds. In this connection, I am sending forward for your information a copy of a letter received by Dr. Moore from Dr. L. B. Pett. I may state that immediately following the receipt of this letter I had a conference with Dr. Moore and Dr. Pett. The discussion at this conference indicated the appalling lack of equipment at the schools visited by the official of the Department of National Health and Welfare.

It is our intention, now that the Superintendent of Training is no longer responsible for administration in the Welfare Division, to work out a standard program for Indian residential schools. In this program provision should be made for -

(a) - A worthwhile course in academic and vocational instruction -

(b) - An agreement with the Churches whereby all teachers employed will be fully qualified academically and professionally -

(c) - Schools to be visited and inspected at least twice annually - once by the Public School Inspector as now, and once by a representative of the department, preferably the official now responsible for the promotion and supervision of vocational courses at Indian schools.

.. It is my
It is my intention to recommend also that following the sittings of the Special Parliamentary Committee a contract containing these and other proposals be entered into by the department with the Churches now engaged in the operation of residential schools.

Director.
Dr. P.E. Moore,
Director,
Indian Health Services.

Re: Our food service assistance to residential schools

Dear Dr. Moore:

In 1945 you secured some assistance on menus and diets in certain schools and I offered continuous service when it could be arranged. This was finally arranged with the assignment of one of my nutritionists, full time, beginning in September, 1946. Three steps have been taken:

(1) A poster drawing contest was sponsored, with cash prizes. My Division spent about $4,000.00 on this and was successful in receiving a great deal of information on how Indians think about food, as well as in giving Indian schools the idea that food is important.

(2) A course for cooks and for Indian girls who might be able to serve as assistant cooks was held at Lebret in July, 1947. This course cost this Division about $500.00 and much more to the Branch. As shown in the accompanying Appendix many of those who attended are not now in a position to use the instruction, and only 1 person out of 39 is known to be using it. This unsatisfactory result is due to several factors, including the method of choosing candidates for the course, and the lack of support from principals and other administrators.

(3) Inspections of Indian Residential Schools were begun in order to help cooks to provide more nutritious meals. Detailed reports were made on dietary shortcomings, facilities in the school and other problems. In 13 schools a re-visit has now been made, nearly a year later, and practically no improvement has been found. To date this work has cost us about $5,000.00.

The following comments may be made from visiting 38 residential schools:

(a) no school was doing a good feeding job;

(b) a lack of mechanical equipment makes necessary the use of much student time on other than instruction;

(c) a lack of coordinated plans for the farm to supply the school meals has caused the purchase of foods which could have been raised; this increases the cost of an adequate diet and makes
our recommendations result in a demand for money when the need is actually for a policy that combines the farm both with the training and the food supply.

(d) The cook frequently lacks training and is thus not able to take advantage of our assistance; efforts to correct this by a cook's course were not successful (see 2 above);

(e) the methods used in Indian Residential Schools as reflected in their food services do not appear to be fitting Indians for their usual return to the reserve (e.g., ignoring local foods and food habits) nor for proper understanding of white procedures.

Conclusions

1. No further visits to Indian Residential Schools appear likely to be useful since there is no value in knowing that another school is below standard nutritionally, and little benefit can be measured from these visits.

2. Emphasis on informing the cooks, rather than the farm managers, Principals, religious administrations, Indian Agents etc., appears to have been a mistake. I suggest that Indian Affairs arrange a conference or series of conferences for these people to discuss food and other problems.

3. Better coordination of farm with food supplies and training is needed for the most economical and practical feeding to be done.

4. Lack of proper equipment is a serious handicap in most places, but since this seems to apply to the whole school it is not just a food matter.

Recommendations

I propose to change our food advice to Indian Residential Schools in the following ways:

1. Continue such contacts as now exist, by correspondence and sending of materials from time to time.

2. Discuss nutrition problems with Principals and others in so far as this is made possible by Conferences called by the proper authorities. One of the purposes of such discussions would be to evolve with their help sets of menus and tests of foods to be provided which could be priced locally and covered by a sufficient money grant in relation to the development of the farm. This need for uniform directions appears to be fundamental to developing good feeding at the schools; it requires planning and coordination at all levels of administration, not the "hot-potato" approach now in effect.
3. Make a demonstration project of at least two schools provided that cooperation of the Indian Affairs Branch and all others concerned can be secured. The schools in mind are the Mohawk Institute, Brantford, and the Edmonton Residential School, for reasons concerned with my own staff and other activities in 1948.

The project would be a long term matter involving several years. A complete nutrition survey of all children would be carried out. Any essential renovation of the kitchen would have to be carried out, as well as assurance of money for the menus, so as to get first-class feeding. Further clinical and statistical studies would be carried out at 6 month or yearly intervals.

In one school it would be possible to study the effects of foods containing added vitamins and minerals. My attitude on this topic, which you raised with me recently, is that there is need for small scale study of any results that can be achieved before launching a wide program in the North. It is a remarkable fact that food fortification was launched in the United States and a few other countries without any such study. Even after several years there is no clear evidence. It seems to me important to have a better indication that is now available on how to achieve the results desired.

I hope that you will comment on these ideas when we meet this Wednesday.

Yours sincerely,

(Signed) L.B. Pett,

L.B. Pett, Ph.D., M.D.,
Chief, Nutrition Division.

Re: Duck Lake Indian Residential School

Enclosed herewith please find form 37 listing thereon cooking and refrigeration equipment required for the above named Indian Residential School.

I. Cooking Kitchen Range.

The present range now in use is badly burnt out and the entire top has become badly warped with the results that a new stove is required. Cooking range now in use is a two fire box, three oven type, coal burner, No. 203, C. F. Model, "John Bull" made by the Gurney Foundry Company, Toronto Ontario.

The Principal of the Duck Lake School would appreciate our purchasing either an Electric Range of the same capacity or a coal burner with automatic stoker. I have checked over the stove now in use and find that it is beyond repair and requires replacing.

In view of the model of the range required being a very large type I am unable to submit quotations from local sources and I believe that our Purchasing Agent will be in a position to secure quotations from firms manufacturing cook stoves in the size and capacity required for the Duck Lake School.

Attendance at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School now totals 225 pupils and the staff totals approximately 25 therefore the cooking range required should be of a capacity to prepare meals for the number shown.

2. Refrigeration

The additional refrigeration equipment is required to provide necessary refrigeration in connection with preservation of perishable food supplies especially milk, butter, eggs and meat. The present refrigerator is really too small and requires freezing temperatures for meats whereas low temperatures is not required for other food supplies such as milk, eggs etc., when I visited the school on May 18th, I found that substantial quantities of perishable food supplies could not be accommodated in the locker and the refrigerator now in use was filled beyond capacity with additional supplies being cooled in rather unsanitary manner due to limited space for this purpose and I believe that the additional refrigeration is badly needed to assist with the proper handling of the necessary supplies that are required.
In connection with moving the present motor that operates refrigeration equipment into the Boiler room. This move is necessary as the motor is housed in a small building outside the main building and is subject to extreme cold in the winter months with the result that the motor does not function properly; by moving the motor into the main boiler room this trouble in connection with operation of the motor in cold weather conditions would be eliminated.

All quotations shown were furnished to the Duck Lake Indian Residential School by the Electric Shop, Prince Albert, Saskatchewan. It is presumed that this firms quotations would be in line with other firms and in view of local firms being unable to supply or submit quotations the enclosures are submitted for approval.

I recommend that the expenditure be approved providing our Branch Officials can provide the finances to cover the expenditure.

With reference to Department letter of the 14th of May, 1949, File 652-5 (E.I.), and my letter dated June 14th, 1949, File 1434-6-8-109, in connection with the installation of the refrigeration equipment at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School, I visited this school on June 18th, accompanied by Indian Superintendent McLeod and Mr. C.A.F. Clark.

With regard to (1) in the Department letter referred to, while the cost is somewhat more than a walk-in refrigerator of the same capacity, the Principal wishes to have the refrigerator at one end of the dining-room and the kitchen, and the location of the present refrigerator is very awkwardly situated with respect to the dining room and the kitchen. If in the dining room, the refrigerator becomes a part of the dining room, and therefore should be ornamental as well as practical. It is the intention to use it for milk and butter, mostly, as the other refrigerator is suitable for meat and vegetables, but cannot be used for milk and butter without tainting them.

With reference to (2), the refrigerator suggested will not reduce the size of the dining room floor space, as it is to be installed under a stairway which has to remain, and will be taking the place of a cupboard now constructed under the stairway, for storage of brooms, etc.

With regard to (3), the cost of moving the present refrigerator unit to a place convenient to the dining room and kitchen would be nearly as much as the construction of a new one, but I am of the opinion that the old one is quite serviceable where it is, and a new one should be added at the point mentioned at the end of the dining room.

Again referring to (2)...........
Again referring to (2), and that part thereof which refers to 300 yds. of expensive linoleum in the dining room, this linoleum has not been laid, and will not be laid on the dining room floor, which is in the basement of the building, and concrete. It is not needed there, and will be a source of trouble, through moisture, if it is laid on that floor. Father Latour would like permission to use it in other parts of the same building. In my opinion it is not very necessary to lay linoleum on most of the remainder of the building where the floors are of hardwood, and there are other schools where it is needed worse than the Duck Lake School, if it is decided that it should not be laid on the dining room floor at the Duck Lake School.

Please instruct me further in connection with the linoleum.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.
