Dear Sir:

The following extracts from the Boiler & Pressure Vessel Act 1948, are particularly drawn to your attention.

Section 14 An inspection certificate may set forth repairs or alterations to be made in, upon or in connection with any boiler, pressure vessel or plant, and the owner shall cause such repairs to be executed forthwith.

Section 17 Every inspection certificate shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the plant or near the boiler or pressure vessel to which it relates and shall be produced by the owner or other person responsible for or in immediate charge of such boiler, pressure vessel or plant upon demand of an inspector.

Section 20 (1) No owner shall cause or permit any high pressure boiler or steam plant to be operated unless:
(a) a chief engineer who holds a certificate entitling him to operate such boiler or steam plant as chief engineer, and who is not responsible for the operation of any other boiler or steam plant, is responsible for and personally supervises the operation thereof; and
(b) either such chief engineer or a shift engineer who holds a certificate entitling him to operate such boiler or steam plant as shift engineer is in immediate charge thereof and the chief engineer, shift engineer or some other person acting under the direct supervision of the chief engineer or shift engineer is in personal attendance on the boiler at all times, whether or not any such boiler is equipped with automatic control.

(2) Subject to subsection (3), no owner shall cause or permit any low pressure boiler or steam plant having a capacity of twenty horse power or more to be operated unless a person who holds a certificate entitling him to operate such boiler or steam plant is responsible for the operation thereof and in personal attendance thereon at all times.

(3) A low pressure boiler having a capacity of not more than seventy-five horse power which is equipped with an automatic low-water cut-out device approved by an inspector and designed to shut off the fuel fire in the event of low water, may be left unattended and in operation for a period not exceeding ten consecutive hours if:
(a) the safety valve is set to relievel at not more than fifteen pounds to the square inch;
(b) the safety valve and automatic low-water cut-out device are tested daily to ensure their efficient operation;
(c) the automatic low-water cut-out device is installed in such manner that it cannot be rendered inoperative by the manipulation of any manual control or regulating apparatus and the water column, water glass and the float chamber of the cut-out device may be thoroughly blown out each day.

Section 27 Every owner of a boiler, pressure vessel or plant shall provide and keep at all times in a readily accessible location an adequately equipped first aid kit for the treatment of minor injuries and shall produce such first aid kit upon demand of an inspector.

MEMORANDUM FOR THE SUPERINTENDENT GENERAL.

Referring to Mr. Hillyard Mitchell's letter of the 26th ultimo herewith, the undersigned would state, for the information of the Superintendent General, that,

On the 21st December 1891 the Bishop of Saskatchewan made application for an Industrial School in the Saskatchewan District, to be under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church, and recommended Duck Lake as the best location for it.

On the 5th March 1892 His Lordship was informed that the best the Government could do at present was to begin, in a small way, the establishment of a Boarding School at the point recommended by him, viz., Duck Lake, which could, in time, be increased.

On the 5th of July 1892 the Department of the Interior reserved the N. E. 1/4 of Sec. 16, Tp 44, R 2, West of the 3rd M., for school purposes.

In the Supplementary Estimates for the current year Parliament voted for the establishment of a Boarding School at Duck Lake the sum of $4000, viz.,

Buildings--------$2,000.00
Furnishing------1,000.00
Maintenance-----1,000.00

The Superintendent General will observe from this
this and the correspondence on file herewith that the proposed school is to be a Boarding School, and not an Industrial School, and also that the location decided upon is at Duck Lake, and further, that it was stated in the Supplementary Estimates, when Parliament voted the $4000, that the School was to be a Boarding School, and that it was to be located at Duck Lake.

The Superintendent General will see from the small sketch on file of the location of the Reserves in the Duck Lake and Carlton Agencies that the great majority of the Indians in the vicinity of Duck Lake are returned as Roman Catholics, while the bulk of the population in the Carlton District, where (viz. Muskeg Lake) Mr. Mitchell says the Roman Catholics are endeavouring to have the proposed school established, are Protestant.

In deciding upon the location of the School in question, this, of course, was one of the chief reasons for choosing Duck Lake. MEMORANDUM FOR THE INFORMATION OF THE SUPERINTENDENT GENERAL.

Referring to letter from Bishop Pascal, dated at Aix Province, on 30th October last, in which His Lordship requested that operations relative to the proposed Boarding School in the vicinity of Duck Lake should be deferred until His Lordship should have an opportunity of interviewing the Department regarding the site, the undersigned begs to report that some few days ago His Lordship, accompanied by the Rev. Father LaCombe, called and discussed the matter.

The undersigned advanced reasons approved by yourself why the site should not be changed to any distance from Duck Lake, and their force was admitted by His Lordship, who agreed that the school should be built near Duck Lake, requesting, however, that it be placed on Roman Catholic Church property there.

The Church will sell for the purpose from 100 to 160 acres of Mission property, as may be required, and take good lands in payment therefor, valuing its lands at $3.00 per acre, and agreeing to take Government lands in exchange.

Since the reasons which determined the Department to select a site near the village of Duck Lake would have induced it to choose land yet nearer to the village than the 1/4 Section reserved, (N.E. 1/4 Sec.16, Tp
Tp 44, R. 2, W. 3rd I.M.), could a suitable one have been obtained; and moreover, by adoption of the proposed location on the Mission there will be additional advantages in the way of use of Mission buildings, and increased supervision and assistance from the Mission staff.

It will be observed that we have the 1/4 Section hereinbefore described set apart for the school, and available for purposes of exchange.

It is recommended, as agreed upon between His Lordship and myself, that Mr. Assistant Indian Commissioner Forget be the arbiter as to value of land to be given in exchange.

Memorandum:

Exchange of lands for those required for Duck Lake School, North-west Territories.

---------------------

The question I am asked to advise on is whether a patent should issue to La Corporation Episcopale Catholique Romaine de la Saskatchewan. The facts of the case as shown on file are that:

1st In 1893 it was determined to erect an Industrial School in the District of Saskatchewan; and it was finally decided that it should be erected at Duck Lake upon lands which the Vicar Apostolique administered on behalf of la Corporation des Oblats de Nordouest and la Corporation Apostolique Catholique Romaine de la Saskatchewan.

2nd The Vicar Apostolique was willing to surrender to the Government one hundred acres in exchange for other lands to be allotted to him out of public lands.

3rd Before it was decided what lands should be given in exchange the Bishop transferred and there was forwarded to the Department a certificate of ownership, dated the 31st May, 1894, issued to the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs and comprising legal sub-division 43 and west half of the legal sub-division 2 of Section 4, in Township 44, in Range 2, west of the 3rd Meridian, containing one hundred acres.

4th By Order in Council, dated 14th January, 1895, on recommendation
recommendation of the Minister of the Interior, there was approval given to the transfer to the Department of Indian Affairs of the South-west quarter of Section 4, and the South-west quarter of Section 14, both in Township 44, Range 20, West of the second principal meridian, in the District of Saskatchewan, for the purpose of effecting an exchange of these lands with la Corporation des Oblats du Nord-ouest and la Corporation Episcopale Catholique Romaine de la District of Saskatchewan respectively for lands given by these Corporations for the purpose of an Indian Industrial School at Duck Lake.

5th By Order in Council of 22nd February, 1897, the North-east quarter of Section 4, Township 44, Range 25, West of the second Meridian, was substituted for the South-east quarter of Section 14, named in the Order in Council of 14th January, 1895.

There is no doubt that there should be given to the two Corporations named in the Order in Council of 14th January, 1895, the legal title to the lands allotted to them respectively by the intent of that Order in Council and the Order in Council of 22nd February, 1897. La Corporation des Oblats du Nord-ouest should have a legal title to the South-west quarter of Section 4, Township 44, Range 20, West of the second meridian, Saskatchewan, and la Corporation Episcopale Romaine de Saskatchewan should have a legal title to the North-east quarter of Section 4, Township 44, Range 25, West of the second Meridian, Saskatchewan.

The question of what legal steps are to be taken to satisfactorily adjust the titles of the Crown to the lands of the Industrial School and the title of the two Corporations to the lands which it is intended to convey to them is one by no means free from doubt, and as it affects another as well as this Department, it appears one proper to be referred to the Department of Justice.
As a matter of conveyancing I think that as the lands to be exchanged with the two Corporations were Dominion lands the lands given in exchange should have been conveyed to the Crown at an express consideration of $320.00 in order that they might be held under the Dominion Lands Act and under Section 31 of that Act His Excellency in Council should have appropriated the desired hundred acres for the purposes of an Indian Boarding School; and that under Section 29 of the Dominion Lands Act there should have been sold to each Corporation respectively for an express consideration of $160.00 the lands intended to be conveyed to them.

It appears to me that the Order in Council of 14th January, 1895, does not come within Section 31 of the Dominion Lands Act, and does not constitute a reserve for Indians under Section 90 of the Dominion Lands Act, and I am at a loss to ascertain in what way it is possible for this Department to use the machinery provided by the Indian Act to carry out the apparent intention of the Order in Council of 14th January, 1895.

I consider that it will be necessary to adjust titles; and I recommend that the Department of Justice be asked to advise as to the requisite steps.

(Sgd) Reginald Rimmer.
Law Clerk.

Ottawa, 3rd April, 1900.

My dear Sir Wilfrid,

Referring to your note of the 26th ultimo, addressed to Mr. Smart, covering a letter from His Lordship Bishop Pascal of Prince Albert, with regard to the issue of patents for certain lands taken in exchange for those required in connection with the Duck Lake School, I beg to state that the facts in this case would appear to be as follows:

In the month of May, 1894, after it had been decided to erect an Industrial School at Duck Lake, His Lordship, on behalf of La Corporation des Oblats du Nord Ouest and La Corporation Apostolique Catholique Romaine de la Saskatchewan, transferred to the Department of Indian Affairs, as a site for the proposed School, one hundred acres of Section 4, Township 44, Range 2, West of the 3rd Meridian, His Lordship agreeing to take in exchange the South West quarter of Section 4 and the South East quarter of Section 14, Township 44, Range 20, West of the 2nd Meridian. to this arrangement was passed on the 14th January, 1895.

On the 29th September, 1896, Mr. Forget, who was then Indian Commissioner at Regina, addressed a letter to the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, in which he stated that His Lordship had written to ask that in the event of the patents for the South West quarter of 4 and the South East quarter of 14, above mentioned, not having been issued, he desired to have substituted for the quarter-section last named the North East quarter of Section 4, Township 44, Range 25, West of the 2nd Meridian. Mr. Forget, in his letter, strongly recommended His Lordship's request to the favourable consideration of the Department, as the quarter-section asked for was of equal value to the one which His Lordship wished to surrender. The former being available, an Order in Council was passed on the 23rd February, 1897, substituting the same for the South East quarter of Section 14, and the latter has since been acquired as a homestead by one Charles Thompson.

In the face of these facts, I am inclined to think that His Lordship must be under a misapprehension with regard to the matter, when he states that the Department should have been held to the terms of the Order in Council of the 14th January, 1895, as these terms were subsequently changed at his own
own request. However, I may add that patents for the South West quarter of Section 4, Township 44, Range 30, and the North East quarter of Section 4, Township 44, Range 25, West of the 2nd Meridian, were issued on the 31st ultimo, and His Lordship has been advised accordingly, and as the South East quarter of Section 14 has been disposed of to Mr. Thompson as a homestead, I am afraid that the matter cannot very well be reopened. It is possible also that Bishop Pascal may have overlooked the amendment which was made to the original arrangement by the Order in Council of February, 1897, and that he may now consider the present settlement as satisfactory.

In the Western Provinces the Indian boarding schools are all conducted under the auspices of the different churches and nearly all are owned by the churches; any not owned by the churches are owned by the Government. A new arrangement has recently been entered into between the Department of Indian Affairs and the church authorities conducting the various boarding schools, under which the schools are to conform to a certain specified standard of excellence as regards buildings, equipment, sanitary arrangements and maintenance. On conforming to this standard the Government-owned schools will receive a per capita grant of $100 per annum, and the church-owned schools will receive a per capita grant of $125 per annum.

The Dusk Lake school is at present Government-owned, and if brought up to the standard would be entitled to the $100 grant, but if church-owned would be entitled to the $125 grant. Present conditions at that school do not, however, conform to the standard. The water supply, drainage, accommodation for the isolation of pupils afflicted with infectious diseases or tuberculosis, &c., &c., require to be improved, involving an estimated expenditure of $20,000.00.

The church authorities have agreed to assume the expense of bringing the school up to the standard in consideration of being allowed to acquire possession of the property on payment of $300 for the site, and of the receipt of the per capita grant of $125 per annum allowed to church-owned schools. This arrangement is considered most advantageous to the Department. It may here be stated that, although this school is at present Government-owned, the authorities of the Roman Catholic Church,
under whose auspices the school is conducted, have contributed largely towards the construction of the buildings.

The said sum of three hundred dollars has been deposited to the credit of the Receiver General on account of Casual Revenue for the purpose above referred to, by the church authorities, who request that the deed for the property be made out in favour of Les Revêrends Peres Oblats de Marie Immaculée des Territoires du Nord Ouest.

The undersigned would recommend that authority be now given for the disposal of the said school property to the Roman Catholic Church authorities for the purpose of the said school.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

With reference to the letter from the Rev. Principal of the Duck Lake Indian Residential School, I wish to report concerning the history of this institution.

In 1894 the Department secured from the Oblate Fathers 100 acres (L.S. 3 and 4 and W. ½ L.S. 2 of Sec. 4, T. 44, R. 2, W. 3rd) and assisted the Church in the erection of the buildings. The institution, which opened for pupils in 1894, was placed as a government-owned boarding school. The consideration for the site was one half section of land worth roughly $600, which was deeded to the Oblate Fathers under authority of R.C. No. 345, February 22, 1897. In 1896-7 the Church authorities spent about $10,000 on buildings. At this time the Government had made a total capital expenditure of $20,775. In 1911 there was a change in status. The Church, undertaking to make replacements to buildings, received a transfer of the property - the site of 100 acres and a state equity in the buildings for a consideration of $500. The authority for this transfer was R.C. 991 dated May 10, 1911.

For 13 years the Duck Lake Indian Residential School has been church-owned and has received the per capita grant for that type of institution.

The Department is preparing to replace the old main building with a modern institution and the Rev. Principal is requesting that we purchase the outbuildings, equipment, stock and the farm of 700 acres. With reference to the outbuildings I consider the only valuable structure is the horse stable erected two years ago. The farm equipment and stock also are of considerable value. 385 acres of the farm are cultivated and are, of course, valuable.

As the Department is offering to take over capital expense and to erect a modern school, I feel that the Church should give us the outbuildings, equipment and stock. This is in harmony with the practice of Church authorities in the past. It is preferable to a fixed arrangement in the case of the Duck Lake Indian Residential School, as the Department has already borne over $21,000 capital expense. I also consider that the Church authorities should transfer the 700 acre farm at a more or less nominal price, say $10 per acre. The original 100 acre school farm has grown to a 700 acre property; but all through the years the institution was not only assisted by grants for capital expense but received per capita earnings from parliamentary appropriation.

Supt. of Indian Education.
Sir:-

Now that the contract for the Duck Lake Boarding School has been placed, it is very important that the placing of these buildings should be carefully considered. On no account should they be in close proximity to the existing buildings, which are more or less of a fire trap, and should they catch fire there would be great danger of this new and expensive building being destroyed.

In the second place, if this school is placed in close proximity to the old buildings, it will spoil the whole effect of the appearance of the new building.

These matters should be considered carefully, in my opinion.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a Report, dated 10th December, 1924, from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, submitting the desirability of the purchase, by the Department of Indian Affairs, of the Duck Lake Indian Residential School farm and improvements thereon from the Roman Catholic Church.

The main building at this school has had to be replaced by a modern institution. The property was owned by the Oblate Order and when funds for the building activity were provided in this year's Parliamentary Appropriation for Indian Education, Vote No. 286, negotiations relative to the acquisition of the farm used for school purposes were commenced. It is considered that the Crown should own the property on which the new institution is being erected and which is all necessary for the satisfactory conduct of the institution. The price of $30.00 per acre has been agreed upon, which has been stated by the Indian Commissioner at Regina to be very reasonable. This price includes the out-buildings and other improvements. Most of the farm, other than the hay lands, is improved and has been yielding good crops.

The Honourable
The Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.
Arrangements for the purchase of the property have been completed by the Department of Justice, whose local agents have found satisfactory title to the land in question - 710.75 acres more or less in Townships 43 and 44, Range 2, West of the 3rd Meridian. The farm is in the immediate vicinity of the town of Duck Lake, Saskatchewan.

The Minister states that it is proposed to issue a cheque for the sum of $21,322.50, payable jointly to the agent of the Department of Justice and the vendors, La Corporation des Reverends Peres Oblats de Marie Immaculee des Territoires du Nord Ouest.

The Minister recommends that authority be granted for the purchase of the Duck Lake Indian Residential School by the Department of Indian Affairs on the terms hereinabove mentioned.

The Committee concur in the foregoing recommendation and submit the same for approval.

Clerk of the Privy Council.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter and requisition received from Indian Agent N.J. McLeod in connection with the need for new sewing machines at the Duck Lake Indian Residential School. Also enclosed is copy of a letter from Mr. A.M. Warren, District Manager of the Singer Sewing Machine Company, to Reverend Father Latour, giving his opinion of the present condition of the sewing machines now in use at the school.

While I agree that we have some sewing machines now in use of such an age that they should be replaced, I do not agree that they should all be replaced at once. It will be noted that two of the machines are forty-three years old, and one is thirty-nine years old. Four of them are twenty-three years old, one twenty-four years old, and one twenty-six years old. The age of the remaining four is not known.

In his enthusiasm to promote sales on behalf of his company Mr. Warren would suggest discarding all of the sewing machines to be replaced by new ones. This does not seem reasonable to me. If two Singer sewing machines have been in operation for forty-three years why should not the four which are twenty-three years old be expected to give some more service?

I would recommend that six new machines be purchased for the Duck Lake School, three of which would replace the three very old machines, and the other three to replace three of those in the poorest condition.

Please note the remarks in the last paragraph of Indian Agent McLeod's letter that all of the old sewing machines being replaced by new ones be distributed to Indians. While this may seem a wise move they will be old machines difficult to keep in repair, and the Indians may have reason to complain if given a machine which is broken and cannot be repaired. If the Department decides to purchase the six machines which I have recommended, and distribute the old machines to Indians, I shall enquire further into the distribution of old machines on my next visit to the Duck Lake Agency if so instructed.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies, Saskatchewan.
Ottawa, 18 September 1946.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander,

We agree with the contents of the last paragraph of your letter. If the old machines are in the condition that is stated by the agent, we cannot see why they should be given to Indians.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr Neary:

A few days ago I was receiving a cheque (no.98142) payable to me for the allowance towards the salary of the Manual Training Instructor, Mr. Arsene Tisserand, for the months of February and January. However, on the 6th of March, Mr. Arsene Tisserand, himself was receiving a cheque (no.87876) payable to him for the allowance towards the salary of the Manual Training Instructor for the month of January.

Re: Duck Lake Indian Residential School

Enclosed herewith please find Form #37, listing materials required to erect an addition to the garage and workshop at the rear of the above named school.

The addition is required to allow sufficient space for mechanical training wherein a farm tractor can be accommodated during the winter months and instruction given to young Indian boys in regards to care, repairing and operation. The addition will also permit space for instruction in carpentry, plumbing and heating, also shoe repairing.

I believe this type of training is necessary, especially in view of the farming Indians now becoming equipped with power farming machines. While the addition is not large it will permit of sufficient space for the purpose required and in this manner will permit instructors to give practical demonstrations in care and operation of farm tractors, trucks and all farming equipment now in use and it is also intended to provide facilities for instruction to adult Indians during the winter months.

The Principal of the Duck Lake School is prepared to furnish all labour costs in excess of the amount shown, $225.00, this sum is estimated to cover costs of wages for the services of a competent bricklayer only, the remainder of the work can be completed by his employees.

I personally believe this type of training is necessary and will result in our young Indian boys leaving residential school with a working knowledge of care and maintenance of power farming equipment and I recommend that the expenditure be approved.

Dear Mr R. A. Hoey;

It is with pleasure that I am forwarding to you a sample of goat-cream butter made here at Duck Lake Indian School.

However, I must state that it was not made in a churn. This was tried with the result that after an hour's churning there was no change whatever in the cream. With an egg-beater the butter is made in twenty minutes. So we are inclined to think that the brisk movement is necessary in the making of this butter.

This week nine gallons of milk were passed through the separator giving us two quarts of cream out of which two pounds, two ounces of butter were obtained.

Trusting that the above information may be of some value to you,

I remain,

Yours truly,

Rev. G.M. Latour O.M.I.,
Principal.

Dear Father Latour:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of June 26, in which you intimate that you have sent forward a sample of goat cream butter.

This butter, or what was at one time butter, reached this office a day or so ago. You can imagine the condition of the parcel, however, when I tell you that the temperature here was 31 when it arrived. It would appear that the can in which it was packed leaked somewhat, with the result that the post office people or express people were compelled to change the wrappings. However, a certain amount of the liquid did reach me. It was certainly a mistake to send forward a parcel such as this at this particular season of the year.

Let me assure you, however, that your thoughtfulness and courtesy in remembering me in this way is very much appreciated. I was more than delighted to learn that you had a herd of goats at the school. I am looking forward anxiously to Mr. Morris' report, in which he will no doubt deal fully with the success you have had in the management of this particular herd.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Morris:

The remarks in your Duck Lake report regarding male goats for the Duck Lake and Blue Quills schools have been noted, but we are advised there are no male goats available at Spanish this year; in fact, it appears the goats there were not bred this year due to Brother Grubb being short of help and unable to devote sufficient time to the goats. Dear Mr. Hoey:

Regarding the sending of male goats to the Grouard, Blue Quill and Duck Lake schools as recommended in my reports I wish to make it clear that I never intended that young goats be sent. I do feel that good animals six months old could be sent without any difficulty. These three schools are very interested in the raising of goats to be distributed to needy T.B. Indians and we will have to encourage the project by helping to obtain breeding stock.

I investigated the possibility of obtaining Saanen male goats at Edmonton, Calgary and at any other place where I thought goats could be obtained. This question was very thoroughly discussed with Inspector Schmidt and all the agents I have visited to date and in every case they state that there are no good breeding goats to be had. Mr. Schmidt stated regarding the purchase of goats in British Columbia that there are only a limited number available at a very high price and that in his opinion there has been a great deal of inbreeding already. He was of the opinion that if goats are to make a success of in the Agencies in the West good breeding stock will have to come from Ontario.

I would therefore suggest that Father Primeau be asked to hold a number of good male goats until I return to Ottawa. I will provide him with shipping instructions so that the animals can be shipped, stopping over certain points where the Farm Instructors can feed water and exercise them, so that they will reach their destination without hardship.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) J. E. Morris.
Acknowledging your letter of July 10th, I would recommend that young male goats be retained at Golden Lake for delivery to the above-mentioned schools some time this fall.

It is regretted that the pure bred herd at Spanish was not bred last year. If Brother Grubb is unable to devote sufficient time to look after this herd of goats it might be well to consider moving them to some other place. I might inform you that many of the Agents are very interested in the securing of goats to supply milk to Indians, and as there are very few pure bred herds in the West it will most likely be necessary to obtain goats in Ontario. It is therefore important that the herd at Spanish be bred this year and goats available for delivery next year.

Yours very truly,

J.E. Morris.

Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Superintendent of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ontario.
REPORT ON DUCK LAKE AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF JUNE, 1944.

Livestock:

Eight head of cattle died during the month and four head of horses. Cause of death of cattle, 1 cow drowned in water hole, 4-2 year old heifers died calving, three died by Blackfly Malady. Two horses died of old age, two mares died at time of foaling. Season calf crop reported as satisfactory increase. Large number of cows being milked and cream shipped to creameries. To-date we have had no report on Tuberculosis test of cattle on Beardy's Reserve conducted by Health of Animals Branch, Department of Agriculture during month of April. Dr. A.B. Gibson, Veterinary, who conducted this test states there were no losses and reasons for delay in submitting his report is due to his time being devoted to a serious malady affecting large herds of cattle in the Prince Albert District during the month caused by infections from Black Flies, approximately 100 head of cattle died in the area surrounding Prince Albert, Sask. during the month from this Malady. Losses on the reserves in this Agency from the same malady totals 3 head only.

On May 18, 1944 Dr. A.B. Gibson, of the Health of Animals Division, Department of Agriculture, tested the Duck Lake Indian School herd for Bangs Disease, 65 head tested. Eleven proved Positive, twenty-two proved Questionable and the remaining thirty-two were negative. On June 23rd a six weeks retest of all Questionable and Negative animals was due. To-date we have no report on this retest, which was conducted by Dr. Gibson on June 23rd.

N.J. McLeod,
Act. Indian Agent.
REPORT ON DUCK LAKE INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF JULY, 1944.

Livestock:

No losses of Indian owned cattle reported. Department Ball Knock Hill Grafter #222215, Roan Shorthorn, age 6 years died on John Smith's Reserve. Full report on cause of death will be forwarded under separate cover. Large number of cows are being milked and butter making for home use. Also cream being shipped to Creameries. Serum Test report of blood samples taken from the Duck Lake Indian School herd by Dr. A.B. Gibson, Health of Animals Division, on July 1, 1944 for Bangs Disease. Of the 54 head tested the report showed as follows: 13 animals proved positive, 13 proved questionable and the remaining 28 were negative. A further retest is to be conducted by Dr. Gibson in 30 days. In the meantime positive and questionable animals are kept separate from remainder of herd pending this retest.

N.J. McLeod,
Act. Indian Agent.
Ottawa, July 10, 1944.

RE: GOATS.

You are authorized to buy sixteen female goats at fourteen dollars each ($14.00) and six male goats at ten dollars ($10.00) each from the Rev. Mr. Jones; payment to be made out of the Welfare Vote. You are also authorized to purchase two female goats and one male goat from Father Rivard at twenty-five dollars for the three animals.

This herd is to be established at Norway House; the milk to be used for tubercular patients and the children of families who are unable to provide milk.

There has been considerable inbreeding in this herd; therefore, you are requested to separate the males at the earliest possible date. Probably you can arrange to pasture them on another island until they are distributed. The male goat purchased from Father Rivard should be used with this herd.

One male goat has already been sent to Island Lake. The others should be disposed of as follows:

One to Father Trudeau to establish a herd at Cross Lake.

One to Indian Agent Lovell at The Pas.
(Note: It is suggested that this goat be sent there by aeroplane when Dr. Yule next visits Norway House.)

Two good billies should be selected -

One to be sent to the Duck Lake Indian Residential School,
Duck Lake, Saskatchewan.
One to the Blue Quill School in Alberta.

It is suggested that you write to Father George Letour, Duck Lake, Saskatchewan, and Father L.C. Letour, St. Paul, Alberta, asking them to provide you with the proper shipping instructions.

- Over -
I understand they will not bring goats out on the "Kensura" until after the tourist season is over; therefore these two goats most likely will be shipped the later part of September or the first of October. In my opinion, it might be wise to send these goats via Prince Albert; the one for Duck Lake could be transported from there by truck, the one for the Blue Quill School could be placed off at a station on the main line to Edmonton. If this is done the goats will be delivered in the shortest possible time.

Dear Doctor Touchet:

Henry Peeteetuce, aged 8 years, was reviewed here yesterday. The father gave a rather unusual story. The boy developed severe head ache on June 6th, which lasted three days. This headache was very severe causing the boy to cry. During the same time he vomited immediately after eating. They also noticed at this time that he had convergence of the eyes. The headache has gradually improved and the vomiting has ceased. The eyes are still converged. The boy is very irritable.

Physical examination and X-ray revealed no change in the chest over that reported to you on May 27th. Examination of the eyes showed the left eye to be converging inwards and had much poorer sight than the right. Examination of the fundi showed the most extensive choked discs we have ever seen. Examination of the other cranial nerves showed no paresis. The knee jerks were absent or very difficult to elicit on both sides. The Babinski test was markedly positive on both sides. Lateral film of the skull showed separation of the frontal suture. Spinal puncture was not done.

In view of the history, the ocular paresis, the choked discs, the positive Babinski and separation of the frontal suture indicating increased intracranial pressure, we think there is some intracranial involvement. As the boy is tuberculous, this most probably is a tuberculoma. If so, nothing much in the way of treatment can be done. Although, in some centers operative work is attempted but I do not believe with very good results.

Yours truly,

Signed: C.H. Andrews, M.D.
for Medical Superintendent.

**File Hills Boarding School**

**Situation**
This School is situated on Little Black Bear Reserve in the File Hills Agency, Treaty No. 4. The Post Office address is Qui Appell Assa.

**Religion**
It is a Presbyterian School conducted under the auspices of the Presbyterian Church authorities, but more especially under the control of the W. F. M. S. of that Church.

**Land**
The Land in connection with the school consists of the North half of Sec. 32, Township 22, Range 11, West of the 2nd Meridian, and also all that part of Sec. 33, in the same Township which is outside the boundaries of the Okanese Indian Reserve, the whole comprising about 200 acres of land or less.

Buildings

The buildings in connection with the Boarding School include the following viz.
Buildings (Continued)

Viz., the Home which is built of stone with mansard roof, 30 x 30 ft sq., the walls being 20 ft high & 18 inches thick. It consists of three floors.

The 1st contains the kitchen, dining room, hall and cellar.

The 2nd floor contains bedrooms, parlor and school room.

The 3rd floor contains two dormitories, one for boys and one for girls.

The School Room situated about 15 yards to the West of the Home is a frame building on a stone foundation, 34 ft long and 16 ft wide with a porch in front which is used as a wash room. There is also a log building used as a play room by the pupils, an ice house, driving house and stables.

Accommodation, Heating

There is ample accommodation for twenty pupils. The buildings are heated by stoves. There is an abundant supply of water convenient.

Cost of Buildings

The Mission Home building was built in 1888 at a cost of $15,500 of which amount the Department paid the sum of $13,500. The balance of the cost of the buildings was paid by the Presbyterian Church authorities. The total amount contributed & paid by the Dept.

Dear Mr. Scott;

I think we have discovered a suitable farmer for File Hills. His name is James Montgomery, and he is from Camilla, Ont., in the neighborhood of Orangeville; has a farm of his own; a married man with no children of his own, but an adopted boy who is about eight years of age. His age is 41, and he seems to be a man of good health, and is of medium size. I have made enquiries from those who know him, and all speak of him as a man whose influence in the neighborhood has always been good, and a farmer who has always kept his farm in good condition; buildings and everything being in good repair. I would judge from his appearance and the reports that I have received that he belongs to one of those families we sometimes find in a neighborhood that stand out somewhat from the average, and who are always called upon to do any special work that needs to be done. This man's father was of that type, and he seems to have inherited his father's temperament. He is the Superintendent of the Sunday School, and has been the Secretary and Treasurer of some organization out amongst the farmers. That type of man that we can usually build upon to do his best.

He came in to see me, and I got one or two others to meet him all of whom were favorably impressed. I was also interested in noticing the carefulness with which he sought to know everything about the situation before deciding. His wife has been a teacher for some years, and should occasion arise perhaps might be of service in filling a vacancy until a successor was secured. He goes West with the hope of making himself of sufficient value to the Government to merit promotion some day. That is a laudable attitude for any man taking up such a situation. He will sell his farm here, and has been perplexed as to whether or not he should take with him his furniture. If sold by auction, it would probably be sacrificed. I have written to Miss Cunningham asking whether or not it would be better in her judgment to take furniture with him and thus to furnish his own house.

I had a letter from Dr. Farquharson of the 9th January, in which is the following sentence from Miss Cunningham;
"It seems the Department is resolved to appoint a married man; building a house for him, and give him a salary of $600 per year, to be taken out of the per capita allowance." Do we understand that the house is to be taken out of the per capita allowance, as well as the increased salary? One would like to have a definite understanding upon these points.

My expectation is that Mr. Montgomery will make the farm more than pay its way, assuming that there will be no frosts or hail-storms, against which no man can protect himself. As soon as I hear from you, and if Mr. Scott's appointment is approved, I shall inform him. He would like to begin at once to dispose of his property, in order to get there with the opening of the spring. I feel hopeful that we have found the man that is wanted.

I am,

Yours sincerely,

Sir,

I beg to report that I am informed indirectly that there is to be a change in the Principalship of the File Hills Boarding school in about three months' time and I take this opportunity of advising the Department that unless a thoroughly competent man is appointed to the position, the school, which is capable of accommodating sixty pupils, will never be more than half filled.

At one time this school was one of the best managed institutions in the country. I speak of the time when it was under the management of Miss Gillespie. The pupils who were turned out had a thorough training in all lines of farm work, and when they returned to the reserves the result of this training was soon evident. At that time conditions under which children were obtained were far more difficult than they are today.

I regret very much that I cannot give you a good report on this school. It has fallen away very much, in fact, it is far from what it should be. For the last two months there has been no Farming Instructor, and the man who was sent up from Toronto was not a success. He had no discipline or authority and besides, was sickly and complained about the hours, although the position is an easy one to fill from a work standpoint.

I regret to report a sad drowning accident which occurred at the Pine Hills Boarding School on Friday, Nov. 1st. About five o'clock in the afternoon three little boys, from 7 to 10 years of age, were playing on the bank of the lake close to the building. One of them, Archie Feather, 7 years old, had a hand sleigh and was running on the thin ice quite close to the shore, and from what I can gather he was pushed out on the ice by the other boys. The ice being quite thin, in fact too thin to be safe at any point, the sleigh and lad went through. The alarm was at once given and it was only from six to ten minutes before the lad was taken out of the water and every effort made to revive life, but without effect. I at once reported the matter to the Coroner who decided it was not necessary to hold an inquest.

The parents of the child feel very keenly about the matter and think there was gross carelessness on the part of those in charge of the school in allowing children of this age entrusted to their care to play near a lake, especially when the ice is just forming. The Principal tells me he warned the children in the morning and again at noon not to go on the ice.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
I would point out that warning children of this age is of very little avail unless there is someone having direct supervision over them, our of doors as well as when they are indoors.

I wish once more to bring to the Department's notice the fact that there is no Instructor or outside men at this Institution and that the children are not getting the supervision or training they should get. This is the third time I have brought this matter to your notice and I trust the Church can be induced to attend to it at once. It seems to me too bad that after such a large outlay of money as was spent on this building that the Department does not insist on its being properly managed.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the above date and number stating that you had received through Chief Inspector Campbell two communications from Dr. Hall, in which he states that Douglas Bear was granted his discharge from the school by me notwithstanding that he was in such a state of health that he required careful nursing. Your letter states further that the Doctor's correspondence tends to show that this boy should not have been discharged from school unless proper provision was made for him in his home, and that the Department would like a report from me on the matter as soon as possible.

I am sorry you have not favored me with copies of the Doctor's letters so that I would be in a better position to reply to any statements that he has made regarding this particular case.

If Dr. Hall has led you to believe that this pupil was discharged from the school without his full consent all I can say is that he is telling you a deliberate untruth.

The circumstances of the case are as follows:

Douglas Bear was ill, more or less, since early Spring. On Oct. 3rd last Dr. Hart of Indian Head was at the Agency looking after a private patient and I had him go up to the school to examine the boy (at that time Dr. Hall had not been attending the school). Dr. Hart stated it was a case of Tuberculosis.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Tuberculosis When the boy got worse Dr. Hall was called in and made four trips to the school between Oct. 12th and Nov. 19th, during which time and in fact up to Dec. 11th, there was a trained nurse in charge who reported the case to the Doctor every day or so over the phone.

I may say that from the beginning, but more particularly from the time Dr. Hall took charge of the case the parents who are fairly intelligent, especially the father, insisted on having the boy at home and the Doctor was informed of this. They claimed from the beginning that nothing could be done for the boy, and as time went on they would come to my office and make demands for the boy to be released from the school claiming that instead of helping him the Doctor was doing him harm. I did everything in my power to reason with the parents, telling them that White men understood the disease and that everything possible was being done for the boy. This had absolutely no effect and they would leave my office weeping; it was quite pathetic. As the case developed the parents became all the more persistent to have the boy home. Four or five times a week they would come to my back door to see me an hour or so before I was up and I was forced to explain the same thing over and over again. Finally matters got so bad that the parents threatened to go and take the boy out of school whether I wanted it or not. I may say that at intervals all through this difficulty I would call up the Doctor and explain what was going on. I ventured to suggest that as there was no hope for the boy, would it not be as well to let the poor people have him at home.
The Doctor would invariably answer me by saying that he would leave the matter to me. Of course I could not accept the responsibility and told him he was the Doctor and it rested entirely with him. He would follow this up by saying that if the boy was discharged by me he would back up the action, which of course I would not do, and so the matter went on. Later the school people took up the matter with the Doctor and he would tell them to see me. I would talk to the Doctor with the same result; he was willing to discharge the boy but wanted me to take the responsibility.

About a week or ten days before the boy was finally discharged the Nurse came over to my office to say that she had just had a conversation with Dr. Hall on the subject of sending the boy home, and he advised her to come to see me and that he would be agreeable to anything the Principal and myself decided to do. I told the Nurse I would not consent to the boy going out without the Doctor's authority. She could not understand this and finally wound up by saying—asking who would find fault if I did not. The next thing I heard was that the Doctor informed the nurse that he had referred the matter to Ottawa. Why this was done I am unable to understand. All the time this wrangling was going on the unfortunate parents were around imploring to have their boy home and the boy himself expressed a dying wish that he be allowed to go to his parents and die at home. Three days before he died phoned to the Doctor again and said I thought the boy should be allowed to go home as he had not long to live. To my surprise he consented and the boy was taken home and died. I never want to go through another experience of this kind. I think the Doctor showed
showed a lack of good judgment in keeping the boy in spite of the strong opposition of the parents. I think too that he should have known long before he did that it was a hopeless case and that he was injuring the cause of the school by insisting on holding the boy. I am positive there is no law that would uphold such a high-handed action. Every year dozens of such cases arise in the Indians schools and the medical officers allow the children to return home; some recover for the time being, and others succumb.

The position I occupied through the whole affair was most undesirable. I could not and would not take the responsibility of discharging the boy in the face of the doctor's indefinite answers, and yet I felt he was exceeding his authority in holding the boy so he did. I never heard of a doctor, in my experience with Indians, acting as he has done in this case. The parents of the boy complained bitterly to me about his manner and threats he made to them when speaking to him about their boy.

My reason for being so particular about having the doctor's orders and making him take the responsibility was that I knew Dr. Hall well and expected he would act as he has done. If half the reports I hear are true he does a great deal of talking about what he is going to do and I come in for a good share of his abuse. Knowing this I tried to take every precaution so as not to leave myself open, but apparently I have failed, and I think it would be in the interests of the Department, if they have the slightest doubt as to the veracity of my statements, to have this case further enquired into. I am not satisfied and do not wish the matter to rest here as I consider Dr. Hall a dangerous man, which is proven by the fact of his sending just the sort of report I was so particularly to guard against.
I would ask what my powers are with regard to retaining Indian children in schools when they are afflicted affected like this. Even if there were a law to hold them in school, how many parents would stand treatment of this kind?

The medical work here is highly unsatisfactory and I trust the matter will soon be adjusted. I have dealt with this in another letter.

I may say that Dr. Hall is away at present on leave, or I should have called him up and demanded an explanation from him.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Dear Dr. Grant,-

May I call the attention of yourself and Committee to the needs of these Indian reserves- (Pasqua Muscowpetung and Piapot). At present there is no school on or near these reserves and no Protestant Church building. The Presbyterian Church has had an interest here since about 1886- or 7-. When a boarding school was opened and a Mission established also a church building erected. Under Rev. W. S. Moore, an Indian congregation was organized- the membership reached something over forty,- over one hundred Indians were baptized, quite a number of these adults. When the Regina industrial school opened in 1891- forty pupils were drafted from the school here (known as the Lakesend school), Mr. Moore left soon after to take up work elsewhere. Whether it was thought that the Regina school would be sufficient to serve the needs of the reserves or not I cannot say, but for some reason the Lakesend school was closed. After Mr. Moore left there were long intervals - often of several years- when there was no Protestant missionary and no Protestant service of any kind. One or two men gave service for brief periods. When the writer took charge
there had been no service for about 3 years, that is no regular missionary. We found the church building had been destroyed by a prairie fire. Services are conducted now in houses and tepees.

The Indians are asking for a school to be centrally located to serve these three reserves. They have been insisting on this for several years. At one time it was thought that the File Hills boarding school would serve these reserves, i.e., the Protestant Indians, but the parents protest that it is too far away and in the past two years we have only been able to get 3 children from these reserves to File Hills school. There are now about 30 children of school age. The Indians are holding these in hope of a school, which they claim has lately been promised them by Govt. officials. Now it seems that if we are to make any permanent stand here we must have control of the children. Pagans, R. Catholic as well as the Protestant Indians are most friendly and would send their children to their home school. If we do not get these 30 children (and there are many more will be of school age in a short time), most of them will be drafted into the nearest school—the R.C. school at Lebret.

No doubt if a school is voted—and the Indians state that it has been promised them—the Dom. Govt. will erect and equip the building, but likely some
Church will have control. It is evident that if the controlling Church is not ours we might as well abandon these reserves.

A school might be opened this winter say after New Years by making use of the old agency buildings on the Muscowpetung reserve—some repairs would be necessary—but a small outlay, say, $500.00, would make the buildings serviceable for the winter—in this way we could hold these children until a permanent building be erected.

Yours sincerely,

R. B. Heron.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 18th inst., enclosing a copy of one received by Dr. Grant from Mr. R. B. Heron, the Presbyterian Missionary who lives near Pasqua Reserve.

I am of the opinion that it would be a decided mistake for the Government or the Presbyterian Church to start a Day school for Piapot, Muscowpetung and Pasqua reserves. The Department have made ample provision for all the children on the Qu'Appelle Agency (both Catholics and Protestants) in the two Government schools at Qu'Appelle and File Hills. The latter was recently built with the idea of taking care of the children of the File Hills and Qu'Appelle Agencies. At the present time there are twelve children from the Qu'Appelle Agency attending this school, five of whom have been admitted since Regina school was closed, and there is room for thirty more pupils in the building. One reason why the children from Qu'Appelle Agency are not attending school

Duncan Campbell Scott, Esq.,
in
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
in greater numbers is that they claim Mr. Campbell told them they would get a Day school and as a result of this alleged promise they have been holding back their children from both File Hills and Qu'Appelle schools, and I have had complaints about this from the Principals of both of these institutions. Another reason, so far as the File Hills School is concerned, is that recruiting has been very indifferently carried on. Mr. Heron was appointed Missionary on the West Reserves and I understand one of his duties was to assist in recruiting for the File Hills School. He has done practically nothing in this regard. His sympathies are, and always have been for a school on the West reserves and he has been talking to the Indians on these lines ever since he went there, and they use this as an argument for not sending their children here.

Mr. Heron's suggestions are impractically. It would be impossible to have a Day school that would serve more than one reserve, although, from his letter, you would think it quite feasible. He says a school might be temporarily started in the old Agency buildings. These are situated ten miles from the Indians on Piapot reserve, seven or eight miles from the settlement on Pasqua's and four miles from the settlement.
settlement on Muscowpetung reserve.

As I said before there is ample provision for all the children and I would suggest that if the Department does not intend to start a Day school at Qu'Appelle Agency, that Mr. Heron be so informed through Dr. Grant, and also that he be advised not to keep agitating for a school that is not at all necessary, as such a course tends to work against the recruiting of the two schools now in existence.

I may add that the Grand Trunk Pacific railway, which now passes along the South Boundary of the reserves of the Qu'Appelle Agency makes it quite convenient for the Indians to bring their children to File Hills as it is only about one and a half hours' run to Balcarres. I think some means should be taken to force the parents, who are holding back their children, to send them to school. There would be no evil consequences if the act were put into force. There is ample room in both schools for all.

Dear Sir,

I am writing you in regard to a matter that has come up in my work here, as Class-
room teacher in the Tile Mills Indian Boarding
School, and I trust that you will kindly
honor my request and reply to my letter
at an early date possible.

A new Agent has been appointed on these
Reserves and as he has two children of school
age, he wishes to send them into my Class-
room along with the Indian children - so there
is no Public school close to the Agency and
the Boarding School is quite near. He also
wishes me to take the children for the whole day,
one child is in the 4th Grade. The other is a toddler.

As you are possibly aware, the Indian
children are in the Classroom only the half
day, and I have them divided up as follows:
In the morning I have the Primer class -
as many as eleven children - also classes
in Grades I., II., III. and IV.

In the afternoon I have classes in
Grade I., II., III. and IV.

In the morning I have an attendance of
37, 39 or 40 children.
There are 63 children on the roll and I have 40 desks in the room.

The size of class-room is 31½ ft. x 24½ ft. x 12½ ft.

What I wish to know is this — In an Indian School such as this is — am I supposed to admit and teach white children? and would I be compelled to give them the whole day system as in a public school?

If I did admit them it would necessarily mean a change of my whole working system with the Indian children — extra work for the teacher and while I desire above all other things to be fair and do my duty well toward everyone concerned, I am wondering if it would be a fair deal to the Indian children for whom the class-room is built or for the white children who would have to be confined in the same room with the Indian children during class hours.

Then on the other hand I am hired and paid not by the Government — but by the Woman's Auxiliary Society of the Presbyterian Church and the Agent is a Government Official — I should think his children would be under the Public School system.

The clerk at the Agency has also a family with one or two of school age and if I admit the one family the others will expect to attend also. We are supposed to have new Indian children coming in all the time and this may mean a constant change of the system of work in the class-room — not only for myself — but for the children.
Other teachers who shall follow me in this work, I would be grateful if you would advise me as to what the Government wish a teacher to do in regard to this matter.

I try to do my duty toward every child, white or brown, as faithfully as possible.

I trust you will judge the matter fairly and let me know what you advise.

Am writing to the women's missionary society regarding their wishes in the matter too.

Believe me to be,

Yours very sincerely,

Rose C. MacKenzie,
Teacher Class-room
Little Hills Indian Bldg. School
Belcarra, B.C.

"Adjacent to the agency, but just outside the reserve, the Presbyterian Mission Board, with a grant from the Department, have, at a cost of $1,550, built a stone boarding school, thirty feet square and three stories high, capable, in addition to being a residence for the Principal and his family, of accommodating about twenty-five pupils. This school was opened in March, and has at the present time an enrolment of eight pupils; and although the Indians have not shown that desire for educating their children which it was confidently hoped they would evince, there is reason to believe, under the able management of the present Principal, the Rev. Alex. Campbell, whose kind and courteous manner and earnest missionary zeal are gradually overcoming their prejudices, the attendance will, in the near future, show a considerable increase. Besides the comfortable home and wholesome food thus provided for the children attending school, Mr. Campbell is enabled to supply very large quantities of clothing kindly sent him by the Ladies Foreign Mission Society."

- Indian Agent Reynolds - 1889.

"The new boarding school has been completed, and is a very good looking structure. The Rev. Mr. Campbell was in charge, and expected to have a full complement of pupils as winter approaches. Everything was in the best order about the premises; and the rooms, beds and bedding were clean and neatly arranged."

- Inspector McGibbon - 1889.

"I regret to report that the Indians have not shown a more willing disposition to avail themselves of the excellent opportunities afforded them for sending their children to school. The average daily attendance for the year has been five. It is very gratifying, however, to know that the few pupils who are attending the boarding school are making most satisfactory progress, under the care of the principal, Mr. Alex. Skene, who is possessed of more than ordinary teaching ability, and is a thorough disciplinarian."

- Indian Agent Reynolds - 1890.

"A marked improvement has taken place with respect to the boarding school at File Hills. The Indians at that agency have, as a rule, evinced a strong dislike to having their children educated, but in so far as securing pupils for the boarding schools is concerned, this has been overcome, and the means available could now be more than utilized."

- Indian Commissioner Reed - 1891.
RE: FILE HILLS INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

"Mr. Skeene still continues his boarding school for the Indians. He has twelve pupils. He speaks encouragingly of his success, and is most sanguine for the future of his school. He is a teacher of long experience, and has an Ontario record as a most successful one. He has no day pupils. Chief Star Blanket still obstinately refuses to allow any children of his band to attend any school."

- Inspector Wadsworth - 1892.

"The industries taught are practical: basket-making, straw plaiting, knitting, sewing, housework, gardening, milking and care of live stock.

Samples of their work in basket-making and straw-plaiting were shown to me; as yet they have not yet made much progress in learning these arts.

The large vegetable garden is a credit to the school.

The principal informs me that he seldom hears the children using any other language than English, even when at play, and that one little fellow has forgotten almost entirely his native dialect. They seldom, if ever, go home, their parents or guardians having given them up entirely to him, and that not one of them wished to or attended the sun dance held on the reserve near the school quite recently.

I examined the routine of work, schedule of the school and the time table of the school-room, they are all satisfactory.

While the children receive a sufficiency of meat, milk and fresh vegetables enter largely into the dietary of the school at this season of the year.

Mr. Skeene gave me the impression that he is a superior teacher of Indian children."

- Inspector Wadsworth - 1893.

Ottawa, May 3, 1928.

Dear Mrs. Motherwell:

Pursuant to your request, I have made a study of all the files available and our various reports, in an effort to learn something of the early history of the Presbyterian educational activity among the Indians at File Hills. Our first record is of a day school on the Little Black Bear's Reserve, opened in October, 1884, with Mr. J. C. Richardson as teacher. This activity failed because of lack of interest and because of the unsettled conditions brought about by the Riel Rebellion. In September, 1886, Mr. R. Toms re-opened the school and it was continued with some success until September 30, 1889. It was closed at this time, as the pupils were recruited for the boarding school which had opened in March of that year.

During our conversation, you mentioned Mr. Donald H. Melvor, an Indian graduate in Theology from Manitoba College. I can find no record of any activity in his case at File Hills. He was teacher of what was known as the Okanase or Riding Mountain Indian Day School, in the Birtle agency, for a few years commencing 1883. He transferred for a time to the Cote School and then back again to Riding Mountain.

There is attached a tabular statement, showing the average attendance, per capita grant allowed and the principals at the File Hills Indian Residential School from 1889 to the present time. I regret that I have no record of the number of half-breeds that were maintained and educated by the school at File Hills during its earlier years. I am attaching also extracts from the official reports of the Department. The year mentioned in each case is the year of the report. I trust these statements will prove useful.

As you requested, I am forwarding a copy of this communication and enclosure direct to Mr. Rhodes, the present principal at the File Hills School.

Yours respectfully,

Supt. of Indian Education.

File Hills Indian Juniors of Saskatchewan Prepare Excellent Portfolio

WE SELDOM receive at National Office a more attractive portfolio than that prepared by the File Hills Indian Juniors of Saskatchewan in reply to one from New Harmony School, Indiana, U.S.A.

The cover is bright red, bound with leather and decorated with an Indian head. The first page displays a very good photograph of His Majesty King George V. The next page has a photograph of File Hills Residential School and of a group of the girls dressed in smart school uniform.

The following introductory letter gives a good idea of school life at File Hills:

"Dear Junior Red Cross Friends:
"On behalf of the pupils of File Hills School, I wish to thank you very much for the interesting and instructive portfolio you sent us.
"We take a special interest in our neighbours to the south of us and we hope the portfolio which we are sending you will be interesting to you.
"Our school was built in 1911. It is twelve miles from the nearest town, Balcarres, and it is about sixty miles from Regina, which is the capital of Saskatchewan.

"There are about ninety children in this school. We come to school when we are five or six years old, and graduate at eighteen.

"The Senior pupils attend school only half a day. Grade VII and VI go in the morning and Grades II and I in the afternoon. The other half day consists of cooking, washing, sewing and mending. The primary classes, from one to four, go both morning and afternoon.

"There are quite a number of buildings around the school. The Principal's house is a little to the east of it. The main building consists of the dining-rooms, play-rooms, dormitories, staff offices, sewing room, kitchen, dairy and store rooms.

"There are nine members on the staff, namely—the Principal, Matron, Domestic Science teacher, Laundry Supervisor, Cook, Engineer, Farm Instructor and a Teacher.

"We have six weeks' vacation in summer. We all go to our homes for our holidays, most of them being quite a distance from here. We also have two weeks' holiday at Christmas.

"In the winter, we usually have picture shows, which are held once a week. Other nights we spend our time by doing what we like.

"Trusting that from the foregoing you will have a little idea of what our school is like.

Your sincere friend,
(Signed) Myrtle Bean,
Grade VIII."

The rest of the portfolio deals with articles about Saskatchewan, samples of school work and well selected illustrations.

Dear Sir:

It will be appreciated if you will take up with the Department at Ottawa the matter of increased pupilage for this school.

At the present time our Pupilage is 90 and for the past 6 months we have had between 95 and 100 pupils enrolled, this has resulted in increased expenditure to the extent of about $100.00 per pupil, which includes new outfits for all new pupils and additional expenses for food etc.

I have found this increased expenditure somewhat burdensome owing to the fact that the past year was practically a total failure in this district as far as crops and garden truck were concerned, the expenditure for feed and seed of all kinds being very heavy (about $1200.00 was spent on these items alone) this is in addition to the increased expenditure for food and clothing for the extra pupils.

I did not want to turn these pupils away, especially after the parents had applied for admission unsolicited. I considered that a refusal to admit them at this time might have an effect on the recruiting in future.

I shall be very glad if you will kindly take this matter up with the Department with a view to having this increase granted as from April 1st.

Dear Sir:

I have the honor to reply to your letter 306-11B of the 28th October, regarding attempted suicide of Kenneth Stonechild, pupil of the File Hills Indian Residential School.

I attach herewith statement from Mr. Rhodes, Principal of the School also statement from Mr. Ganner, Boys Supervisor.

At about 9 A.M. Sunday Octr. 22nd, Mr. Rhodes came to my home and informed me that a boy Kenneth Stonechild truanted from the School at about 5.30 P.M. last time, Saturday Octr. 21st. He also informed me that the Father of the boy and the boy arrived at the School at 8.15 Sunday morning. The father stated that he had found his son Kenneth hanging by the neck from a cross beam in his stable at approximately ten minutes to seven.

Mr. Rhodes and I went to the home and stable of Harry Stonechild, father of the boy, and we inspected the rope in the stable, and found that it had been cut. We also found that the knot of the rope was still quite loose. While we were in the stable Harry Stonechild came over from the house and explained to us just how he had found Kenneth hanging. He also explained that he had cut the rope and assisted Kenneth over to the house. We then proceeded to the house and I questioned Kenneth and examined him for marks in the vicinity of the neck. I found a very slight abrasion running along the point of the jawbone. Kenneth informed me that he had run away from the school because he had been sent back on the playground by one of the members of Staff, also that he "thought" the member had said he would attend to him later. He also informed me that he had obtained the rope used, from the barn room in the barn. I then returned to the Agency and immediately called Dr. Sims the Medical officer and the R.C.M.P. at Balcarres requesting them to come out and make an examination and investigation. I presume reports in full have been submitted to you from the Doctor and Police.

I would like to point out however the fact that the rope knot was quite loose indicating that no great strain had been placed upon it, further the beam from which the rope was suspended was quite low and that in my opinion it was impossible for a person of this boy's height to hang suspended from this rope. Another fact which would require some explaining is that while this boy was cut down at 6.30 A.M. yet he and his father returned to the school at 8.15 A.M. and the place where the deed was done is some 20 to 25 minutes walk from the school, which would indicate the boy had not suffered much physical strain.

While Mr. Rhodes opinion is that this boy was trying to bring discredit to the school, my opinion is that the boy wanted away from the school for good, also Mr. Rhodes informed me afterwards that the parents of this boy had made a verbal request last spring for the discharge of Kenneth.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Thomas Robertson, Esq.
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Doctor Robertson:

Re: Kenneth Stonechild, Pupil File Hills School.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter file 306-11B., dated November 8, requesting report on the above named Indian school boy.

Since his admission to hospital for observation following which was thought to be an attempt to commit suicide, he has appeared to be perfectly normal and in no way has exhibited any symptoms of mental disarrangement. In order to be certain he was normal it will be necessary to take him in for examination and report by Dr. Rothwell. I am hoping that it will not be necessary for him to remain in Hospital, but expect to take him to the Doctor's office. Once this report is received a report will be forwarded to you.

At present I am of the opinion that the action he took was not that he wished to take his own life, but rather that he wished to stir up dissatisfaction against the school and staff, with the hope that he would be discharged. Unless Dr. Rothwell recommends that he be committed to a mental institution, I would recommend that arrangements be made for him to be transferred to another Residential School. I do not feel that it would be in the best interests of the other pupils to have him back at File Hills School and there would be a certain amount of punishment, that he is going to be away from his parents and not be able to see them as frequently as in the past. To me there is no reason why he should not continue to attend school. I will admit that no matter how long he may go he never will win a Governor General's medal, but that is no excuse to allow him to return to the Reserve to bum around and do nothing. If he is wanting to start that before he is 15 years of age, what will be be like when he reaches the age of 25 years.

Your Obedient Servant,

Dear Sir:

I beg to attach Police Report and correspondence re Kenneth Stonechild, attempted suicide, File Hills Residential School.

It will be noted the Police suggest that some further investigation should be made into the cause for his act. I have taken the matter up with Mr. Doids, the Agent; Mr. Rhodes, the Principal of the School; and Dr. Simes, our Medical Superintendent. I can find no evidence that this boy has received any punishment in the past, had anything to fear at that time, or any valid reason why he should have made this attempt.

The boy has been, since that date, in the Qu'Appelle Indian Hospital, under the supervision of Dr. Simes, and the Doctor reports that he can find no evidence of any mental derangement. He is, however, going to bring him in to Dr. Rothwell for further examination. It is also Dr. Simes' opinion that the boy was not troubled with the intention of taking his life, but rather to stir up trouble in the school in the hope of securing his discharge. Dr. Simes recommends that if the boy is found to be normal he be returned to another school, as he considers the boy would have a bad influence, if he were returned there, on the rest of the pupils. Dr. Simes is apparently also of the opinion that he is not very bright and the schooling will not be of much benefit to him, but considers that he would be better there than running around the reserve.

We have in our schools both boys and girls around 15 years of age upon whom, in my opinion, we are simply squandering money in continuing them there with the hope of advancing them further in education. This boy is apparently one of that class. Under ordinary conditions I would recommend his discharge, but owing to the fact that it is believed he took this action for the purpose of obtaining his discharge, were it now given, it would have a tendency to encourage other pupils to take some action such as this to obtain theirs. I would therefore recommend that if this boy be found normal, authority be given to transfer him to another school. May I have your instructions please.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

P.S.--Since writing the above, I am in receipt of another letter from Dr. Simes in which he states that Dr. Rothwell can find no evidence of mental derangement but recommends the boy be transferred to another school rather than sent back to File Hills. I might also state that I have advised the Police I can find no reason for this boy's action except a desire to obtain his discharge from the school.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of November 17 and also a police report relating to the above noted student, attached thereto.

I note that in the last paragraph of your letter you state: "We have in our schools both boys and girls around 15 years of age upon whom in my opinion we are simply squandering money in continuing them there with the hope of advancing them further in education."

I am inclined to agree with you that a great deal of time is wasted in all educational institutions in seeking to educate boys and girls with a low I.Q. On the other hand, we have learned from experience that it is an exceedingly dangerous thing to turn boys and girls of this age with a low I.Q. rating loose on the reserves. You should feel perfectly free to point out to the principals of residential schools that these boys and girls should be engaged in vocational work—sewing, knitting, mat making, basketry, elementary agriculture, dish washing, etc. I learned from experience in the operation of the subnormal institution at Portage that it is astonishing what these boys and girls can undertake and accomplish if given the right direction.

Dr. A. B. Simes:
