Dear Dr. Simes:

Your patient, Stonechild, was in my office on November 14th. After going into this case, and with the information you had given me, I feel that it is just a problem of behaviour in this boy. It might seem a little unusual that he would go to the lengths of trying to take his life, but I feel, as you seem to, that he did not intend to do anything more than create sympathy for himself. He is undoubtedly deaf and has considerable difficulty in the school classroom, and as a result of this he claims that the teacher would get out of patience with him at times and "boxed his ears", I believe he said. He is quite emotional and cried when telling about it. I suppose that it was not as bad as that, but rather he himself was not anxious to remain in school. No doubt these children of the wild are even more inclined to want to be out of School in the wide open spaces than a white child, so it would not be very unusual if he did feel that way about school.

When he left the school and went home he was still in fear of his father punishing him and taking him back to the school, and that no doubt would explain his remaining outside and then arranging things so that it would appear when they turned up in the morning that he had tried to take his own life. He is only fifteen years of age and rather young to think of something as serious as that, and I do not feel that he was intending to take his own life—in fact he volunteers the statement now that he did not, but thought it would be a good way to have himself excused from running away from school.

I am inclined to be sympathetic towards this youngster because there were many things about the school that he did not like besides the teacher. He tells me that the boys of his age teased him a great deal and would tell him he was both dumb and deaf and, from his own statements, they did impose upon him. To protect himself from that he chose to play with children much younger, which no doubt created the impression among the teachers that he was of their mental age.

You suggest getting some new school environment and I think that would be advisable and it might help to solve the problem. I do not feel that this boy is as yet either a defective or a case of mental trouble.

Yours very truly,

O.E. Rothwell, M.D.
Director,
Psychopathic Department.

Dear Doctor Robertson;

Re: No.167. Reginald Keewatin.

I have to report that the above mentioned Pupil of this School truanted on Friday evening, November 17th between 5-30 and 6-00 PM, he proceeded to his home the same evening, I went to the home of his Parents the following morning and they informed me that the boy was out helping his brothers to cut wood, when the Father and myself went to the bluff the boy could not be found, I decided to leave the boy with his Parents and advised them to bring him back to the School when he had settled down somewhat, they returned him to the School on Tuesday afternoon and at 5-30 the same evening he was again missing he was returned to the School again on Thursday and was put to bed and his clothing taken away from him.

On Friday morning Mr Ganner, the Boys Supervisor sent one of the Boys to the Dormitory for this boys dishes, the boy returned immediately and reported that Reggie was trying to hang himself in the Bathroom in the Dormitory, Mr Ganner immediately went to the Dormitory and found this Boy suspended from a vent pipe in the Bathroom by a belt under his chin and attached to a Bed sheet thrown over the pipe, Mr Ganner released the boy and sent him back to his bed,(the boy was able to walk to his bed without any difficulty) and placed a guard over him, this guard has been maintained since.

On Saturday on my return I notified the Mounted Police at Balcarres of this incident and he made a trip to the School for the purpose of questioning this Boy, we were not able to glean any information as to why he had done this other than that the Staff are always mean to him and are always picking on him, this has been the excuse given in other cases.
the reason for running away, I would say that this boy like Kenneth Stonechild has not been disciplined or punished, and they therefore cannot give this as a cause for their truancy, they resent being spoken to and corrected by the members of Staff, that is the only reason we can find for their actions.

It would appear upon questioning that this Boy did not actually intend to do away with himself, it is significant that he waited until he heard someone coming to the Dormitory and then made the attempt knowing that they would immediately look for him when they found that he was not in his bed, he has admitted to me since that it was not his intention to go the limit, that he wanted to cause trouble by this action, I believe there is a concerted effort afoot to cause trouble and bring discredit upon the School and the Staff, particularly Mr Ganner, it has always been my experience that one member of Staff is particularly disliked by the Indians and they will go to any length to cause trouble for him in the hope that he will be discharged, when they succeed in their efforts they direct their attentions to another member of Staff, in past years this attitude has been ignored by myself and I have told the Indians that I will take the responsibility for my Staff, and that I would not tolerate any interference on their part, I still believe that these boys have been put up to this by some-one outside, but neither the Mounted Police Corporal or myself have been successful in finding out who it is.

In this connection I have been thinking that it might be as well if we were to ask the Mounted Police to co-operate and send a special investigator to the School, I would be willing to give Mr Ganner extended leave of absence, and the investigator could take Mr. Ganner's position at the School, we could leave the impression that Mr Ganner had resigned and left, this arrangement would have to be entirely secret of course, I wonder if you could see the Mounted Police authorities and discuss this with them (if you consider such action would help to clear up this matter) I am firmly convinced that this is the only way we can get to the bottom of the affair.

In connection with the Kenneth Stonechild case; I am quoting a few extracts from a short letter I received from Mr Frayling of the Gordon's School on Saturday, his letter is dated the 23rd.

"Dear Mr Rhodes,

I was sorry to hear of the sad ending of one of your boy pupils, *** You have my sympathy knowing the many untrue reports that can circulate at such times."

It would appear from the above that reports have been circulated among the Indians of the Touchwood Agency that Stonechild actually took his life, I have not heard where Mr Frayling got his information, but there is no doubt that what he has heard is quite
accepted as true on that Agency, I do not know just how general the circulation of this report has been, but there is no doubt that the whole Province, (at least the Indians of the Province) are aware of the attempt made by Stonechild, I would therefore like you to co-operate with me and forward a letter to the Indian Agent at the Touchwood Agency stating that the reports circulated throughout that Agency are entirely untrue and requesting the Agent to correct this impression in his contacts with the Indians, it might be that we shall hear of similar reports from other Agencies and it might then be necessary to circulate all Agencies that these reports are absolutely untrue.

If you feel that this could be better discussed verbally in your Office I would be willing to come in and do so, at the present time I feel that one can hardly leave the place in case something else crops up that will have more disastrous effects.

I trust you will be able to give this matter your early attention.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

Re: File Hills Indian Residential School.

I am attaching a letter received from Mr. Rhodes, Principal of the above school. You will note from this that there has been another case of so-called attempted suicide at this school; that it is Mr. Rhodes' opinion that there is some outside influence trying to stir up trouble; that he suggests getting the Mounted Police to send in a special investigator.

I have discussed the matter thoroughly with Mr. Rhodes. He is firmly convinced that in neither case did the boys actually intend to commit suicide—in fact both of them have admitted that they did not. In the last case the strap was under the boy's chin, not around his throat.

He suggested that the Police send in an investigator, and while, in my opinion, to do so would be of no value, as I do not believe the Indians would give any information to any white man so sent in, even if outside influence is being used, I took the matter up with the Mounted Police and they advise that while they are at all times

In relative the above Mr. Rhodes, Principal of the above school called at this office this p.m., stating that on Friday last during his absence from the school the above named youth had attempted to take his life by hanging; he had however been found in time and no damage to him had occurred.

Information obtained at the school was to the effect that Keeswatin ran away from the school on Nov. 17th and was returned to the school by his parents on Nov. 21st, he ran away again at 5.30 p.m., that night and his parents reported him at home on the 23rd inst., he was then brought back to school by the staff and kept in his room, on Friday morning one of the staff sent a boy to Keeswatin's room to get the dishes he had used when eating, the boy found Keeswatin in the bathroom trying to hang himself, he was taken down by Mr. Ganner and has since been kept under guard.

3. Undoubtedly there is a movement on foot through the students at this school to cause trouble, the seat of the trouble is unknown, it does not appear that this lad intended to take his life, he states himself he did it to cause trouble.

4. Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a report from the Mounted Police on Wilfred Deiter, an Indian boy from the File Hills Colony who ran away from the school for the second time. Evidently the Police were called in and the boy in question was found with his father near their home on the Reserve. Constable Mears states in his report as follows:

"In conversation with this boy and also his father, it was learned that his reason for running away from the school, is due to the fact that he gets no class work, he is doing outside work, such as hauling hay, cutting wood, and general labouring; the father states, that in view of the fact that his boy is receiving no better education at the school than he would receive at home, and further that the other boys have enlisted and he can use this boy's help, he does not encourage him to stay at school.

With full knowledge of the fact, that Indians are fond of making complaints of frivolous nature, there would appear to be some ground for this matter and in view of the fact that hunting these children takes up considerable time, at a time when other more important matters have to be neglected, it is considered that some action should be taken to have conditions rectified, in order that there will be no recurrence."

Superintendent Nicholson of the Police makes the following remark:

"It would be appreciated if the matter of this boy's escapades could be brought to the attention of the officials concerned in order that appropriate control may be exercised over his future actions."

I, of course, have not heard your part of the story but from the foregoing if he were my boy and not receiving any education at the school I certainly would not leave him there.

Report on File Hills Residential School

I wish to inform you that while visiting the Lebret School the week before last I left about 4:00 in the afternoon of the second day for Balcarres, where I stayed overnight, and the following day inspected the File Hills Residential School. While there I inspected the school buildings, also the out-buildings, and everything in general connected with the school, and have come to the conclusion that this institution is well managed in every way.

File Hills School is a very good building and the only repair work that is required is some decorating in the kitchen, and the Principal, I believe, has already arranged for this. Mr. Rhodes remarked to me that unless some unforeseen calamity happened he would need but very little in the next 3 years. Here is a man who realizes that there is a war on and does not intend to ask for anything unless it is absolutely required. The out-buildings are small and scattered all over the yard. They are all of cheap construction but have been painted recently and are in good state of repair. This also applies to the barn. The two classrooms are in a separate building and this is also in good state of repair.

The school maintains about 35 head of cattle, mostly all cows, and 22 were milking at the time of my inspection. They keep chickens but no hogs. They also farm 35 acres of land which yielded a fair crop last year. They have all of the potatoes and vegetables that they require, in fact the Principal told me that he had potatoes to sell.

The children receive milk three times a day and as I was there at noon I checked over the bill of fare and was in the dining room while the children were eating. From the appearance of the children and from the food that was being served to them, I think they are well cared for and they seemed to be happy and full of life. Yours truly,

Report on the File Hills Indian Residential School

Dear Sir:

I wish to inform you that I visited the File Hills Indian Residential School on the 5th instant.

I reported on this School on November 28th, 1940, and everything is practically the same as it was at that time.

The buildings are in about the same state of repair as they were last year.

The crop, however, was very poor this year on account of drought, and they only threshed 900 bus. of Oats from 63 acres, and 570 bus. of Wheat from 40 acres. The Principal also informed me that they only harvested 300 bus. of Potatoes and it will be necessary for him to purchase additional potatoes during the Winter. This is no fault of the School, simply a case of lack of moisture.

They have the same amount of cattle at the School as they had last year and at the time of my visit they were milking 12 cows.

The well at the School with which they had so much trouble last year, is functioning satisfactorily at the present time and they have an abundance of water.

I was in the classrooms talking to the children and they all looked exceptionally well. Therefore they are evidently well cared for and there was no sickness of any kind in the School. There were 90 children in residence and two still to come, at the time of my inspection.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir:

Regarding the burning of the classrooms at the File Hills Indian Residential School, which happened on the 8th instant, when Mr. Jones, the Indian Agent, was in the office here last week, he was of the opinion that the fire had been started by faulty electric wiring. However, he now informs me that a few days after some of the children started to discuss the fire at different times and there were a lot of rumours floating around. Therefore Mr. Jones got in touch with Cpl. McCarro, of the R.C.M.Police, Balcarres, who carried out an investigation at the school, during which three boys admitted setting fire to the school.

The boy who actually lit the match and started the fire is only 12 years old and is from the Carlton Agency, Mistawasis Reserve. Benny Pasqua and Jimmy Keepiness, aged 15, of the Qu'Appelle Agency, helped the little fellow and more or less forced him to start the fire.

Agent Jones was in the office today and we went to see Superintendent Darling, of the R.C.M.Police here in the city. While we were there he got in touch with Commissioner Ring, of the Bureau of Child Protection and it was decided to take the three boys into custody. Mr. Jones is to lay the charges tonight when he returns to Balcarres. These boys will be brought in to Regina very likely to-morrow and placed in the Industrial School here until such time as their case comes up.

Have you any instructions to give in the matter? You will receive this letter on Monday morning, as I am sending it by Air Mail, and if you write back immediately I should receive your reply on Tuesday. The Police Report will not be forwarded by Cpl. McCarro until about Monday.

Yours truly,

I am now able to submit a further report on the burning of the classrooms at the File Hills Indian Residential School.

In conjunction with Corporal McCarro of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Balcarres Detachment, an investigation lasting two days was carried out, and it has definitely been established that the classrooms were deliberately set on fire by the students. To date three boys, Sampson Pechawis age 12 years of the Mistawasis Reserve, Carlton Agency; Benny Pasqua age 15 years, of the Pasqua Reserve, Qu'Appelle Agency; and Jimmie Keepness, age 15 years, of Moscowpetung Reserve, also of the Qu'Appelle Agency; have each admitted his guilt and the part each played in this affair.

The investigation was carried out on April 15th and 16th. I laid an Information and Complaint on Friday, April 17th and the boys were removed to the Regina Industrial School on Saturday, April 18th. They will remain there pending further instruction from the Department. It is understood Mr. Christianson, General Superintendent of Indian Agencies has contacted the Department requesting the Department's wishes and instructions.

As stated above, to date three boys have admitted their guilt, but there is no doubt in my mind that all of the senior boys in the School were aware of what was going to take place and had a hand in the careful and deliberate plans that were laid. It is my intention to have the investigation continued.

I understand the police are submitting a detailed report to the Department. Therefore I did not see the necessity of my doing so and have confined my report to the findings to date and the action taken.

Yours truly,

1. With reference to the above. This early A.M. phone call was received from R.S. Jones, Indian Agent of the File Hills Agency, reporting that during the evening previous April 7th, the school house at the File Hills Indian Residential School had burned to the ground with the total loss of the school equipment contained therein. This building was 100' X 26', one storey with full sized basement, and contained two class rooms known as the senior and junior. The building was heated by a pipeless furnace located in the basement. The fire was first noticed at approx. 7:30 p.m. and as enquiries from the staff revealed no fire to have been put in the furnace since 5:30 p.m. and very little at this time, all the circumstances indicated the fire to have been set and for this reason Mr. Jones requested a police investigation.

2. In company with Capt. Zimmerman and Caldwell, patrol was immediately made to the File Hills Agency, but other than being fairly well convinced that the fire had been set by some of the children, no definite information to that effect could be obtained this date and on Mr. Jones suggestion it was deemed advisable to let the matter rest for a few days during which time with the aid of the staff every effort would be made to obtain some lead which would assist the investigation.

15-4-42

3. This date Mr. Jones stated that he had information which he considered would be worthy of checking, with the following results.

STATEMENT OF MRS. AGNES ALEXANDER, Kitchen Supervisor.

BEGINS: "Yesterday morning April 14th, I was talking to Edith RIDER, age 14 yrs., and in conversation she said that Samson PECHAWIS told Elsie Anderson on Wednesday morning April 8th that the boys were going to burn the class room that night. I asked which boys; she said Benny and Stanley Pasqua, Jimmy Keepness & Samson Pechawis. Elsie Anderson is employed in the dairy and it was on Wednesday morning when Samson took the milk in that he told Elsie about the class room going to be burned. That night, Edith Rider said that from what she understood it was Stanley Pasqua who actually set the fire." ENDS:

Witness: R. Macara. (Sgd) Agnes Alexander.

4. Following up the contents of the above statement the following statement was taken from Edith Rider, age 14 yrs.

BEGINS: "Fern Goforth told me that Elsie Anderson told her as a secret that she (Elsie) while in the dairy on Wednesday morning April 8th, Samson Pechawis came into the dairy with the milk and at that time told Elsie that he and Benny and Stanley Pasqua and Jimmy Keepness were going to set fire to the class room that night. Fern told me this when the class room was burning." ENDS:

Witness: R. Macara. (Sgd) Edith Rider.

5. Fern Goforth interviewed furnished the following statement.

BEGINS: "Between supper time and when the class room caught fire on Wednesday evening April 8th I was talking to Elsie Anderson and she told me as a secret that Samson Pechawis had told her that not to study in the class room as he and Benny Pasqua and Jimmy Keepness were going to burn the class room down. Elsie did not tell me when Samson told her this!" ENDS: Witness: R. Macara. (Sgd) Fern Goforth.

6. From the contents of the foregoing statements it was evident that Samson Pechawis and Jimmy Keepness were fragrantly implicated in the burning of the school and after considerable questioning and cross examination they furnished the following statements:

Statement of Samson Pechawis - Age 12 yrs.

BEGINS: On Sunday evening April 5th, 1942, I was at the senior play ground. Benny Pasqua, Andrew Rider, Jimmy Keepness and Willie Hilkit were there. We were all lying on the grass. These boys told me to burn down the class room, I said no. They said why don't you do it there is too much trouble. I told them I did not know how to burn down the class room. They said there is lots of paper in the waste paper basket in the basement and I was to take this paper and put it in the corner near the chimney and set fire to it. I said no I would not do it. No time was mentioned when the fire was to be set. On Tuesday morning April 7th, I told Elsie Anderson at the dairy that we were going to set the school on fire. She said do it right away, that would be nice. After supper that day Benny Pasqua, Andrew Rider, Jimmy Keepness and Willie Hilkit and I went behind the class room. The boys asked Andrew Rider to go in the north east class room window, he said no I am too big it would not fit me. They then said to me you are the smallest and told me to go in this class room window and go down and open the coal chute door in the basement. I said no you always make me do everything. They said go and do it if you don't the big boys will hang you. I had trouble before with Andrew Rider and Terrence Bear over some money I lost and they gave me a licking. I am afraid of the big boys. I crawled up the north east class room window the storm window had a slide in it and I went into the junior room through this slide. I went to the basement and opened the coal chute door. This door was fastened with a bolt about a foot long with a stick on the end about two feet long which was turned between two uprights. I unturned this stick so as the door could be opened from the outside. I was going to set the fire at this time but the bell rang and I came out the basement through the coal chute. It was the 7:30 p.m. bell that rang. After lining up in the main building all the senior boys went out to the play ground to play football. Soon after Mr. Andres and Mr. Huston came with the truck and Stanley Pasqua and my brother Arnold who had run away a few days previous. We all then came into the play gymnasium room and soon after Jimmy Keepness said to me, let's go and do it again, meaning start the fire. I said no they might think we are running away.

Wednesday after supper we boys were out playing and Willie Hilkit said to me Arnold, Wilfred Haywash, Stanley Pasqua and Jimmy Keepness wants you to come and see them. These boys were at the toilet, I went with Willie to the toilet, these boys were there. I asked them what they wanted, Jimmy said we want you to put the school on fire. There was a narrow place beside the chimney and Jimmy put a lot of paper at this place to the ceiling. I lit the match to it, the fire flamed right up to the ceiling. We got out the coal chute right away. Only Willie Hilkit was spying around the corner when Jimmy and I came out the basement. We then went to the senior playground. Jimmy and I went back and went into the basement and we seen the fire had started to burn the ceiling and then we came out again. We went back to the playground. Lloyd said do you know what to do, we said no, he told us to set the class room on fire. We all said yes. On Wednesday April 6th just after supper Wilfred Haywash, Arnold Pechawis, Leslie Sanderson and I were at the toilet and I met Samson Pechawis at the corner of the school house. Then Benny Pasqua came. Sammy asked me to help him climb in the class room, and Benny and I helped him to get up to the window. Benny went away and the next time I seen Samson he came out the coal chute. Samson called me and asked me to come down with him, I said no. Then Wilfred and Arnold came and Arnold told me to go down. I went down into the basement with Samson and I gathered paper and he put it close by the chimney and then he set fire to it. As soon as I seen the flames going up I got through the coal chute and Samson came soon after. Wilfred and Arnold were outside when I came out, I went to Arnold and Wilfred and we went around to the front steps and Samson came and found us there. We all then went back to the school house and looked through the basement window, we seen the fire dying off, we thought it was going to go out so left. It will be noted that the contents of the foregoing statements are somewhat at variance with regard to persons present, etc., but that Jimmy Keppness, Benny Pasqua and the above named admit their active participation in the setting of the fire, while the others, particularly Arnold Pechawis, Alfred Hatawai and Lloyd Stonechild, who are considered the chief counsellors of the offence have no admission in implicating Pasqua, Keppness and Samson Pechawis, but they are cleverly endeavouring to keep themselves from being involved. It is also fairly well established that the anticipated burning of the school was common knowledge particularly among the senior boys of which there are some 16, and while several others are mentioned in the statements as being present, investigation has so far failed to confirm same and the parties giving the statements on being further questioned state they may have been mistaken in the identity of certain ones, however, as already stated there would appear considerable to hand implicating Arnold Pechawis, Alfred Hatawai and Lloyd Stonechild, and this is further borne out by the contents of the following note which was handed to me by Mr. Jones on the morning of the 18th when I went for the above named and his companions to take them to Regina, and at which time I was given to understand the note had been found and turned over to Mr. Jones. Contents of the note follow and there is very little doubt but that it was written by Arnold Pechawis.

BEGIN: "To Samson: Hello there, well here goes an answer which I got this afternoon. Well Sammy its longest you don't blame me and W.H. for that gas we got, don't say anything about that please, tell him you them Mr.G.M.P. Lloyd told you to set it the time I and S.F. ran away so you get the idea from him. That's what we going to say too they just want to find out you got that idea first so just tell them he say that the time you got stripping after you run away, if they know Lloyd really got that idea first so they'll let us go. Jimmy said he going to tell them that to, tell them mounties my brother Arnold got after me after we did that he sure gave me hell for doing that but he didn't want to tell anybody first, say that to them, so I won't be in trouble and tell them I wasn't home that time he tell you and Jimmy I set the fire in the school, tell them that's time I was away I and S.F., tell them that so long from your brother A.F. If you answer give it to me."

Samson Pechawis on being questioned about the above letter furnished the following information in the form of a statement.

BEGIN: "During the afternoon of April 17th., I wrote a note to my brother Arnold Pechawis told him to tell the truth about the big boys and the fire and maybe they would let us off. I gave this note to Terrance Bear to give to Arnold. Later Terrance gave me the note that Cpl. Macara has shown me and said that Arnold sent it. I read it about half then put it in my side pants pocket. I lost this note and Jimmy Keppness has told me that George Stonechild seen the note sticking out of my pocket while I was eating and he took it out of my pocket and gave it to Lloyd Stonechild. Lloyd Stonechild told me that the best way to set the fire was with gas. He told me to ask Walter Stonechild for some gas. I didn't ask Walter. Walter helps Mr. Lame in the engine room." END. Sgd. THE STATEMENT OF WILFRED HAYWARI - AGE 16 YEARS OLD.

STATEMENT OF ARNOLD PECHANIS, age 16 yrs., 7 months.

Having been warned by Cpl. Macara, I need not say anything, I have nothing to hope from any promise or favour and nothing to fear from any threat whether or not I say anything. Any thing I do say may be used in evidence at my trial. Understanding the above, I make the following statement voluntarily.

On Monday, March 30th., 1942, I in company with Stanley Pechanis run away from the File Hills Indian Residential School. We were brought back to the school on Tuesday evening, April 7th., and receiving a talking and strapping from Mr. Huston, Principal. After receiving the strapping I went upstairs and Jimmy Krehmee who had also run away before I did said, "I was trying to burn the school while you were gone" and that he still intended to do it. On Wednesday evening, April 8th., just after supper, Wilfred Baynham and I went to the toilet. At this time I seen Benny Pechanis and Willie Hilbert standing by the school and I also seen Jimmy Krehmee and Samson Pechanis go down the coal chute into the basement. We knew these boys were setting fire to the school and Wilfred and I went over. Benny went away with Hilbert and Jimmy and Samson came out the basement. There wasn't only Wilfred, Jimmy, Samson and I left. We looked in the basement windows and seen the fire had kind of died down. Jimmy had a jam can and said lets go and get some gasoline from the sewing outfit. All four of us went to the sewing outfit, Jimmy loosened the gas pipe and we all took turns sucking gas out and spitting it into the can. Jimmy then took the pipe right off and was able to fill the can with gas. We then took the gasoline back to the class room.

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

The Women's Missionary Society of the United Church of Canada has submitted the name of Mr. L.L. Dobbin as Principal of the File Hills Indian Residential School. At the present time Mr. Dobbin is in charge of the Indian Mission at the Cote Reserve.

The Department has approved the temporary appointment of Mr. Dobbin as Principal, but we have advised the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada that we consider conditions at the school should be carefully reviewed after he has been in charge for six months or so. Due to the destruction of the classroom building at the File Hills School by fire and the apparent lack of discipline mentioned in several letters received from you, it is our feeling that it would have been preferable to have a clergyman appointed Principal. It is for this reason that we have only approved of Mr. Dobbin temporarily. As you can realize, the United Church at the present time is experiencing considerable difficulty in obtaining qualified men for Principals of residential schools, as there has been a heavy demand for many of their best men to enter the Chaplain Services with some branch of the Active Army.

I feel certain that both the Indian Agent and yourself will do everything possible to assist Mr. Dobbin and we will be glad to hear from you from time to time regarding his administration of the school.

Dear Sir:

In connection with the burning of the File Hills Indian Residential School classrooms, the trial was held at Balcarres on Saturday afternoon last, May 16th, which I attended.

Regarding the fire, five boys have been held in custody, two at the Regina Jail and three at the Boys' Industrial School here in Regina, and they received the following sentences:

Samson Pechawis, aged 12, Mistawasis Reserve - 3 months in the Industrial School here in Regina. He will then be discharged on probation and has to report every two weeks to his Agent.

Jim Keepness, aged 15, and Benny Pasqua, aged 15, both from the Qu'Appelle Agency, were sentenced to remain at the Industrial School until September 1st, at which time they will be transferred to the Brandon Residential School until June 30th, 1943.

Arnold Pechawis, aged 16, Mistawasis Reserve (brother of Samson Pechawis), and Wilfred Haywhi, aged 16, from the Assiniboina Reserve, Qu'Appelle Agency - one year in the Moosomin Jail.

Jim Keepness and Benny Pasqua had counsel and were defended by Mr. Robinson, a lawyer here in Regina. This was arranged for by the parents of the two boys. The other three had no counsel.

At the trial and investigation it was revealed that the five boys sentenced are not any worse than the other boys at the School because everybody knew the night before that the fire was going to take place, apparently, with the exception of the Staff. I must say that the boys who were reprimanded seemed to be very nice and this was borne out by the Principal of the

I am submitting this information because no doubt it will be some time before you receive the Police Report on this case.

Yours truly,

I say that our Department does not intend to appear on this case, therefore we have more or less left the matter to Mr. Christianson of the Indian Department. I note you have notified him of the date. We are telling him what we consider might be done with these boys from the observations made by the Superintendent of the School. He says that the two younger boys, he thinks, could be put on probation, and maybe the older boy as well. We would suggest, therefore, that the recommendation be that the boys all be put on probation to the Indian Agent or to somebody well known in the district, and if the Judge did not think this was sufficient that the older boy be sent to the Industrial School, and the younger ones be put on probation.

The boys have been very well behaved while in detention, and have shown a willingness to do everything they have been told, and even this small amount of punishment may be of some benefit to them.

Dear Sir:

Regarding the burning of the File Hills Indian Residential School classrooms, I have been in touch with Mr. Ring, the Commissioner of the Bureau of Child Protection; the Police Magistrate; the Police; and Mr. Robinson, the lawyer who defended the two boys, and it has been revealed in the investigation and throughout the trial that every boy in the School was probably just as guilty as the others who were taken into custody, although it will probably not be recorded.

It is my belief that since a new Principal is coming to the School in the presence of Mr. Dobbin, the present staff should be transferred to some other School because I am of the opinion that they have outlived their usefulness where they are now, although they may do very good work at some other institution.

I trust that you will take this up with the Women's Missionary Society of the United Church of Canada, and insist on this action being taken.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,

Dear Sir:

I hereby submit my monthly report covering the File Hills Agency for the month of May 1942;

CRIME:

The five boys implicated with the burning of the class-room at the File Hills Residential School, were charged under Sec. 511 of the Criminal Code and were brought before Magistrate Fraser on May 16th, and were sentenced as follows:

Arnold Pechawis of the Carlton Agency and Wilfred Hawawie of the Qu'Appelle Agency were each sentenced to One Year in the Moosomin Goal.

Benny Pasqua and Jimmy Keepness both of the Qu'Appelle Agency were sentenced to remain at the Regina Industrial School until the Fall term opens at the Brandon Indian Residential School where they will remain for one year.

Sampson Pechawis, age 12 years, of the Carlton Agency will return to his home the end of June.

AGENT'S REPORT ON FILE HILLS AGENCY FOR MONTH OF JUNE.

Mr. Dobbin arrived at the File Hills Indian Residential school to take over the duties of Principal on June 1st. The last of the pupils left for summer vacation on Saturday, June 27th.

E.S. Jones,

Ottawa,
July 14, 1942.

Dear Sir:

Mr. L.L. Dobbin has now been Principal of the File Hills Residential School for a period of six weeks. The Department is anxious to know if he appears to be obtaining control of the situation at this school. I should, therefore, appreciate receiving from you a very frank report on his work as well as the work of the other members of the staff. Is it your opinion that there should be additional changes in the staff at this school? An early reply would be appreciated. When replying you should let me know the number of times you have found it possible to visit the school since Mr. Dobbin took charge.

Yours truly,

Dear Doctor Dorsey:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of April 14, in which you seek information with respect to the provision made in the 1943-44 estimates for the erection of a classroom building at the File Hills Indian Residential School.

I may state that no provision has been made in these estimates for the construction of Indian day or residential schools anywhere in the Dominion, with the exception of two Indian day schools in Nova Scotia, which schools were urgently needed in that province, in view of the centralization of the Indian population at Shubenacadie and Eskasoni.

The claims of certain Indian reserves for additional school buildings have been carefully reviewed during the last two years. There has been, and still is, however, a feeling that an attempt should be made to carry on with the buildings now available, in the hope that huge supplies of lumber and other building equipment will be available for a worthwhile building program immediately following the close of the war. In addition to the acute shortage of certain building materials, there is, as you know, an acute shortage of skilled labour in the Dominion. These have been the main considerations that have resulted in our present policy. However, if the war continues, it is just possible that this policy may have to be modified to meet conditions such as the conditions now existing at File Hills. It is scarcely necessary to add that I would be glad to discuss this matter with you more fully during one of your periodical visits to Ottawa.

Yours very truly,

RAH

Report on File Hills Indian Residential School

I might say while at the Agency I visited the File Hills Indian Residential School and everything there seemed to be going along fairly satisfactory.

The staff there were glad to know that the classrooms are being rebuilt. I was in the new classrooms talking to the man in charge, Mr. Dick Hasty, whom I have known for the past thirty years. He is getting up in years but he is a first class carpenter and we can depend on anything Mr. Hasty does therefore I know he will make a good job of rebuilding these classrooms. Mr. Hasty told me that they probably would be finished at the end of this month but on account of the shortage of labour he thought it might take him a couple of weeks longer so in all probability it will be on in November some time before the building is completed. However, it is closed in and there should be no trouble in finishing even if the weather does get cold.

The Principal again brought to my attention the boiler at the school. When Mr. Mayhew, Provincial Boiler Inspector, was down there last he reported to me when the new boiler was being installed that we should make arrangements to purchase another new boiler to replace the other one, and I brought this to the attention of our Branch. I again brought this to the attention of our Branch on July 17th last since no action had been taken stating that the boiler was not satisfactory but again no attention was paid to this by our Branch. To quote Mr. Dobbin's remarks it does not matter how much you fire this boiler it is so badly caked that very little results are obtained from the fuel burned in this heating plant therefore they are depending mostly on the boiler that was installed a year ago last Fall at the school and in real cold weather this is not sufficient. The matter of having a new boiler installed should be given consideration.

The staff at the school, of course, is new as several of the ladies there are beginning their first year but there were one or two ladies who were there before I certainly was not sorry to see leave this institution. Mr. Dobbin, the Principal, seems to be carrying on very satisfactorily.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

I wish to submit the following report concerning recent occurrences at File Hills School: On Sunday morning, February 24th, about 2:30 noises were heard in the senior boy's balcony and upon investigation by the Boys Supervisor five Senior girls were discovered there.

An immediate investigation by Principal and Staff revealed the following facts. One of the Senior boys had opened the lock on the balcony store room door by means of a key which he had fashioned from another key with the aid of a small file. Having thus gained access to this store-room which is separated from the girls balcony by a thin partition of ½ in. V-joint, the boys managed to get possession of a brace and bit with which they bored holes in the wall and removed several short boards from the bottom panel of the partition. The opening thus formed was in a corner near the floor and behind a cupboard which was put back in its usual position afterwards. On the girl's side of the partition a large packing box covered the opening. About 2 A.M. one of the senior boys unlocked the storeroom door and sent a smaller boy through the opening into the girls dormitory to waken a number of the girls who followed him back to the senior boys dormitory, after which they spent some time in bed with the boys. In two cases attempted sexual intercourse was admitted. At first the visits were made with utmost stealth but later the girls became careless and the noise attracted the attention of the night watchman and boys Supervisor who made the discovery, actually catching five girls in the boys balcony. The visits were planned to take place shortly after the night watchman had made his hourly inspection of the dormitory. The offenders have been summarily dealt with and punishment administered fitting the seriousness of the offenses. Parents of pupils implicated were informed at once and allowed to visit the balconies.

I would appreciate very much if you would give this matter your immediate attention, conducting a further investigation to ascertain whether or not legal action may be taken against the boy who made the key and opened the storeroom.

Yours very truly,

Sgd. Leonard L. Dobbin.

Sir:

Allow me to bring to your notice a situation which we feel is worthy of consideration.

I am the engineer of File Hills Residential Indian Institute. We were engaged and moved here from Winnipeg July 145. Had our furniture and piano shipped and tracked.

We live in a separate cottage provided by the school for the engineer. As far as I know I have been satisfactory and we have tried to cooperate with the needs and interests of the school, beginning the day at 6 a.m., and quite often working till 10 p.m. at the school. I sleep and eat at the cottage. We were paid for $75 per month with maintenance, but we buy considerable food, garden seeds, and hoe the garden. We made improvements at the cottage including building and installing attachments to a western yard work, built a good garage. Mrs. Tooch, my wife voluntarily without remuneration takes timely interest in Indians—teaching stamp and music twice a week and likes to help in any special events. It is good for her as she is fond of Indian children. We rejected a more remunerative employment for this job to find a mingling with children (our home was deprived and benefit of our stay).

We feel this discharge is very unfair, and though it may be of little "bread and butter" to us we should appreciate a few words from you. It takes work and some money to move and damages goods.

She was unable to furnish any definite information as to who may have taken the purse, but stated that there was considerable unusual activity around the school with the children and their respective parents as it was the end of the school term and the children were departing to their homes for the holidays. These girls were former students at the File Hills Indian School and were well known to Mrs. Graham. In conversation with the girls she remarked to them that a certain cat had kittens and that they were upstairs in the dormitory with the result that the girls went up to see them and for this reason Mrs. Graham is suspicious of these girls being implicated in the disappearance of her purse. Automobile trouble and bad roads delayed us. The pupils have come back to the classroom after supper to try a test in Division and a test in spelling.

The classroom won't hold all the pupils assigned to this teacher, and so the "half-day system" is unescapable.

The children are clean and happy. They had no chance of a warning to "spruce up" for this visit.
Things are a bit crowded in the boys' dormitory. As usual in many schools (even where hooks are possible) the boys "hang" their day clothing on the beds. Here the bed- and night-clothes are clean and adequate.

The little fellow is ailing but there is no other place to put him.

This is pretty ancient plumbing and a prime example of what should NOT be held up to impressionable children as the product of a superior civilization. Observe that in some wash-basins a portable hand-basin has been placed to avoid the use of the drain.

A girls' bathroom. The lack of partitions makes supervision so much easier although there are those who might carp at the indelicacy that such a setup must encourage. On the centre seat I have placed an orange wrapper which was the only tissue I could find. But on each of the teacher's desks there was a roll of tissue for use in the classroom. I spoke of this to the Principal, and later I mailed each teacher a package of Kleenex without comment.

It is surprising how many of our schools fail in this training. Also it is gratifying to find a few schools where this matter is splendidly handled.
The main building and the schoolhouse (blank wall). Additional classroom space could be added here.

The electric plant is not very effective. The 32-volt system should be replaced by something in the 110-115 volt class in order to ensure ample voltage at the extremes.

The junior classroom has a full quota of pupils. Here Mr. McLean is seen talking to Mr. Scovil of the Regina office who very kindly drove the car by which I was able to get to the school. The "road" through the reserve needs more than a little attention.

Top of a fire-escape pole which leads down from a dormitory to the verandah. When the trap door is opened a bell begins and continues to ring.

The fuel supply. Principal Mclean is a pretty good planner.
The Principal has done a good job of cleaning and beautifying the grounds. Thrift and foresight characterize his activities. This little hot-house will give him all the tomato, etc. plants which he can use in his outside garden for school purposes.

As elsewhere in Saskatchewan water is a problem. This dug-out cannot be used for school water. Seepage from the barn drains down to it; moreover it is placed in a pasture where the animals drink from it. Another dug-out and well should be arranged nearer to the school (off the picture to the right).

This is the first school where I have found that the chapel has to be used as a dining hall for the pupils and the "chancel" (beyond the curtain) as the staff dining-room. Most of our schools insist on a one-purpose chapel.

Supper was served too soon after my arrival to allow for any stage-setting. The children had meat, vegetables, bread and butter, milk to drink, and a dessert of jello with a generous helping of whipped cream. The children recognized the vanilla flavouring. They were obviously used to good meals.

File Hills Residential School

(1) REPAIRS:

By now you will have received an Army Signal concerning the boiler repairs and the purchase of the lighting plant required at the above residential school.

The Minister has approved the acceptance of the tender of Greenfield Motors Limited, to the amount of $797.60 to carry out the repairs as listed in their tender of June 4th, 1948.

Yesterday we mailed a copy of purchase order 33063 covering the purchase of a lighting plant and a set of batteries from Greenfield Motors Limited.

(2) FUTURE POLICY WITH REGARD TO THE OPERATION OF THIS SCHOOL:

Two days ago, Dr. Dorey of the United Church of Canada visited this office. The contents of your letter of June 15th was discussed with him at some length and while not committing himself fully, it seems fairly evident that he is in agreement with the replacement of this residential school by day schools.

Major Clark was also present at the discussion and he too is in agreement with your recommendation. It
is understood that the two class room school block now on the site of the residential school could be used as a day school, providing transportation for the children could be arranged. It was, therefore, agreed that Major Clark would visit the school this fall and go over the roads thoroughly and decide whether bus transportation is feasible. It would be appreciated if efforts could be made to improve the roads selected to the extent required for them to be used by a heavy school bus. Our experiences with such transportation in Ontario have convinced us that good roads are essential for the provision of adequate school bus transportation.

I also understand that another day school would be required on this reserve near the File Hills colony. Would it be possible to have arrangements made for the school children at the File Hills colony to be admitted to the provincial school at Lorette?

To summarize, therefore -

(1) File Hills Residential School will be operated as a residential school during the 1948-49 academic year.

(2) A thorough survey will be completed to decide what day school facilities can be provided to replace this residential school during the 1949-50 academic year.

(3) Before the closing of this residential school is authorized, adequate educational facilities must be ready to provide for the continuance of the education of these children. In other words, we cannot close the residential school until the day schools required are complete and bus transportation is provided.

Bernard P. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

File Hills School Situation:

The photos show buildings associated with church work in the File Hills "colony." 

1. The United Church Mission house, occupied by a woman worker. It could provide room for a teacher.

2. The adjacent United Church. It is not readily adaptable for classroom purpose.

3. Shows the phone line extending to the sub-agency buildings, about 1000 yd. distant. Land for a school site could be found here, to the left of the church in photo #2.

Photo #4 shows the Roman Catholic Church and Hall. This two-story building could become a teachers' residence and classroom if the Indians of that faith press their demand for a day school also.

It is, however, a matter of opinion and if one's concept of living standards whether the File Hill Indians are ready for an abrupt transition to day schools. My own opinion is that the majority of homes need to be increased in size and improved in quality. If not, the general cultural level which...
has been achieved — and perhaps artificially maintained — by the influence of residential schools may suffer a considerable recession.

Mr. Ostrander has a large-scale map of the reserve on which the agency staff has entered the size and religious affiliation of families, existing and proposed roads, and the agricultural possibilities.

It would be possible to fill a one-room school, perhaps even a two-room school, with Protestant children at the colony, and at the same time conduct a full-time day school in the two-room school block at the U.C. residential school. This school is presently congested, and gives only part-time classwork in some grades.

The road-building programme, however, required to ensure bus service for a colony school would be quite extensive and would, perhaps, be better spread over two or three years.

A beginning of day-school instruction might be made by an adjustment in the residential pupilage to permit pupils who are conveniently and suitably housed to attend on a day-pupil schedule. To this end the basement of the existing school block could be adjusted to afford a third classroom and an activity room; or, if dormitories for either sex are reduced or abandoned, the main building could afford extra classroom accommodation.

Children could make their way on foot or in vehicles supplied by parents. Or a beginning could be made in bus service.

The advantages of centralized teaching could thus be preserved for pupils and for staff, and the necessary residential facilities retained. In view of the situation at Round Lake it would appear necessary to retain some U.C. place of refuge in the province.

C.A.T. Clark

Dear Mr. Ostrander:

I am submitting a report on William Creeley.

Sunday evening, February 13th., after being home for half an hour I went back to the school building about 5.30 P.M. When I went in some boys told me William Creeley had gone up to their dormitory. I was surprised as visiting is over at 4.30 and no visitor is allowed upstairs unless they have special permission.

I immediately went up and found him in the room of the Boys' Supervisor—Mr. Panchuck. I asked him what he was doing there and what he wanted. He replied that he wanted the Boys' Supervisor to give his children (a boy of 9 and a boy of 7) special attention and favors, and that when he came in the younger boy was crying. I told him all children here are treated alike and that none received special favors and then I asked him to leave.

I walked ahead of him to the stairs but let him go down first. When we reached the playroom he said "come on outside" I went with him to the boys' door and opened it for him. During this time I had said nothing. As he went down he suddenly rushed back and caught me by the legs and as I was totally unprepared for such a move he succeeded in pulling me down the steps. He said he wanted to fight and he called to two friends who were waiting to come and help him.

Mr. Panchuck, who had followed me, and I both tried to reason with him but he took off his coat and pulled out a knife and started swinging it around. I called to the boys who had gathered to get Mr. Reeves, the Engineer, and he came and tried to talk to him. Then I turned to go into the school and he made a race at me and as his arm went round my neck I put up my hand to save my face. The knife cut the sweater I was wearing and made a cut in the fleshy part of my right thumb. When he made the race at me Mr. Panchuck tried to come to my assistance but George Kewatin, one of the Creeleys' friends, grabbed him by the hands and held him long enough to give Creeley his chance. Creeley kept repeating that he would kill me yet and that he would come back till he did.

As I had been told by several .........................
As I had been told by several that Bill Creeley was a very dangerous man I have always treated him very carefully in an effort to avoid friction. Last September he caused considerable unpleasantness here when he threatened me because visiting hours were on Saturday from 2 to 4:30 P.M. He wanted to come on Sunday and any time he pleased. Following a talk with Mr. Booth on the matter I have allowed visiting both Saturday and Sunday afternoons from 2 to 4:30 since last October.

I phoned the police in Balcarres and they came out Sunday night. They arrested him on Tuesday and I understand the charge is common assault. He is out on bail and the case come up February 24th.

Yours truly,

(Signed) Lachlan McLean.
March 1, 1949.

6. The following is a copy of the statement obtained from Mr. McLean, principal of File Hills Indian Residential School, Sask., regarding this matter.

Sunday Feb. 13, 1949

"I Lachlan McLean, state that I am principal of File Hills Indian Residential School. At 5:30 P.M. on Sunday February 13, 1949 I came from my residence to the School. Some of the children told me Mr. Creeley was up in the boys dormitory. I went up to see what the trouble was as he had no business being up there.

I asked him what he wanted here. I couldn't make head or tail of what he was saying. I told him he better get out of here altogether, he had no business up here.

When he got to the bottom of the stairs he said will you come outside. I opened the door so he could go out and he grabbed me by the leg and pulled me downstairs to the bottom outside. I think Mr. Panchook, boys supervisor was with me. He wanted to fight. I think Mr. Panchook told him to stop. Creeley had tried to hit me but Panchook stood between me and him. Then Creeley called in two other Indians who were with him and he pulled off his coat and hat and threw it down on the ground. I told the school children to go and get Mr. Reeves the Engineer. Mr Reeves tried to reason with him. Then he took out a knife and held the knife in his hand, it was a jack knife and opened. He said I'll kill you. He made a strike at me with his right hand with the knife and it came around my neck, I put up my right hand and got a cut just behind the last knuckle of the right thumb. Mr Reeves told me I better go in. I went in. I wouldn't say he was drunk, he struck me as being partly insane.

(Sgd) Lachlan McLean

A slight cut was noted on the back of Mr. McLean's right hand, the skin was broken as a drop of blood had seeped through.

6. The following is a copy of the statement obtained from Peter Panchook, boys supervisor File Hills Indian Residential School.

Sunday Feb. 13, 1949

"I Peter Panchook state that I am boys supervisor at File Hills Indian School. About 5:45 P.M. today Feb. 13, 1949 I was up in my room. I was sitting there, there was a knock on the door, I opened it and Bill Creeley came in. I asked him what he wanted, he said one of his kids was crying downstairs. I said I couldn't help it. I told him he wasn't supposed to be up here. Then he told me he had seen Mr. McLean about it and he wouldn't pay any attention so he was going to see me.

Just about then Mr. McLean walked in. He put his hand on Creeley's shoulder and told him he had no business..."
6. (continued) had no business up there. Just then Mr. McLean put him ahead of him. Creeley said something about getting outside. I didn't exactly hear what it was. I thought there might be trouble so I went along with them. When we got to the boys outside door, Mr. McLean opened the door and told him to get out. As soon as Mr. McLean opened the door he grabbed ahead of him by the collar; as soon as he grabbed Mr. McLean, I got Mr. McLean by the shoulders and tried to hold him and Mr. Creeley grabbed Mr. McLean by the leg and he pulled Mr. McLean outside and I went with him.

While he was holding him by the leg I got him away. Creeley asked two Indians who were outside to take their coats off and help him. They came over but did not take their coats off. When I was trying to hold Creeley off one of the Indians who had a parka on caught ahead of my hand from behind and held it.

Then Creeley got Mr. McLean's leg again. Mr. Reeves came then. Then we got Creeley away from Mr. McLean.

Creeley got up on the steps, Mr. McLean was below with Mr. Reeves and myself. Creeley pulled a jack knife out of his pocket and opened it. He said any of you that makes a move is going to get it. Mr. Reeves told Mr. McLean to go in and Creeley made a dive for Mr. McLean, he took a swing at Mr. McLean with the knife and then it was rough and tumble. When Creeley dived this Indian had me by the hand again. Creeley had said to Mr. McLean I'll get you sooner or later and I'll kill you.

(Sgd) Peter Panchook.

7. The following is a copy of the statement obtained from William J. Reeves, Engineer at File Hills Indian Residential School, Sask., Sunday Feb. 13, 1949.

"I William J. Reeves, state that I am an engineer at File Hills Indian Residential School. About 5:45 P.M. on Sunday Feb. 13, 1949 one of the boys called me. I was in the staff sitting room, he told me Will Creeley was fighting Mr. McLean. I went to the boys doorway and outside. Mr. Creeley had Mr. McLean by the leg. I helped pull him off. As we parted them Creeley stood on the steps and Mr. McLean below. Myself Mr. Panchook and an Indian were between them. Creeley was using abusive language towards Mr. McLean. I didn't know what he meant. He got his pocket knife out, opened it. He was threatening Mr. McLean. He put it down for a little while. I warned him it was a serious offence to threaten anybody with a pocket knife. He brought the knife up again and he tried to jump past us. He got Mr. McLean who was leaving to go around to the front door. There was a rough and tumble and I did not see what took place. Mr. McLean went into the school I went inside myself then. After I warned him about using the knife he said he had lots of money to pay and lots of friends to help him pay. When I first got down there I asked him what the trouble was and he said Mr. McLean had put him out of the dormitory, and I told him it was Mr. McLean's duty. I remember him saying he would get Mr. McLean sooner or later."

(Sgd) W.J. Reeves.

Continued page -4-
Mr. McLean stated that he wished to take some action against Creeley but was undecided at this time as to what charge to lay and would call at Det. in connection with same following A.M. Mr. McLean and staff stated that they did not intend taking any action against either of the other Indians as they had attempted to restrain Creeley. As far as could be learned Creeley had left with the other Indians for the reserve. Mr. McLean stated that the routine of the school was badly upset as a result of the incident and at his request Sgt. Irvine remained at the school overnight returning to Det. following A.M.

14-2-49

This A.M., Mr. McLean called at Det. and after discussing the matter advised that he intended to lay a charge of Common Assault under Sec. 291 of the Criminal Code against Creeley. Same date Mr. McLean appeared before Mr. Arthur E. GRAHAM, J.S.C. of Fort Qu'Appelle and laid a charge under Sec. 291 of the code and warrant to apprehend was issued for Creeley.

15-2-49

At 9:00 A.M. this date the writer accompanied by Sgt. Irvine patrolled per I.A. Code 2564 to File Hills Indian Residential School and continued per team, gratis, to File Hills Indian reserve where CREELEY was taken into custody. At this time he stated he had lost his knife out where he had been skinning a deer.

Patrol continued per I.A. Code 2564 to Fort Qu'Appelle where William CREELEY appeared before Mr. Arthur E. GRAHAM J.S.C. and made application for bail. Same was granted and Creeley was released on bail after entering into his own recognizance in the amount of $100.00 to appear 2:00 P.M. 24-2-49 H.O.M.P. Court Balcarres. Patrol returned to Det. 4:30 P.M.

24-2-49

At 12:00 A.M. this date the writer accompanied by Sgt. Irvine patrolled per I.A. Code 2564 to File Hills Indian Residential School were copies of Summons to Defendant under the hand of Arthur E. GRAHAM, J.S.C. were personally served by Sgt. Irvine on William J. REEVES and Peter PANCHUK, same being returnable at H.O.M.P. Court. 2:00 P.M. 24-2-49. Patrol continued on other duties.

At 2:00 P.M. this date William CREELEY appeared before Mr. Arthur E. GRAHAM J.S.C. at Balcarres and entered a plea of Not Guilty to the charge. He was represented by Mr. G.W. TRUSCOTT Barrister of Melville, Sask.

Mr. L. McLean, William J. REEVES and Peter PANCHUK were called as witnesses for the prosecution and gave evidence along the lines of their statements already recorded.

William CREELEY, Defendant gave evidence on his own behalf to the effect that he had gone to see Mr. McLean in the school because one of his children had been crying. He had been told to get out and Mr. McLean shoved him. He had pulled his knife out on the steps but had not intended
16. (continued) to use it. He had not lunged at Mr. Mclean and had never been close enough with the knife to touch him. He stated he was a councillor of his band and was interested in investigating conditions at the school on his own.

16. Howard Creeley, brother of Wm. Creeley gave evidence of seeing his brother on the steps with the knife but George Kenatin had taken it away from him and he had never lunged at Mr. Mclean with it. It appeared to him that his brother was trying to scare Mr. Mclean.

17. George Kenatin gave evidence that he had come out to the fight and saw Creeley on the steps with the knife he had taken it away from him and he had never made any attempt to strike Mr. Mclean.

18. His Worship found Creeley Guilty as charged and sentenced him to 2 months in Regina Common Gaol. He remarked that Creeley appeared to have reform of the schools in mind but that nothing would be accomplished by the use of force and it was contrary to the principles of this country and warned him to control his temper in the future.

24-2-49

19. At 9:00 P.M., this date the writer accompanied by Sgt. Irvine patrolled per P.A. Code 3564 to Regina escorting prisoner William Creeley. Creeley was handed over to Night Guard at Regina City Police Cells, warrant together with his effects were handed over to Night Guard at Regina Town Station and a receipt obtained which is attached hereto. Patrol returned to Det. 1:45 A.M. 25-2-49.

Dear Dr. Dorey:

File Hills Residential School.

The Superintendent of Education returned here this morning, and has reported on the discussion held with Mrs. Loveys, Mrs. Robertson and yourself concerning the future of the above residential school.

This will confirm the following proposals made by Colonel Neary:

(1) That the File Hills Residential School cease to function as a residential school on June 30, 1949.
(2) That a new day school be erected at the File Hills colony to provide educational facilities for the children within walking distance of the proposed site.
(3) That the present classroom block at the residential school be operated as the second two-room day school and that this provide educational facilities for the children within walking distance.
(4) That the six or eight children who could not attend these two day schools as proposed above, be sent to the Portage la Prairie or Brandon residential schools.
(5) That all furniture and equipment at the File Hills residential school be transferred to the Brandon, Portage la Prairie, or Round Lake residential schools as required.
(6) That the qualified teachers at the school be retained, if they so desire, at the two proposed day schools.
(7) That accommodation for the day school teachers will be provided at the new colony day school, and that the principal's or farmer's residence at the residential school be used as teachers' residence for the day school there.
You have been left the photostatic map prepared by Mr. Indian Superintendent Booth showing all the Indian homes on the Reserve. You will note that we are locating these schools to provide educational facilities for the United Church children.

I would be pleased to hear from you after the Women's Missionary Society executive has met and decided concerning the proposals made.

Yours sincerely,

Director.

Rev. George Dorey, D.D.,
Secretary,
Board of Home Missions
of the United Church of Canada,

Toronto 2B, Ontario.

Dear Colonel Neary:

I have been requested by the Secretary of The Woman's Missionary Society to inform you that the Society is in accord with the suggestion that the File Hills School be closed on June 30th, 1949, as a residential school. NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.
